[A YANKEE IN [CANADA]1-canada]739-a yankee in canada .

-------

“ [New England]20-new england is by some affirmed to be [an island]5225-an island , bounded on [the north with [the River Canada]21-the river canada]5226-the north with the river canada ( so called from [Monsieur Cane).”—JOSSELYN[402-wendell phillips] ’S RARETIES]403-monsieur cane).”—josselyn ’s rareties .

And still older , in [Thomas Morton]404-thomas morton ’s “ New English Canaan , ”[404-thomas morton] published in 1632 , it is said , on page 97 , “ From [[this Lake]39-the lake]5227-this lake [ [Erocoise ] Northwards]22-erocoise ] northwards is derived [the famous River of [Canada]1-canada]5228-the famous river of canada , so named , of [Monsieur de Cane]406-monsieur de cane , [a French Lord , who first planted [a Colony of French]5230-a colony of french in [America]23-america]5229-a french lord , who first planted a colony of french in america . ”[404-thomas morton]

------------------------------------------------------------------------

CHAPTER I.

CONCORD TO [MONTREAL]15-montreal .

[I]0-i fear that [I]0-i have not got much to say about [Canada]1-canada , not having seen much ; what [I]0-i got by going to [Canada]1-canada was a cold . [I]0-i left [Concord]24-concord , [Massachusetts]12-massachusetts , Wednesday morning , September 25th , 1850 , for [Quebec]16-quebec . Fare , seven dollars there and back ; distance from [Boston]8-boston , five hundred and ten miles ; being obliged to leave [Montreal]15-montreal on the return as soon as Friday , October 4th , or within ten days . [I]0-i will not stop to tell [the reader]747-the reader the names of [[my]0-i fellow - travellers]748-my fellow - travellers ; there were said to be [fifteen hundred of [them]749-fifteen hundred of them]749-fifteen hundred of them . [I]0-i wished only to be set down in [Canada]1-canada , and take one honest walk there as [I]0-i might in [Concord]24-concord woods of an afternoon .

[The country]750-the country was new to [me]0-i beyond [Fitchburg]25-fitchburg . In [Ashburnham]26-ashburnham and afterward , as [we]751-we were whirled rapidly along , [I]0-i noticed the woodbine ( _ Ampelopsis quinquefolia _ ) , its leaves now changed , for the most part on dead trees , draping them like a red scarf . It was a little exciting , suggesting bloodshed , or at least a military life , like an epaulet or sash , as if it were dyed with the blood of the trees whose wounds it was inadequate to stanch . For now the bloody autumn was come , and an Indian warfare was waged through [the forest]752-the forest . These military trees appeared very numerous , for [our]751-we rapid progress connected those that were even some miles apart . Does the woodbine prefer the elm ? The first view of [Monadnoc]407-monadnoc was obtained five or six miles [this side of [Fitzwilliam]27-fitzwilliam]753-this side of fitzwilliam , but nearest and best at [Troy]28-troy and beyond . Then there were [the Troy cuts and embankments]754-the troy cuts and embankments . [Keene Street]29-keene street strikes [the traveller]755-the traveller favorably , it is so wide , level , straight , and long . [I]0-i have heard one of [[my]0-i relatives , who was born and bred there]756-my relatives , who was born and bred there , say that [you]757-you could see a chicken run across it a mile off . [I]0-i have also been told that when [this town]758-this town was settled [they]759-they laid out [a street]760-a street four rods wide , but at a subsequent meeting of [the proprietors]761-the proprietors one rose and remarked , “ [We]765-our have plenty of land , why not make [the street]5231-the street eight rods wide ? ”[761-the proprietors] and so [they]759-they voted that it should be eight rods wide , and [the town]762-the town is known far and near for [[its]762-the town handsome street]763-its handsome street . It was a cheap way of securing comfort , as well as fame , and [I]0-i wish that [all new towns]764-all new towns would take pattern from this . It is best to lay [our]765-our plans widely in youth , for then [land]766-land is cheap , and it is but too easy to contract [our]765-our views afterward . [Youths]767-youths so laid out , with [broad avenues and parks]768-broad avenues and parks , that [they]767-youths may make [handsome and liberal old men]769-handsome and liberal old men ! Show [me]0-i a youth whose mind is like [some Washington city of magnificent distances]770-some washington city of magnificent distances , prepared for the most remotely successful and glorious life after all , when [those spaces]771-those spaces shall be built over and the idea of [the founder]772-the founder be realized . [I]0-i trust that [every New England boy]773-every new england boy will begin by laying out [a Keene Street]774-a keene street through [his]773-every new england boy head , eight rods wide . [I]0-i know [one such [Washington]30-washington city of [a man , whose lots as yet are only surveyed and staked out , and except a cluster of shanties here and there]776-a man , whose lots as yet are only surveyed and staked out , and except a cluster of shanties here and there]775-one such washington city of a man , whose lots as yet are only surveyed and staked out , and except a cluster of shanties here and there , only [the Capitol]777-the capitol stands there for [all structures]778-all structures , and any day [you]779-you may see from afar [his]773-every new england boy princely idea borne coachwise along the spacious but yet empty avenues . [Keene]408-keene is built on a remarkably large and level interval , like the bed of [a lake]780-a lake , and the surrounding hills , which are remote from [[its]777-the capitol street]781-its street , must afford some good walks . The scenery of [mountain towns]782-mountain towns is commonly too much crowded . [A town]783-a town which is built on a plain of some extent , with an open horizon , and surrounded by hills at a distance , affords the best walks and views .

As [we]784-we travel northwest up [the country]750-the country , sugar - maples , beeches , birches , hemlocks , spruce , butternuts , and ash trees prevail more and more . To [the rapid traveller]786-the rapid traveller the number of elms in [a town]783-a town is the measure of its civility . [One man]788-one man in [the cars]789-the cars has a bottle full of some liquor . [The whole company]790-the whole company smile whenever it is exhibited . [I]0-i find no difficulty in containing [myself]0-i . [The Westmoreland country]791-the westmoreland country looked attractive . [I]0-i heard [a passenger]792-a passenger giving the very obvious derivation of this name , [West - more - land]793-west - more - land , as if it were purely American , and [he]788-one man had made a discovery ; but [I]0-i thought of “ [[my]788-one man cousin]5232-my cousin Westmoreland ”[788-one man] in [England]31-england . [Every one]794-every one will remember the approach to [Bellows Falls]32-bellows falls , under a high cliff which rises from the [Connecticut]33-connecticut . [I]0-i was disappointed in the size of [the river here]795-the river here ; it appeared shrunk to [a mere mountain stream]796-a mere mountain stream . [The water]797-the water was evidently very low . [The rivers which [we]799-we had crossed [this forenoon]34-this forenoon]798-the rivers which we had crossed this forenoon possessed more of the character of [mountain streams]800-mountain streams than those in [the vicinity of [Concord]24-concord]801-the vicinity of concord , and [I]0-i was surprised to see everywhere traces of recent freshets , which had carried away [bridges]802-bridges and injured [the railroad]803-the railroad , though [I]0-i had heard nothing of it . In [Ludlow]35-ludlow , [Mount Holly]36-mount holly , and beyond , there is interesting mountain scenery , not rugged and stupendous , but such as [you]804-you could easily ramble over,—long narrow mountain vales through which to see the horizon . [You]804-you are in [the midst of [the Green Mountains]806-the green mountains]805-the midst of the green mountains . [A few more elevated blue peaks]807-a few more elevated blue peaks are seen from [the neighborhood of [Mount Holly]36-mount holly]808-the neighborhood of mount holly , perhaps [Killington Peak]37-killington peak is one . Sometimes , as on [the Western Railroad]809-the western railroad , [you]810-you are whirled over mountainous embankments , from which the scared horses in [the valleys]811-the valleys appear diminished to hounds . [All the hills]812-all the hills blush ; [I]0-i think that autumn must be the best season to journey over even [the _ Green _ Mountains]813-the _ green _ mountains . [You]810-you frequently exclaim to [yourself]810-you , what _ red _ maples ! The sugar - maple is not so red . [You]810-you see some of the latter with rosy spots or cheeks only , blushing on one side like fruit , while all the rest of the tree is green , proving either some partiality in the light or frosts , or some prematurity in particular branches . Tall and slender ash trees , whose foliage is turned to a dark mulberry color , are frequent . The butternut , which is a remarkably spreading tree , is turned completely yellow , thus proving its relation to the hickories . [I]0-i was also struck by the bright yellow tints of the yellow - birch . The sugar - maple is remarkable for its clean ankle . The groves of these trees looked like vast forest sheds , [their]812-all the hills branches stopping short at a uniform height , four or five feet from the ground , like eaves , as if [they]812-all the hills had been trimmed by art , so that [you]810-you could look under and through [the whole grove]814-the whole grove with its leafy canopy , as under a tent whose curtain is raised .

As [you]810-you approach [Lake Champlain]42-lake champlain [you]810-you begin to see [the New York mountains]815-the new york mountains . The first view of [the Lake]39-the lake at [Vergennes]40-vergennes is impressive , but rather from association than from any peculiarity in the scenery . It lies there so small ( not appearing in that proportion to the width of [the State]816-the state that it does on the map ) , but beautifully quiet , like a picture of [the Lake of [Lucerne]41-lucerne]817-the lake of lucerne on a music - box , where [you]810-you trace the name of [Lucerne]41-lucerne among the foliage ; far more ideal than ever [it]41-lucerne looked on the map . It does not say , “ Here [I]818-the conductor am , [Lake Champlain]42-lake champlain , ”[818-the conductor] as [the conductor]818-the conductor might for it , but having studied the geography thirty years , [you]810-you crossed over [a hill]819-a hill one afternoon and beheld it . But it is only a glimpse that [you]810-you get [here]820-here . At [Burlington]43-burlington [you]810-you rush to [a wharf]821-a wharf and go on board [a steamboat]822-a steamboat , two hundred and thirty - two miles from [Boston]8-boston . [We]823-we left [Concord]24-concord at twenty minutes before eight in the morning , and were in [Burlington]43-burlington about six at night , but too late to see [the lake]824-the lake . [We]823-we got [our]823-we first fair view of [the lake]824-the lake at dawn , just before reaching [Plattsburg]44-plattsburg , and saw [blue ranges of mountains]826-blue ranges of mountains on either hand , in [New York]45-new york and in [Vermont]46-vermont , the former especially grand . [A few white schooners , like gulls]827-a few white schooners , like gulls , were seen in the distance , for it is not waste and solitary like [a lake in [Tartary]47-tartary]828-a lake in tartary ; but it was such a view as leaves not much to be said ; indeed , [I]0-i have postponed [Lake Champlain]42-lake champlain to another day .

The oldest reference to these waters that [I]0-i have yet seen is in the account of [Cartier]410-cartier ’s discovery and exploration of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence in 1535 . [Samuel Champlain]411-champlain actually discovered and paddled up [the Lake]39-the lake in July , 1609 , eleven years before [the settlement of [Plymouth]49-plymouth]829-the settlement of plymouth , accompanying a war - party of [the Canadian Indians]412-the indians against [the Iroquois]413-the iroquois . [He]42-lake champlain describes [the islands]830-the islands in [it]830-the islands as not inhabited , although [they]830-the islands are pleasant,—on account of the continual wars of [the Indians]412-the indians , in consequence of which [they]412-the indians withdraw from [the rivers]831-the rivers and [lakes]832-lakes into [the depths of [the land]834-the land]833-the depths of the land , that [they]412-the indians may not be surprised . “ Continuing [our]5233-our course , ”[42-lake champlain] says [he]42-lake champlain , “ in [this lake]5227-this lake , on the western side , viewing [the country]750-the country , [I]42-lake champlain saw on the eastern side very [high mountains]5236-high mountains , where there was snow on the summit . [I]42-lake champlain inquired of the savages if those places were inhabited . [They]835-the number of french - canadian gentlemen and ladies among the passengers replied that [they]835-the number of french - canadian gentlemen and ladies among the passengers were , and that [they]835-the number of french - canadian gentlemen and ladies among the passengers were Iroquois , and that in those places there were [beautiful valleys]5237-beautiful valleys and [plains fertile in corn]5238-plains fertile in corn , such as [I]42-lake champlain have eaten in [this country]5239-this country , with an infinity of other fruits . ”[42-lake champlain] This is the earliest account of what is now [Vermont]46-vermont .

[The number of [French - Canadian gentlemen and [ladies]837-ladies among [the passengers]838-the passengers]836-french - canadian gentlemen and ladies among the passengers]835-the number of french - canadian gentlemen and ladies among the passengers , and the sound of the French language , advertised [us]839-we by this time that [we]839-we were being whirled towards some foreign vortex . And now [we]839-we have left [[Rouse]414-rouse ’s Point]840-rouse ’s point , and entered [the Sorel River]50-the sorel river , and passed the invisible barrier between [the States]841-the states and [Canada]1-canada . [The shores of [the Sorel]51-the sorel]842-the shores of the sorel , [Richelieu]52-richelieu , or [St. John ’s River]53-st. john ’s river , are flat and reedy , where [I]0-i had expected something more rough and mountainous for a natural boundary between [two nations]843-two nations . Yet [I]0-i saw a difference at once , in [the few huts]844-the few huts , in [the pirogues on the shore]845-the pirogues on the shore , and as [it]845-the pirogues on the shore were , in [the shore]846-the shore itself . This was an interesting scenery to [me]0-i , and the very reeds or rushes in [the shallow water]847-the shallow water , and the tree - tops in [the swamps]848-the swamps , have left a pleasing impression . [We]839-we had still a distant view behind [us]839-we of two or [three blue mountains in [Vermont]46-vermont and [New York]45-new york]849-three blue mountains in vermont and new york . About nine o’clock in the forenoon [we]839-we reached [St. John ’s]54-st. john ’s , an old frontier post three hundred and six miles from [Boston]8-boston and twenty - four from [Montreal]15-montreal . [We]839-we now discovered that [we]839-we were in [a foreign country]850-a foreign country , in [a station - house of [another nation]852-another nation]851-a station - house of another nation . [This building]853-this building was [a barn - like structure]854-a barn - like structure , looking as if [it]853-this building were the work of [the villagers]855-the villagers combined , like [a log - house in [a new settlement]857-a new settlement]856-a log - house in a new settlement . [My]0-i attention was caught by the double advertisements in French and English fastened to [its]856-a log - house in a new settlement posts , by the formality of the English , and the covert or open reference to [[their]855-the villagers queen]858-their queen and [the British lion]859-the british lion . [No gentlemanly conductor]860-no gentlemanly conductor appeared , [none whom [you]862-you would know to be [the conductor]818-the conductor by [his]818-the conductor dress and demeanor]861-none whom you would know to be the conductor by his dress and demeanor ; but erelong [we]839-we began to see here and there [a solid , red - faced , burly - looking Englishman]864-a solid , red - faced , burly - looking englishman , [a little pursy perhaps , who made [us]839-we ashamed of [ourselves]839-we and [[our]839-we thin and nervous countrymen,—a grandfatherly personage]866-our thin and nervous countrymen,—a grandfatherly personage]865-a little pursy perhaps , who made us ashamed of ourselves and our thin and nervous countrymen,—a grandfatherly personage , at [home]867-home in [his]865-a little pursy perhaps , who made us ashamed of ourselves and our thin and nervous countrymen,—a grandfatherly personage great - coat , who looked as if [he]865-a little pursy perhaps , who made us ashamed of ourselves and our thin and nervous countrymen,—a grandfatherly personage might be [a stage proprietor]868-a stage proprietor , certainly [a railroad director]869-a railroad director , and knew , or had a right to know , when [the cars]789-the cars did start . Then there were two or [three pale - faced , black - eyed , loquacious Canadian French gentlemen there , shrugging [their]789-the cars shoulders]871-three pale - faced , black - eyed , loquacious canadian french gentlemen there , shrugging their shoulders ; pitted as if [they]789-the cars had all had the small - pox . In the mean while [some soldiers]872-some soldiers , red - coats , belonging to [the barracks near by]873-the barracks near by , were turned out to be drilled . At every important point in [our]839-we route [the soldiers]874-the soldiers showed [themselves]874-the soldiers ready for [us]839-we ; though [they]874-the soldiers were evidently rather raw recruits here , [they]874-the soldiers manœuvred far better than [[our]839-we soldiers]875-our soldiers ; yet , as usual , [I]0-i heard [some Yankees]876-some yankees talk as if [they]876-some yankees were no great shakes , and [they]876-some yankees had seen the Acton Blues manœuvre as well . [The officers]877-the officers spoke sharply to [them]877-the officers , and appeared to be doing [their]877-the officers part thoroughly . [I]0-i heard [one suddenly coming to the rear]878-one suddenly coming to the rear , exclaim , “ [Michael Donouy]415-michael donouy , take [his]415-michael donouy name ! ”[0-i] though [I]0-i could not see what the latter did or omitted to do . It was whispered that [Michael Donouy]415-michael donouy would have to suffer for that . [I]0-i heard some of [[our]839-we party]879-our party discussing the possibility of [their]879-our party driving [these troops]880-these troops off [the field]881-the field with [their]879-our party umbrellas . [I]0-i thought that [the Yankee]882-the yankee , though undisciplined , had this advantage at least , that [he]415-michael donouy especially is [a man who , everywhere and under all circumstances , is fully resolved to better [his]415-michael donouy condition essentially , and therefore [he]415-michael donouy could afford to be beaten at first]883-a man who , everywhere and under all circumstances , is fully resolved to better his condition essentially , and therefore he could afford to be beaten at first ; while the virtue of [the Irishman]884-the irishman , and to a great extent [the Englishman]885-the englishman , consists in merely maintaining [his]885-the englishman ground or condition . [The Canadians]416-the french [here]820-here , a rather poor - looking race , clad in gray homespun , which gave [them]416-the french the appearance of being covered with dust , were riding about in caleches and [small one - horse carts called charettes]887-small one - horse carts called charettes . [The Yankees]888-the yankees assumed that [all the riders]889-all the riders were racing , or at least exhibiting the paces of [their]889-all the riders horses , and saluted [them]889-all the riders accordingly . [We]890-we saw but little of [the village]891-the village here , for [nobody]892-nobody could tell [us]890-we when [the cars]789-the cars would start ; that was kept a profound secret , perhaps for political reasons ; and therefore [we]890-we were tied to [our]890-we seats . [The inhabitants of [[St. John]54-st. john ’s ’s and vicinity]895-st. john ’s and vicinity]894-the inhabitants of st. john ’s and vicinity are described by [an English traveller]896-an english traveller as “ singularly unprepossessing , ”[896-an english traveller] and before completing [his]896-an english traveller period [he]896-an english traveller adds , “ besides , [they]894-the inhabitants of st. john ’s and vicinity are generally very much disaffected to the British crown . ”[896-an english traveller] [I]0-i suspect that that “ besides ”[896-an english traveller] should have been a because .

At length , about noon , [the cars]789-the cars began to roll towards [La Prairie]56-la prairie . The whole distance of fifteen miles was over [a remarkably level country]898-a remarkably level country , resembling [a Western prairie]899-a western prairie , with [the mountains about Chambly visible in the northeast]900-the mountains about chambly visible in the northeast . This novel , but monotonous scenery , was exciting . At [La Prairie]56-la prairie [we]890-we first took notice of the tinned roofs , but above all of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence , which looked like [a lake]780-a lake ; in fact it is considerably expanded here ; it was nine miles across diagonally to [Montreal]15-montreal . [Mount Royal]57-mount royal in [the rear of [the city]903-the city]902-the rear of the city , and [the island of [St. Helen]58-st. helen ’s opposite to [it]56-la prairie]904-the island of st. helen ’s opposite to it , were now conspicuous . [We]890-we could also see the [Sault St. Louis]59-sault st. louis about five miles up [the river]905-the river , and [the Sault Norman]417-the sault norman still farther eastward . [The former]906-the former are described as [the most considerable rapids in the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]907-the most considerable rapids in the st. lawrence ; but [we]890-we could see merely a gleam of light there as from a cobweb in the sun . Soon [the city of Montreal]908-the city of montreal was discovered with [its]908-the city of montreal tin roofs shining afar . [Their]908-the city of montreal reflections fell on the eye like a clash of cymbals on the ear . Above all [the church of [Notre Dame]61-notre dame]909-the church of notre dame was conspicuous , and anon [the Bonsecours market - house]910-the bonsecours market - house , occupying a commanding position on [the quay]911-the quay , in the rear of [the shipping]912-the shipping . [This city]913-this city makes the more favorable impression from being approached by water , and also being built of stone , a gray limestone found on [the island]914-the island . Here , after travelling directly inland [the whole breadth of [New England]20-new england]915-the whole breadth of new england , [we]890-we had struck upon [a city]916-a city ’s harbor,—it made on [me]0-i the impression of a seaport,—to which [ships of six hundred tons]917-ships of six hundred tons can ascend , and where [vessels]918-vessels drawing fifteen feet lie close to [the wharf]919-the wharf , five hundred and forty miles from [the Gulf]62-the gulf ; the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence being here two miles wide . There was [a great crowd assembled on [the ferry - boat wharf]921-the ferry - boat wharf]920-a great crowd assembled on the ferry - boat wharf and on [the quay]911-the quay to receive [the Yankees]888-the yankees , and flags of all colors were streaming from [the vessels]924-the vessels to celebrate [their]924-the vessels arrival . When the gun was fired , [the gentry]925-the gentry hurrahed again and again , and then [the Canadian caleche - drivers , who were most interested in the matter , and who , [I]0-i perceived]926-the canadian caleche - drivers , who were most interested in the matter , and who , i perceived , were separated from the former by a fence , hurrahed [their]926-the canadian caleche - drivers , who were most interested in the matter , and who , i perceived welcome ; first the broadcloth , then the homespun .

It was early in the afternoon when [we]890-we stepped ashore . With [a single companion]927-a single companion , [I]0-i soon found [my]0-i way to [the church of [Notre Dame]61-notre dame]909-the church of notre dame . [I]0-i saw that it was of great size and signified something . It is said to be [the largest ecclesiastical structure in [North America]63-north america]929-the largest ecclesiastical structure in north america , and can seat ten thousand . It is two hundred and fifty - five and a half feet long , and the groined ceiling is eighty feet above [your]930-your head . [The Catholic]931-the catholic are [the only churches which [I]0-i have seen worth remembering , which are not almost wholly profane]932-the only churches which i have seen worth remembering , which are not almost wholly profane . [I]0-i do not speak only of the rich and splendid like this , but of the humblest of [them]932-the only churches which i have seen worth remembering , which are not almost wholly profane as well . Coming from [the hurrahing mob]933-the hurrahing mob and [the rattling carriages]934-the rattling carriages , [we]890-we pushed aside the listed door of [this church]935-this church , and found [ourselves]890-we instantly in an atmosphere which might be sacred to thought and religion , if [one]936-one had any . There sat [one or two women who had stolen a moment from the concerns of the day , as [they]937-one or two women who had stolen a moment from the concerns of the day , as they were passing were passing]937-one or two women who had stolen a moment from the concerns of the day , as they were passing ; but , if there had been [fifty people]938-fifty people [there]939-there , it would still have been the most solitary place imaginable . [They]938-fifty people did not look up at [us]890-we , nor did one regard another . [We]890-we walked softly down the broad - aisle with [our]890-we hats in [our]890-we hands . Presently came in [a troop of Canadians]940-a troop of canadians , in [their]940-a troop of canadians homespun , who had come to [the city]903-the city in [the boat]942-the boat with [us]890-we , and one and all kneeled down in the aisle before the high altar to [their]940-a troop of canadians devotions , somewhat awkwardly , as cattle prepare to lie down , and there [we]890-we left [them]940-a troop of canadians . As if [you]943-you were to catch [[some farmer]944-some farmer ’s sons from [Marlboro]64-marlboro]945-some farmer ’s sons from marlboro , come to cattle - show , silently kneeling in [Concord meeting - house some Wednesday]946-concord meeting - house some wednesday ! Would there not soon be a mob peeping in at the windows ? It is true , [these Roman Catholics]947-these roman catholics , [priests]948-priests and all , impress [me]0-i as [a people who have fallen far behind the significance of [their]949-a people who have fallen far behind the significance of their symbols symbols]949-a people who have fallen far behind the significance of their symbols . It is as if an ox had strayed into [a church]950-a church and were trying to bethink [himself]945-some farmer ’s sons from marlboro . Nevertheless , [they]949-a people who have fallen far behind the significance of their symbols are capable of reverence ; but [we]890-we [Yankees]418-yankees are [a people in whom this sentiment]951-a people in whom this sentiment has nearly died out , and in this respect [we]890-we can not bethink [ourselves]890-we even as oxen . [I]0-i did not mind the pictures nor the candles , whether tallow or tin . Those of the former which [I]0-i looked at appeared tawdry . It matters little to [me]0-i whether the pictures are by a neophyte of [the Algonquin]419-the algonquin or [the Italian tribe]952-the italian tribe . But [I]0-i was impressed by the quiet religious atmosphere of [the place]953-the place . It was a great cave in the midst of [a city]916-a city ; and what were the altars and the tinsel but the sparkling stalactics , into which [you]955-you entered in a moment , and where the still atmosphere and the sombre light disposed to serious and profitable thought ? Such [a cave at hand , which [you]955-you can enter any day , is worth a thousand of [[our]890-we churches]957-our churches which are open only Sundays,—hardly long enough for an airing,—and then filled with [a bustling congregation,—a church where [the priest]959-the priest is the least part , where [you]960-you do [your]960-you own preaching , where the universe preaches to [you]960-you and can be heard]958-a bustling congregation,—a church where the priest is the least part , where you do your own preaching , where the universe preaches to you and can be heard]956-a cave at hand , which you can enter any day , is worth a thousand of our churches which are open only sundays,—hardly long enough for an airing,—and then filled with a bustling congregation,—a church where the priest is the least part , where you do your own preaching , where the universe preaches to you and can be heard . [I]0-i am not sure but this Catholic religion would be an admirable one if [the priest]959-the priest were quite omitted . [I]0-i think that [I]0-i might go to [church]962-church [myself]0-i sometimes some Monday , if [I]0-i lived in [a city]916-a city where there was such a one to go to . In Concord , to be sure , [we]890-we do not need such . [Our]890-we forests are such [a church , far grander and more sacred]964-a church , far grander and more sacred . [We]890-we dare not leave _ [[our]890-we _ meeting - houses]965-our _ meeting - houses open for fear [they]965-our _ meeting - houses would be profaned . Such a cave , such a shrine , in one of [[our]890-we groves]966-our groves , for instance , how long would it be respected ? for what purposes would it be entered , by such baboons as [we]890-we are ? [I]0-i think of its value not only to religion , but to philosophy and to poetry ; besides [a reading - room]967-a reading - room , to have [a thinking - room in [every city]969-every city]968-a thinking - room in every city ! Perchance the time will come when [every house]970-every house even will have not only [[its]970-every house sleeping - rooms]971-its sleeping - rooms , and [dining - room]972-dining - room , and [talking - room]973-talking - room or [parlor]974-parlor , but [[its]970-every house thinking - room]975-its thinking - room also , and [the architects]976-the architects will put it into [their]976-the architects plans . Let it be furnished and ornamented with whatever conduces to serious and creative thought . [I]0-i should not object to the holy water , or any other simple symbol , if it were consecrated by the imagination of [the worshippers]977-the worshippers .

[I]0-i heard that [some Yankees]876-some yankees bet that the candles were not wax , but tin . [A European]979-a european assured [them]876-some yankees that [they]876-some yankees were wax ; but , inquiring of the sexton , [he]979-a european was surprised to learn that [they]876-some yankees were tin filled with oil . [The church]980-the church was too poor to afford wax . As for [the Protestant churches]981-the protestant churches , here or elsewhere , [they]981-the protestant churches did not interest [me]0-i , for it is only as caves that churches interest [me]0-i at all , and in that respect [they]981-the protestant churches were inferior .

[Montreal]15-montreal makes the impression of [a larger city than [you]983-you had expected to find]982-a larger city than you had expected to find , though [you]983-you may have heard that it contains nearly sixty thousand inhabitants . In the newer parts it appeared to be growing fast like a small [New York]45-new york , and to be considerably [Americanized]65-americanized . The names of the squares reminded [you]983-you of [Paris,—the Champ de Mars]66-champ de mars , [the Place d’Armes]984-the place d’armes , and [others]985-others , and [you]983-you felt as if a French revolution might break out any moment . Glimpses of [Mount Royal]57-mount royal rising behind [the town]762-the town , and the names of [some streets]987-some streets in that direction , make one think of [Edinburgh]67-edinburgh . [That hill]988-that hill sets off [this city]913-this city wonderfully . [I]0-i inquired at [a principal bookstore for books published in [Montreal]15-montreal]990-a principal bookstore for books published in montreal . [They]991-they said that there were none but school - books and the like ; [they]991-they got [their]991-they books from [the States]841-the states . From time to time [we]993-we met [a priest in [the streets]995-the streets]994-a priest in the streets , for [they]994-a priest in the streets are distinguished by [their]994-a priest in the streets dress , like the _ civil _ police . Like [clergymen]996-clergymen generally , with or without the gown , [they]994-a priest in the streets made on [us]993-we the impression of effeminacy . [We]993-we also met [some Sisters of Charity , dressed in black , with Shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces , who looked as if [they]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces had almost cried [their]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces eyes out , [their]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces complexions parboiled with scalding tears ; insulting the daylight by [their]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces presence , having taken an oath not to smile . By cadaverous [I]0-i mean that [their]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces faces were like the faces of [those who have been dead and buried for a year]998-those who have been dead and buried for a year , and then untombed , with the life ’s grief upon [them]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces , and yet , for some unaccountable reason , the process of decay arrested .

“ Truth never fails [[her]5240-her servant]5241-her servant , [sir]5242-sir , nor leaves [him]5242-sir With the day ’s shame upon [him]5242-sir . ”[997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces]

[They]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces waited demurely on [the sidewalk]999-the sidewalk while [a truck]1000-a truck laden with raisins was driven in at [the seminary of [St. Sulpice]68-st. sulpice]1001-the seminary of st. sulpice , never once lifting [their]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces eyes from the ground .

[The soldier]1002-the soldier here , as everywhere in [Canada]1-canada , appeared to be put forward , and by [his]1002-the soldier best foot . [They]997-some sisters of charity , dressed in black , with shaker - shaped black bonnets and crosses , and cadaverous faces were in the proportion of [the soldiers]874-the soldiers to [the laborers in [an African ant - hill]1005-an african ant - hill]1004-the laborers in an african ant - hill . [The inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants evidently rely on [them]1006-the inhabitants in a great measure for music and entertainment . [You]1007-you would meet with [them]1006-the inhabitants pacing back and forth before [some guard - house]1008-some guard - house or passage - way , guarding , regarding , and disregarding all kinds of law by turns , apparently for the sake of the discipline to [themselves]1006-the inhabitants , and not because it was important to exclude [anybody]1009-anybody from entering that way . [They]1006-the inhabitants reminded [me]0-i of [the men who are paid for piling up bricks]1010-the men who are paid for piling up bricks and then throwing [them]1010-the men who are paid for piling up bricks down again . On every prominent ledge [you]1011-you could see [England]31-england ’s hands holding [the Canadas]133-the canadas , and [I]0-i judged by the redness of [her]1012-her knuckles that [she]1012-her would soon have to let go . In the rear of [such a guard - house]1013-such a guard - house , in [a large gravelled square or parade - ground]1014-a large gravelled square or parade - ground , called [the Champ de Mars]66-champ de mars , [we]1015-we saw a large body of [soldiers]1016-soldiers being drilled , [we]1015-we being as yet [the only spectators]1017-the only spectators . But [they]1017-the only spectators did not appear to notice [us]1015-we any more than [the devotees in [the church]980-the church]1018-the devotees in the church , but were seemingly as indifferent to fewness of [spectators]1020-spectators as the phenomena of nature are , whatever [they]1020-spectators might have been thinking under [their]1020-spectators helmets of [the Yankees that were to come]1021-the yankees that were to come . [Each man]1022-each man wore white kid gloves . It was one of the most interesting sights which [I]0-i saw in [Canada]1-canada . The problem appeared to be how to smooth down all individual protuberances or idiosyncrasies , and make [a thousand men]1023-a thousand men move as [one man]788-one man , animated by one central will ; and there was some approach to success . [They]1017-the only spectators obeyed the signals of [a commander who stood at a great distance , wand in hand]1025-a commander who stood at a great distance , wand in hand ; and the precision , and promptness , and harmony of [their]1017-the only spectators movements could not easily have been matched . The harmony was far more remarkable than that of any choir or band , and obtained , no doubt , at a greater cost . [They]1017-the only spectators made on [me]0-i the impression , not of [many individuals]1026-many individuals , but of one vast centipede of [a man]1027-a man , good for all sorts of pulling down ; and why not then for some kinds of building up ? If [men]1028-men could combine thus earnestly , and patiently , and harmoniously to some really worthy end , what might [they]1028-men not accomplish ? [They]1028-men now put [their]1028-men hands , and partially perchance [their]1028-men heads , together , and the result is that [they]1028-men are the imperfect tools of an imperfect and tyrannical government . But if [they]1028-men could put [their]1028-men hands and heads and hearts and all together , such a co - operation and harmony would be the very end and success for which government now exists in [vain,—a government]1029-vain,—a government , as it were , not only with tools , but stock to trade with .

[I]0-i was obliged to frame some sentences that sounded like French in order to deal with [the market - women]1030-the market - women , who , for the most part , can not speak English . According to the guide - book the relative population of [this city]913-this city stands nearly thus : two fifths are [French Canadian]412-the indians ; nearly [one fifth British Canadian]1032-one fifth british canadian ; one and a half fifth English , Irish , and [Scotch]70-scotch ; somewhat less than [one half fifth Germans]1033-one half fifth germans , [United States]2-the united states people , and [others]985-others . [I]0-i saw nothing like pie for sale , and no good cake to put in [my]0-i bundle , such as [you]1035-you can easily find in [[our]1036-our towns]1037-our towns , but plenty of fair - looking apples , for which [Montreal Island]72-montreal island is celebrated , and also pears , cheaper , and [I]0-i thought better than [ours]1038-us , and peaches , which , though [they]1039-they were probably brought from [the South]1040-the south , were as cheap as [they]1039-they commonly are with [us]1038-us . So imperative is the law of demand and supply that , as [I]0-i have been told , the market of [Montreal]15-montreal is sometimes supplied with green apples from [the State of New York]73-the state of new york some weeks even before [they]1041-they are ripe in the latter place . [I]0-i saw here the spruce wax which [the Canadians]416-the french chew , done up in little silvered papers , a penny a roll ; also a small and shrivelled fruit which [they]416-the french called _ cerises _ mixed with many little stems somewhat like raisins , but [I]0-i soon returned what [I]0-i had bought , finding [them]416-the french rather insipid , only putting a sample in [my]0-i pocket . Since [my]0-i return , [I]0-i find on comparison that it is the fruit of the sweet viburnum ( _ Viburnum Lentago _ ) , which with [us]1038-us rarely holds on till it is ripe .

[I]0-i stood on the deck of [the steamer]1042-the steamer [John Munn]423-john munn , late in the afternoon , when the second and third [ferry - boats]1043-ferry - boats arrived from [La Prairie]56-la prairie , bringing the remainder of [the Yankees]418-yankees . [I]0-i never saw so many caleches , cabs , charettes , and [similar vehicles]1044-similar vehicles collected before , and doubt if [New York]45-new york could easily furnish more . The handsome and substantial stone quay , which stretches a mile along [the river - side]1045-the river - side , and protects [the street]5231-the street from the ice , was thronged with [the citizens who had turned out on foot and in carriages to welcome or to behold the Yankees]1047-the citizens who had turned out on foot and in carriages to welcome or to behold the yankees . It was interesting to see [the caleche drivers]1048-the caleche drivers dash up and down the slope of [the quay]911-the quay with [their]1048-the caleche drivers active little horses . [They]1048-the caleche drivers drive much faster than in [[our]1038-us cities]1050-our cities . [I]0-i have been told that [some of [them]1051-some of them]1051-some of them come nine miles into [the city]903-the city every morning and return every night , without changing [their]1051-some of them horses during the day . In the midst of [the crowd of [carts]1054-carts]1053-the crowd of carts , [I]0-i observed one deep one loaded with sheep with [their]1053-the crowd of carts legs tied together , and [their]1053-the crowd of carts bodies piled one upon another , as if [the driver]1055-the driver had forgotten that [they]1053-the crowd of carts were sheep and not yet mutton . A sight , [I]0-i trust , peculiar to [Canada]1-canada , though [I]0-i fear that it is not .

------------------------------------------------------------------------

CHAPTER II .

[QUEBEC AND MONTMORENCI]74-quebec and montmorenci .

About six o’clock [we]1038-us started for [Quebec]16-quebec , one hundred and eighty miles distant by [the river]905-the river ; gliding past [Longueil]75-longueil and [Boucherville]76-boucherville on the right , and [_ Pointe aux Trembles _]77-_ pointe aux trembles _ , “ so called from having been originally covered with aspens , ”[0-i] and _ Bout de l’Isle _ , or the end of [the island]914-the island , on the left . [I]0-i repeat these names not merely for want of more substantial facts to record , but because [they]1058-they sounded singularly poetic to [my]0-i ears . There certainly was no lie in [them]1058-they . [They]1058-they suggested that some simple , and , perchance , heroic human life might have transpired there . There is all the poetry in [the world]741-the world in a name . It is a poem which the mass of [men]1028-men hear and read . What is poetry in the common sense , but a string of such jingling names ? [I]0-i want nothing better than a good word . The name of a thing may easily be more than the thing itself to [me]0-i . Inexpressibly beautiful appears the recognition by [man of the least natural fact]1061-man of the least natural fact , and the allying [his]1061-man of the least natural fact life to it . All [the world]741-the world reiterating this slender truth , that aspens once grew there ; and the swift inference is , that [men]1028-men were there to see [them]1028-men . And so it would be with the names of [[our]1064-we native and [neighboring villages]1066-neighboring villages]1065-our native and neighboring villages , if [we]1064-we had not profaned [them]1065-our native and neighboring villages .

The daylight now failed [us]1064-we , and [we]1064-we went below ; but [I]0-i endeavored to console [myself]0-i for being obliged to make this voyage by night , by thinking that [I]0-i did not lose a great deal , [the shores]1067-the shores being low and rather unattractive , and that [the river]905-the river itself was much the more interesting object . [I]0-i heard something in the night about [the boat]942-the boat being at [William Henry]424-william henry , [Three Rivers]1070-three rivers , and in [the Richelieu Rapids]78-the richelieu rapids , but [I]0-i was still where [I]0-i had been when [I]0-i lost sight of [_ Pointe aux]79-_ pointe aux Trembles _ . To hear [a man who has been waked up at midnight in [the cabin of [a steamboat]822-a steamboat]1072-the cabin of a steamboat]1071-a man who has been waked up at midnight in the cabin of a steamboat , inquiring , “ [Waiter]5243-waiter , where are [we]1076-we now ? ”[1071-a man who has been waked up at midnight in the cabin of a steamboat] is , as if at any moment of [the earth]1074-the earth ’s revolution round the sun , or of the system round [its]905-the river centre , [one]936-one were to raise [himself]1071-a man who has been waked up at midnight in the cabin of a steamboat up and inquire of one of the deck hands , “ Where are [we]1076-we now ? ”[936-one]

[I]0-i went on deck at daybreak , when [we]1076-we were thirty or forty miles above [Quebec]16-quebec . [The banks]1077-the banks were now higher and more interesting . There was an “ uninterrupted succession of [whitewashed cottages ”]5244-whitewashed cottages ”[0-i] on [each side of [the river]905-the river]1078-each side of the river . This is what [every traveller]1080-every traveller tells . But it is not to be taken as an evidence of the populousness of [the country]750-the country in general , hardly even of [the river banks]1082-the river banks . [They]1083-they have presented a similar appearance for a hundred years . [The Swedish traveller]1084-the swedish traveller and naturalist , [Kalm]425-kalm , who descended [this river]1085-this river in 1749 , says : “ It could really be called [a village]5245-a village , beginning at [Montreal]15-montreal and ending at [Quebec]16-quebec , which is a distance of more than one hundred and eighty miles ; for [the farm - houses]5246-the farm - houses are never above five arpens , and sometimes but three asunder , a few places excepted . ”[425-kalm] Even in 1684 [Hontan]426-hontan said that [the houses]1086-the houses were not more than a gunshot apart at most . [Erelong]427-erelong [we]1076-we passed [Cape Rouge]80-cape rouge , [eight miles above [Quebec]16-quebec]1087-eight miles above quebec , the mouth of [the Chaudière on the opposite or south side]1088-the chaudière on the opposite or south side , [New Liverpool Cove]81-new liverpool cove with [its]81-new liverpool cove lumber rafts and some shipping ; then [Sillery]428-sillery and [Wolfe ’s Cove]82-wolfe ’s cove and [the Heights of [Abraham]84-abraham]83-the heights of abraham on the north , with now a view of [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond , and [the citadel in front]1089-the citadel in front . The approach to [Quebec]16-quebec was very imposing . It was about six o’clock in the morning when [we]1076-we arrived . There is but [a single street under [the cliff on the south side of the cape]1091-the cliff on the south side of the cape , which was made by blasting the rocks and filling up [the river]905-the river]1090-a single street under the cliff on the south side of the cape , which was made by blasting the rocks and filling up the river . [Three - story houses]1093-three - story houses did not rise more than one fifth or one sixth the way up [the nearly perpendicular rock , whose summit is three hundred and forty - five feet above the water]1094-the nearly perpendicular rock , whose summit is three hundred and forty - five feet above the water . [We]1076-we saw , as [we]1076-we glided past , the sign on the side of the precipice , part way up , pointing to [the spot where [Montgomery]429-montgomery was killed in 1775]1095-the spot where montgomery was killed in 1775 . Formerly it was the custom for those who went to [Quebec]16-quebec for the first time to be ducked , or else pay a fine . Not even [the Governor General]1096-the governor general escaped . But [we]1076-we were too many to be ducked , even if the custom had not been abolished.[1 ]

Footnote 1 :

[Hierosme Lalemant]430-hierosme lalemant says in 1648 , in [his]430-hierosme lalemant relation , [he]430-hierosme lalemant being [Superior]1097-superior : “ All those who come to [New France]86-new france know well enough [the mountain of [Notre Dame]61-notre dame]5247-the mountain of notre dame , because the pilots and [sailors]5248-sailors , being , arrived at [that part of [the Great River which is opposite to those high mountains]5250-the great river which is opposite to those high mountains]5249-that part of the great river which is opposite to those high mountains , baptize ordinarily for sport [the new passengers]5251-the new passengers , if [they]5251-the new passengers do not turn aside by some present the inundation of this baptism which one makes flow plentifully on [their]5251-the new passengers heads . ”[430-hierosme lalemant]

[Here]820-here [we]1076-we were , in [the harbor of [Quebec]16-quebec]1099-the harbor of quebec , still three hundred and sixty miles from [the mouth of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1100-the mouth of the st. lawrence , in a basin two miles across , where the greatest depth is twenty - eight fathoms , and though the water is fresh , the tide rises seventeen to twenty - four feet,—a harbor “ large and deep enough , ”[1101-a british traveller] says [a British traveller]1101-a british traveller , “ to hold [the English navy]5252-the english navy . ”[1101-a british traveller] [I]0-i may as well state that , in 1844 , [the county of Quebec]1102-the county of quebec contained about [forty - five thousand inhabitants]1103-forty - five thousand inhabitants ( [the city and suburbs]1104-the city and suburbs having about forty - three thousand ) ; about twenty - eight thousand being [Canadians of French origin]1105-canadians of french origin ; [eight thousand British]1106-eight thousand british ; over [seven thousand natives of [Ireland]87-ireland]1107-seven thousand natives of ireland ; [one thousand five hundred natives of [England]31-england]1108-one thousand five hundred natives of england ; [the rest Scotch and others]1109-the rest scotch and others . Thirty - six thousand belong to [the Church of [Rome]88-rome]1110-the church of rome .

Separating [ourselves]1076-we from [the crowd]1111-the crowd , [we]1076-we walked up [a narrow street]1112-a narrow street , thence ascended by some wooden steps , called [the Break - neck Stairs]1113-the break - neck stairs , into [another steep , narrow , and zigzag street]1114-another steep , narrow , and zigzag street , blasted through the rock , which last led through a low massive stone portal , called [Prescott Gate]89-prescott gate , [the principal thoroughfare into [the Upper Town]1116-the upper town]1115-the principal thoroughfare into the upper town . [This passage]1117-this passage was defended by cannon , with [a guard - house]1118-a guard - house over [it]1117-this passage , [a sentinel at [his]1119-a sentinel at his post post]1119-a sentinel at his post , and [other soldiers]1120-other soldiers at hand ready to relieve [him]1119-a sentinel at his post . [I]0-i rubbed [my]0-i eyes to be sure that [I]0-i was in the nineteenth century , and was not entering one of those portals which sometimes adorn the frontispieces of new editions of old black - letter volumes . [I]0-i thought it would be a good place to read [Froissart]431-froissart ’s Chronicles . It was such a reminiscence of the Middle Ages as [Scott]432-scott ’s novels . [Men]1028-men apparently dwelt there for security . Peace be unto [them]1028-men ! As if [the inhabitants of [New York]45-new york]1122-the inhabitants of new york were to go over to [Castle William]90-castle william to live ! What a place it must be to bring up [children]1123-children ! Being safe through the gate [we]1124-we naturally took [the street]5231-the street which was steepest , and after a few turns found [ourselves]1124-we on [the Durham Terrace]91-the durham terrace , [a wooden platform on the site of [the old castle of [St. Louis]92-st. louis]1127-the old castle of st. louis]1126-a wooden platform on the site of the old castle of st. louis , still one hundred and fifteen feet below the summit of [the citadel]1128-the citadel , overlooking [the Lower Town]1129-the lower town , [the wharf where [we]1124-we had landed]1130-the wharf where we had landed , [the harbor]1131-the harbor , [the Isle of Orleans]93-the isle of orleans , and [the river and surrounding country]1132-the river and surrounding country to a great distance . [It]1126-a wooden platform on the site of the old castle of st. louis was literally a _ splendid _ view . [We]1124-we could see six or seven miles distant , in the northeast , an indentation in [the lofty shore of [the northern channel]1134-the northern channel]1133-the lofty shore of the northern channel , apparently on one side of [the harbor , which marked the mouth of the Montmorenci]1135-the harbor , which marked the mouth of the montmorenci , whose celebrated fall was only a few rods in the rear .

At [a shoe - shop]1136-a shoe - shop , whither [we]1124-we were directed for this purpose , [we]1124-we got some of [our]1124-we American money changed into English . [I]0-i found that American hard money would have answered as well , excepting cents , which fell very fast before [their]1137-their pennies , it taking two of [the former]906-the former to make one of the latter , and often the penny , which had cost [us]1124-we two cents , did [us]1124-we the service of one cent only . Moreover , [[our]1124-we robust cents]1139-our robust cents were compelled to meet on even terms [a crew of vile half - penny tokens]1140-a crew of vile half - penny tokens , and bung - town coppers , which had more brass in [their]1140-a crew of vile half - penny tokens composition , and so perchance made [their]1140-a crew of vile half - penny tokens way in [the world]741-the world . Wishing to get into [the citadel]1128-the citadel , [we]1124-we were directed to [the Jesuits ’ Barracks,—a]1143-the jesuits ’ barracks,—a good part of [the public buildings]1144-the public buildings [here]820-here are barracks,—to get a pass of [the Town Major]1146-the town major . [We]1124-we did not heed [the sentries]1147-the sentries at the gate , nor did [they]1147-the sentries [us]1124-we , and what under the sun [they]1147-the sentries were placed there for , unless to hinder a free circulation of the air , was not apparent . There [we]1124-we saw [soldiers]1016-soldiers eating [their]1016-soldiers breakfasts in [[their]1016-soldiers mess - room]1149-their mess - room , from bare wooden tables in camp fashion . [We]1124-we were continually meeting with [soldiers]1016-soldiers in [the streets]995-the streets , carrying funny little tin pails of all shapes , even semicircular , as if made to pack conveniently . [I]0-i supposed that [they]1016-soldiers contained [their]1016-soldiers dinners,—so many slices of bread and butter to each , perchance . Sometimes [they]1016-soldiers were carrying some kind of military chest on a sort of bier or hand - barrow , with a springy , undulating , military step , all passengers giving way to [them]1016-soldiers , even the charette - drivers stopping for [them]1016-soldiers to pass,—as if the battle were being lost from an inadequate supply of powder . There was [a regiment of Highlanders]1152-a regiment of highlanders , and , as [I]0-i understood , of [Royal Irish]1153-royal irish , in [the city]903-the city ; and by this time there was [a regiment of [Yankees]418-yankees]1155-a regiment of yankees also . [I]0-i had already observed , looking up even from the water , the head and shoulders of some [General Poniatowsky]433-general poniatowsky , with an enormous cocked hat and gun , peering over the roof of [a house]1156-a house , away up where the chimney caps commonly are with [us]1124-we , as it were a caricature of war and military awfulness ; but [I]0-i had not gone far up [St. Louis Street]95-st. louis street before [my]0-i riddle was solved , by the apparition of a real live Highlander under a cocked hat , and with [his]433-general poniatowsky knees out , standing and marching sentinel on [the ramparts]1157-the ramparts , between [St. Louis]92-st. louis and [St. John ’s Gate]96-st. john ’s gate . ( It must be a holy war that is waged there . ) [We]1124-we stood close by without fear and looked at [him]433-general poniatowsky . [His]433-general poniatowsky legs were somewhat tanned , and the hair had begun to grow on [them]1158-them , as [some of [[our]1124-we wise men]1160-our wise men]1159-some of our wise men predict that it will in such cases , but [I]0-i did not think [they]1159-some of our wise men were remarkable in any respect . Notwithstanding all [his]433-general poniatowsky warlike gear , when [I]0-i inquired of [him]433-general poniatowsky the way to [the Plains of Abraham]1161-the plains of abraham , [he]433-general poniatowsky could not answer [me]0-i without betraying some bashfulness through [his]433-general poniatowsky broad Scotch . Soon after , [we]1124-we passed another of [these creatures standing sentry at [the St. Louis Gate]97-the st. louis gate , who let [us]1124-we go by without shooting [us]1124-we]1162-these creatures standing sentry at the st. louis gate , who let us go by without shooting us , or even demanding the countersign . [We]1124-we then began to go through the gate , which was so thick and tunnel - like , as to remind [me]0-i of those lines in [[Claudian]434-claudian ’s Old Man of [Verona]98-verona]1163-claudian ’s old man of verona , about the getting out of the gate being the greater part of a journey;—as [you]1164-you might imagine [yourself]1164-you crawling through an architectural vignette _ at the end _ of a black - letter volume . [We]1124-we were then reminded that [we]1124-we had been in [a fortress]1165-a fortress , from which [we]1124-we emerged by numerous zig - zags in [a ditch - like road]1166-a ditch - like road , going a considerable distance to advance a few rods , where [they]1167-their could have shot [us]1124-we two or three times over , if [their]1167-their minds had been disposed as [their]1167-their guns were . The greatest , or rather the most prominent , part of [this city]913-this city was constructed with the design to offer the deadest resistance to leaden and iron missiles that might be cast against it . But it is a remarkable meteorological and psychological fact , that it is rarely known to rain lead with much violence , except on places so constructed . Keeping on about a mile [we]1124-we came to [the Plains of [Abraham,—for]100-abraham,—for]99-the plains of abraham,—for having got through with [the Saints]1169-the saints , [we]1124-we come next to [the Patriarchs]1170-the patriarchs . Here [the Highland regiment]1171-the highland regiment was being reviewed , while [the band]1172-the band stood on one side and played,—methinks it was _ La Claire Fontaine _ , the national air of [the Canadian French]1173-the canadian french . This is [the site where a real battle once took place , to commemorate which [they]1172-the band have had a sham fight here almost every day since]1174-the site where a real battle once took place , to commemorate which they have had a sham fight here almost every day since . [The Highlanders]1175-the highlanders manœuvred very well , and if the precision of [their]1172-the band movements was less remarkable , [they]1172-the band did not appear so stiffly erect as the English or [Royal Irish]435-royal irish , but had a more elastic and graceful gait , like a herd of [their]1172-the band own red deer , or as if accustomed to stepping down [the sides of [mountains]1177-mountains]1176-the sides of mountains . But [they]1172-the band made a sad impression on the whole , for it was obvious that [all true manhood]1178-all true manhood was in the process of being drilled out of [them]1172-the band . [I]0-i have no doubt that [soldiers well drilled]1179-soldiers well drilled are , as a class , peculiarly destitute of originality and independence . [The officers]877-the officers appeared like [men]1028-men dressed above [their]877-the officers condition . It is impossible to give [the soldier]1002-the soldier a good education , without making [him]1002-the soldier [a deserter]1183-a deserter . [[His]1002-the soldier natural foe]1184-his natural foe is the government that drills [him]1002-the soldier . What would [any philanthropist]1185-any philanthropist , who felt an interest in [these men]1186-these men ’s welfare , naturally do , but first of all teach [them]1186-these men so to respect [themselves]1186-these men , that [they]1186-these men could not be hired for this work , whatever might be the consequences to [this government]1187-this government or that;—not drill a few , but educate all . [I]0-i observed [one older man among [them]1186-these men]1188-one older man among them , gray as a wharf - rat , and supple as [the Devil]436-the devil , marching lock - step with [the rest who would have to pay for that elastic gait]1189-the rest who would have to pay for that elastic gait .

[We]1190-we returned to the citadel along the heights , plucking such flowers as grew there . There was an abundance of succory still in blossom , broad - leaved golden - rod , buttercups , thorn bushes , [Canada]1-canada thistles , and ivy , on [the very summit of [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond]1191-the very summit of cape diamond . [I]0-i also found [the bladder - campion in [the neighborhood]1193-the neighborhood]1192-the bladder - campion in the neighborhood . [We]1190-we there enjoyed an extensive view , which [I]0-i will describe in another place . [Our]1190-we pass , which stated that all the rules were “ to be strictly enforced , ”[1190-we] as if [they]1186-these men were determined to keep up the semblance of reality to the last gasp , opened to [us]1190-we [the Dalhousie Gate]1194-the dalhousie gate , and [we]1190-we were conducted over [the citadel]1128-the citadel by [a bare - legged Highlander in cocked hat and full regimentals]1196-a bare - legged highlander in cocked hat and full regimentals . [He]1188-one older man among them told [us]1190-we that [he]1188-one older man among them had been here about three years , and had formerly been stationed at [Gibraltar]101-gibraltar . As if [[his]1188-one older man among them regiment]1197-his regiment , having perchance been nestled amid [the rocks of [Edinburgh Castle]102-edinburgh castle]1198-the rocks of edinburgh castle , must flit from rock to rock thenceforth over [the earth]1074-the earth ’s surface , like a bald eagle , or other bird of prey , from eyrie to eyrie . As [we]1190-we were going out , [we]1190-we met [the Yankees]418-yankees coming in , in a body , headed by [a red - coated officer called [the commandant]1201-the commandant]1200-a red - coated officer called the commandant , and escorted by [many citizens]1202-many citizens , [both English and French Canadian]1203-both english and french canadian . [I]0-i therefore immediately fell into the procession , and went round the citadel again with more intelligent guides , carrying , as before , all [my]0-i effects with [me]0-i . Seeing that [nobody]892-nobody walked with [the red - coated commandant]1205-the red - coated commandant , [I]0-i attached [myself]0-i to [him]1205-the red - coated commandant , and though [I]0-i was not what is called well - dressed , [he]1205-the red - coated commandant did not know whether to repel [me]0-i or not , for [I]0-i talked like [one who was not aware of any deficiency in that respect]1206-one who was not aware of any deficiency in that respect . Probably there was not one among [all the Yankees who went to [Canada]1-canada this time , who was not more splendidly dressed than [I]0-i was]1207-all the yankees who went to canada this time , who was not more splendidly dressed than i was . It would have been a poor story if [I]0-i had not enjoyed some distinction . [I]0-i had on [my]0-i “ bad - weather clothes , ”[0-i] like [Olaf Trygesson the Northman]437-olaf trygesson the northman , when [he]437-olaf trygesson the northman went to the Thing in [England]31-england , where , by the way , [he]437-olaf trygesson the northman won [[his]437-olaf trygesson the northman bride]1208-his bride . As [we]1209-we stood by the thirty - two - pounder on [the summit of [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond]1210-the summit of cape diamond , which is fired three times a day , [the commandant]1201-the commandant told [me]0-i that [it]85-cape diamond would carry to the [Isle of Orleans]93-the isle of orleans , four miles distant , and that [no hostile vessel]1212-no hostile vessel could come round [the island]914-the island . [I]0-i now saw [the subterranean or , rather , “ casemated barracks ”[874-the soldiers] of [the soldiers]874-the soldiers , which [I]0-i had not noticed before , though [I]0-i might have walked over [them]874-the soldiers]1214-the subterranean or , rather , “ casemated barracks ” of the soldiers , which i had not noticed before , though i might have walked over them . [They]874-the soldiers had very narrow windows , serving as loop - holes for musketry , and small iron chimneys rising above the ground . There [we]1209-we saw [the soldiers]874-the soldiers at [home]867-home and in an undress , splitting wood,—I looked to see whether with swords or axes,—and in various ways endeavoring to realize that [their]874-the soldiers nation was now at peace with [this part of [the world]741-the world]1218-this part of the world . [A part of [each regiment]1221-each regiment]1220-a part of each regiment , [chiefly officers]1222-chiefly officers , are allowed to marry . A grandfatherly , would - be [witty Englishman]438-witty englishman could give [a Yankee whom [he]438-witty englishman was patronizing no reason for the bare knees of [the Highlanders]1175-the highlanders]1223-a yankee whom he was patronizing no reason for the bare knees of the highlanders , other than oddity . The rock within [the citadel]1128-the citadel is a little convex , so that shells falling on it would roll toward the circumference , where [the barracks of [the soldiers]874-the soldiers and [officers]1228-officers are]1226-the barracks of the soldiers and officers are ; it has been proposed , therefore , to make it slightly concave , so that [they]1226-the barracks of the soldiers and officers are may roll into the centre , where [they]1226-the barracks of the soldiers and officers are would be comparatively harmless ; and it is estimated that to do this would cost twenty thousand pounds sterling . It may be well to remember this when [I]0-i build [[my]0-i next house]1229-my next house , and have the roof “ all correct ”[0-i] for bombshells .

At mid - afternoon [we]1230-we made haste down _ [Sault - au]104-sault - au - [Matelot _ street]105-matelot _ street , towards [the Falls of [Montmorenci]106-montmorenci]1231-the falls of montmorenci , about eight miles down the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence , on the north side , leaving the further examination of [Quebec]16-quebec till [our]1230-we return . On [our]1230-we way , [we]1230-we saw [men]1028-men in [the streets]995-the streets sawing logs pit - fashion , and afterward , with a common wood - saw and horse , cutting the planks into squares for paving [the streets]995-the streets . This looked very shiftless , especially in [a country]1235-a country abounding in water - power , and reminded [me]0-i that [I]0-i was no longer in [Yankee land]1236-yankee land . [I]0-i found , on inquiry , that the excuse for this was , that labor was so cheap ; and [I]0-i thought , with some pain , how [cheap men]1237-cheap men are here ! [I]0-i have since learned that [the English traveller]1238-the english traveller , [Warburton]439-warburton , remarked , soon after landing at [Quebec]16-quebec , that everything was cheap there but [men]1028-men . That must be the difference between going thither from [New]107-new and from [Old England]108-old england . [I]0-i had already observed the dogs harnessed to [their]1028-men little milk - carts , which contain a single large can , lying asleep in the gutters regardless of the horses , while [they]1028-men rested from [their]1028-men labors , at different stages of the ascent in [the Upper Town]1116-the upper town . [I]0-i was surprised at the regular and extensive use made of these animals for drawing , not only milk , but groceries , wood , & c. It reminded [me]0-i that the dog commonly is not put to any use . Cats catch mice ; but dogs only worry the cats . [Kalm]425-kalm , a hundred years ago , saw sledges here for [ladies]837-ladies to ride in , drawn by a pair of dogs . [He]425-kalm says , “ A middle - sized dog is sufficient to draw [a single person]5253-a single person , when [the roads]5254-the roads are good ”[425-kalm] ; and [he]425-kalm was told by [old people]1242-old people , that horses were very scarce in [their]1242-old people youth , and almost all [the land - carriage]1243-the land - carriage was then effected by dogs . [They]1242-old people made [me]0-i think of [the Esquimaux , who , in fact , are [the next people on the north]1245-the next people on the north]1244-the esquimaux , who , in fact , are the next people on the north . [Charlevoix]440-charlevoix says , that the first horses were introduced in 1665 .

[We]1246-we crossed [Dorchester Bridge]109-dorchester bridge , over the [St. Charles]110-st. charles , [the little river in which [Cartier]410-cartier]1247-the little river in which cartier , [the discoverer of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1248-the discoverer of the st. lawrence , put [[his]1248-the discoverer of the st. lawrence ships]1249-his ships , and spent the winter of 1535 , and found [ourselves]1246-we on [an excellent macadamized road]1250-an excellent macadamized road , called _ [Le Chemin de Beauport]113-le chemin de beauport _ . [We]1246-we had left [Concord]24-concord Wednesday morning , and [we]1246-we endeavored to realize that now , Friday morning , [we]1246-we were taking a walk in [Canada]1-canada , in [the Seigniory of [Beauport]115-beauport]114-the seigniory of beauport , [a foreign country]850-a foreign country , which a few days before had seemed almost as far off as [England]31-england and [France]116-france . Instead of rambling to [Flint ’s Pond]117-flint ’s pond or the [Sudbury Meadows]118-sudbury meadows , [we]1246-we found [ourselves]1246-we , after being a little detained in [cars]1252-cars and steamboats,—after spending half a night at [Burlington]43-burlington , and half a day at [Montreal,—taking]119-montreal,—taking a walk down the bank of the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence to [the Falls of Montmorenci]120-the falls of montmorenci and elsewhere . Well , [I]0-i thought to [myself]0-i , here [I]0-i am in [a foreign country]850-a foreign country ; let [me]0-i have [my]0-i eyes about [me]0-i , and take it all in . It already looked and felt a good deal colder than it had in [New England]20-new england , as [we]1246-we might have expected it would . [I]0-i realized fully that [I]0-i was four degrees nearer the pole , and shuddered at the thought ; and [I]0-i wondered if it were possible that the peaches might not be all gone when [I]0-i returned . It was an atmosphere that made [me]0-i think of the fur - trade , which is so interesting [a department in [Canada]1-canada]1254-a department in canada , for [I]0-i had for all head - covering a thin palm - leaf hat without lining , that cost twenty - five cents , and over [my]0-i coat one of those unspeakably cheap , as well as thin , brown linen sacks of the Oak Hall pattern , which every summer appear all over [New England]20-new england , thick as the leaves upon the trees . It was a thoroughly Yankee costume , which some of [[my]0-i fellow - travellers]748-my fellow - travellers wore in [the cars]789-the cars to save [their]789-the cars coats a dusting . [I]0-i wore [mine]0-i , at first , because it looked better than the coat it covered , and last , because two coats were warmer than one , though [one]936-one was thin and dirty . [I]0-i never wear [my]0-i best coat on a journey , though perchance [I]0-i could show a certificate to prove that [I]0-i have a more costly one , at least , at [home]867-home , if that were all that [a gentleman]1259-a gentleman required . It is not wise for [a traveller]1260-a traveller to go dressed . [I]0-i should no more think of it than of putting on a clean dicky and blacking [my]0-i shoes to go a - fishing ; as if [you]1261-you were going out to dine , when , in fact , [the genuine traveller]1262-the genuine traveller is going out to work hard , and fare harder,—to eat a crust by the wayside whenever [he]1262-the genuine traveller can get it . [Honest travelling]1263-honest travelling is about as dirty work as [you]1264-you can do , and [a man]1027-a man needs a pair of overalls for it . As for blacking [my]0-i shoes in such a case , [I]0-i should as soon think of blacking [my]0-i face . [I]0-i carry a piece of tallow to preserve the leather , and keep out the water ; that ’s all ; and many an officious shoe - black , who carried off [my]0-i shoes when [I]0-i was slumbering , mistaking [me]0-i for [a gentleman]1259-a gentleman , has had occasion to repent it before [he]1259-a gentleman produced a gloss on them .

[My]0-i pack , in fact , was soon made , for [I]0-i keep a short list of those articles which , from frequent experience , [I]0-i have found indispensable to [the foot - traveller]1267-the foot - traveller ; and , when [I]0-i am about to start , [I]0-i have only to consult that , to be sure that nothing is omitted , and , what is more important , nothing superfluous inserted . [Most of [[my]0-i fellow - travellers]748-my fellow - travellers]1268-most of my fellow - travellers carried carpet - bags , or valises . Sometimes [one]936-one had two or three ponderous yellow valises in [his]936-one clutch , at each hitch of [the cars]789-the cars , as if [we]1272-we were going to have another rush for seats ; and when there was a rush in earnest , and there were not a few , [I]0-i would see [[my]0-i man]1273-my man in the crowd , with two or [three affectionate lusty fellows along each side of [his]1273-my man arm]1274-three affectionate lusty fellows along each side of his arm , between [his]1273-my man shoulder and [his]1273-my man valises , which last held [them]1274-three affectionate lusty fellows along each side of his arm tight to [his]1273-my man back , like the nut on the end of a screw . [I]0-i could not help asking in [my]0-i mind , What so great cause for showing [Canada]1-canada to those valises , when perhaps [[your]1275-your very nieces]1276-your very nieces had to stay at [home]867-home for want of [an escort]1278-an escort ? [I]0-i should have liked to be present when [the custom - house officer]1279-the custom - house officer came aboard of [him]1279-the custom - house officer , and asked [him]1279-the custom - house officer to declare upon [his]1279-the custom - house officer honor if [he]1279-the custom - house officer had anything but wearing apparel in [them]1274-three affectionate lusty fellows along each side of his arm . Even the elephant carries but a small trunk on [his]1279-the custom - house officer journeys . The perfection of travelling is to travel without baggage . After considerable reflection and experience , [I]0-i have concluded that the best bag for [the foot - traveller]1267-the foot - traveller is made with a handkerchief , or , if [he]1279-the custom - house officer study appearances , a piece of stiff brown paper , well tied up , with a fresh piece within to put outside when the first is torn . That is good for both [town and country]1281-town and country , and [none]1282-none will know but [you]1283-you are carrying [home]867-home the silk for a new gown for [[your]1283-you wife]1285-your wife , when it may be a dirty shirt . A bundle which [you]1283-you can carry literally under [your]1283-you arm , and which will shrink and swell with its contents . [I]0-i never found the carpet - bag of equal capacity , which was not a bundle of itself . [We]1286-we styled [ourselves]1286-we the Knights of the Umbrella and [the Bundle]1287-the bundle ; for wherever [we]1286-we went , whether to [Notre Dame]61-notre dame or [Mount Royal]57-mount royal , or the [Champ de Mars]66-champ de mars , to [the Town Major]1146-the town major ’s or [the Bishop ’s Palace]1289-the bishop ’s palace , to [the Citadel]1128-the citadel , with a bare - legged Highlander for [[our]1286-we escort]1291-our escort , or to [the Plains of [Abraham]84-abraham]1161-the plains of abraham , to dinner or to bed , the umbrella and the bundle went with [us]1286-we ; for [we]1286-we wished to be ready to digress at any moment . [We]1286-we made it [[our]1286-we home]1293-our home nowhere in particular , but everywhere where [our]1286-we umbrella and bundle were . It would have been an amusing circumstance , if [the Mayor of [one of [those cities]1296-those cities]1295-one of those cities]1294-the mayor of one of those cities had politely asked [us]1286-we where [we]1286-we were staying . [We]1286-we could only have answered , that [we]1286-we were staying with [his]1294-the mayor of one of those cities Honor for the time being . [I]0-i was amused when , after [our]1286-we return , [some green ones]1297-some green ones inquired if [we]1286-we found it easy to get accommodated ; as if [we]1286-we went abroad to get accommodated , when [we]1286-we can get that at [home]867-home .

[We]1286-we met with many charettes , bringing wood and stone to [the city]903-the city . The most ordinary looking horses travelled faster than [ours]1286-we , or , perhaps [they]1297-some green ones were ordinary looking , because , as [I]0-i am told , [the Canadians]1300-the canadians do not use the curry - comb .
