Moreover , it is said , that on the approach of winter [their]1300-the canadians horses acquire an increased quantity of hair , to protect [them]1300-the canadians from the cold . If this be true , some of [our]1286-we horses would make [you]1301-you think winter were approaching , even in midsummer . [We]1286-we soon began to see [women]1302-women and [girls]1303-girls at work in [the fields]1304-the fields , digging potatoes alone , or bundling up the grain which [the men]1305-the men cut . [They]1305-the men appeared in rude health , with a great deal of color in [their]1305-the men cheeks , and , if [their]1305-the men occupation had made them coarse , it impressed [me]0-i as better in its effects than making shirts at fourpence apiece , or doing nothing at all ; unless it be chewing slate pencils , with still smaller results . [They]1305-the men were much more agreeable objects , with [their]1305-the men great broad - brimmed hats and flowing dresses , than [the men]1305-the men and [boys]1307-boys . [We]1286-we afterwards saw [them]1305-the men doing various other kinds of work ; indeed , [I]0-i thought that [we]1286-we saw [more women]1308-more women at work out of doors than [men]1028-men . On [our]1286-we return , [we]1286-we observed in [this town]758-this town a girl with Indian boots , nearly two feet high , taking the harness off a dog . The purity and transparency of the atmosphere were wonderful . When [we]1286-we had been walking an hour , [we]1286-we were surprised , on turning round , to see how near [the city]903-the city , with [its]903-the city glittering tin roofs , still looked . [A village]5245-a village ten miles off did not appear to be more than three or four . [I]0-i was convinced that [you]1313-you could see objects distinctly there much farther than here . It is true [the villages]1314-the villages are of a dazzling white , but the dazzle is to be referred , perhaps , to the transparency of the atmosphere as much as to the whitewash .

[We]1286-we were now fairly in [the village of Beauport]1315-the village of beauport , though there was still but [one road]1316-one road . [The houses]1086-the houses stood close upon this , without any front - yards , and at any angle with it , as if [they]1086-the houses had dropped down , being set with more reference to the road which the sun travels . It being about sundown , and [the Falls]1318-the falls not far off , [we]1286-we began to look round for [a lodging]1319-a lodging , for [we]1286-we preferred to put up at [a private house]1320-a private house , that [we]1286-we might see more of [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants . [We]1286-we inquired first at [the most promising looking houses]1322-the most promising looking houses , if , indeed , any were promising . When [we]1286-we knocked , [they]1286-we shouted some French word for come in , perhaps _ entrez _ , and [we]1286-we asked for a lodging in English ; but [we]1286-we found , unexpectedly , that [they]1286-we spoke French only . Then [we]1286-we went along and tried [another house]1323-another house , being generally saluted by a rush of two or three little curs , which readily distinguished [a foreigner]1324-a foreigner , and which [we]1286-we were prepared now to hear bark in French . [Our]1286-we first question would be , _ [Parlez - vous Anglais]442-parlez - vous anglais ? _ but the invariable answer was , _ Non , monsieur _ ; and [we]1286-we soon found that [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants were exclusively [French Canadians]1326-french canadians , and [nobody]892-nobody spoke English at all , any more than in [France]116-france ; that , in fact , [we]1286-we were in [a foreign country]850-a foreign country , where [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants uttered not one familiar sound to [us]1286-we . Then [we]1286-we tried by turns to talk [French]416-the french with [them]1006-the inhabitants , in which [we]1286-we succeeded sometimes pretty well , but for the most part , pretty ill . _ Pouvez - vous nous donner un lit cette nuit ? _ [we]1286-we would ask , and then [they]1006-the inhabitants would answer with French volubility , so that [we]1286-we could catch only a word here and there . [We]1286-we could understand [the women]1330-the women and [children]1123-children generally better than [the men]1305-the men , and [they]1305-the men [us]1286-we ; and thus , after a while , [we]1286-we would learn that [they]1305-the men had no more beds than [they]1305-the men used .

So [we]1286-we were compelled to inquire : _ Y a - t - il une maison publique ici ? _ ( _ auberge _ [we]1286-we should have said , perhaps , for [they]1305-the men seemed never to have heard of the other ) , and [they]1305-the men answered at length that there was [no tavern]1333-no tavern , unless [we]1286-we could get lodgings at [the mill]1334-the mill , _ le moulin _ , which [we]1286-we had passed ; or [they]1305-the men would direct [us]1286-we to [a grocery]1335-a grocery , and almost [every house]970-every house had a small grocery at one end of [it]970-every house . [We]1286-we called on the public notary or [village lawyer]1337-village lawyer , but [he]1337-village lawyer had no more beds nor English than [the rest]1338-the rest . At [one house]1339-one house there was so good a misunderstanding at once established through the politeness of all parties , that [we]1286-we were encouraged to walk in and sit down , and ask for a glass of water ; and having drank [their]1305-the men water , [we]1286-we thought it was as good as to have tasted [their]1305-the men salt . When [[our]1286-we host]1340-our host and [[his]1340-our host wife]1341-his wife spoke of [their]1305-the men poor accommodations , meaning for [themselves]1305-the men , [we]1286-we assured [them]1305-the men that [they]1305-the men were good enough , for [we]1286-we thought that [they]1305-the men were only apologizing for the poorness of the accommodations [they]1305-the men were about to offer [us]1286-we , and [we]1286-we did not discover [our]1286-we mistake till [they]1305-the men took [us]1286-we up a ladder into [a loft]1342-a loft , and showed to [our]1286-we eyes what [they]1305-the men had been laboring in vain to communicate to [our]1286-we brains through [our]1286-we ears , that [they]1305-the men had but that [one apartment with [its]1305-the men few beds for [the whole family]1344-the whole family]1343-one apartment with its few beds for the whole family . [We]1286-we made [our]1286-we _ a - dieus _ forthwith , and with gravity , perceiving the literal signification of that word . [We]1286-we were finally taken in at [a sort of public - house , whose master worked for [Patterson]443-patterson]1345-a sort of public - house , whose master worked for patterson , [the proprietor of [the extensive saw - mills driven by a portion of the Montmorenci stolen from the fall , whose roar [we]1286-we now heard]1347-the extensive saw - mills driven by a portion of the montmorenci stolen from the fall , whose roar we now heard . [We]1286-we here talked , or murdered [French]416-the french all the evening , with [the master of [the house]1349-the house]1348-the master of the house and [[his]1348-the master of the house family]1350-his family]1346-the proprietor of the extensive saw - mills driven by a portion of the montmorenci stolen from the fall , whose roar we now heard . we here talked , or murdered french all the evening , with the master of the house and his family , and probably had a more amusing time than if [we]1286-we had completely understood one another . At length [they]1350-his family showed [us]1286-we to a bed in [[their]1350-his family best chamber]1351-their best chamber , very high to get into , with a low wooden rail to [it]1349-the house . It had no cotton sheets , but coarse , home - made , dark colored , linen ones . Afterward , [we]1286-we had to do with sheets still coarser than these , and nearly the color of [our]1286-we blankets . There was a large open buffet loaded with crockery , in one corner of [the room]1352-the room , as if to display [their]1350-his family wealth to [travellers]1353-travellers , and pictures of Scripture scenes , French , Italian , and Spanish , hung around . [[Our]1286-we hostess]1354-our hostess came back directly to inquire if [we]1286-we would have brandy for breakfast . The next morning , when [I]0-i asked [their]1354-our hostess names , [she]1354-our hostess took down the temperance pledges of [herself]1354-our hostess and [husband]1355-husband , and [children]1123-children , which were hanging against the wall . [They]1354-our hostess were [Jean Baptiste Binet]444-jean baptiste binet , and [[his]444-jean baptiste binet wife]1341-his wife , [Geneviève Binet]445-geneviève binet . [Jean Baptiste]444-jean baptiste binet is the sobriquet of [the French Canadians]1358-the french canadians .

After breakfast [we]1286-we proceeded to the fall , which was within half a mile , and at this distance its rustling sound , like the wind among the leaves , filled all the air . [We]1286-we were disappointed to find that [we]1286-we were in some measure shut out from the west side of the fall by [the private grounds]1359-the private grounds and fences of [Patterson]443-patterson , who appropriates not only a part of the water for [[his]443-patterson mill]1360-his mill , but a still larger part of the prospect , so that [we]1286-we were obliged to trespass . [[This gentleman]1361-this gentleman ’s mansion - house]1362-this gentleman ’s mansion - house and [grounds]1363-grounds were formerly occupied by [the Duke of [Kent]123-kent]1364-the duke of kent , [father to [Queen Victoria]446-queen victoria]1365-father to queen victoria . It appeared to [me]0-i in bad taste for [an individual]1366-an individual , though [he]1366-an individual were [the father of [Queen Victoria]446-queen victoria]1367-the father of queen victoria , to obtrude [himself]1366-an individual with [his]1366-an individual land titles , or at least [his]1366-an individual fences , on so remarkable a natural phenomenon , which should , in every sense , belong to mankind . [Some falls]1368-some falls should even be kept sacred from the intrusion of [mills]1369-mills and [factories]1370-factories , as water privileges in another than [the millwright]1371-the millwright ’s sense . [This small river falls]1372-this small river falls perpendicularly nearly two hundred and fifty feet at one pitch . [The St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence falls only one hundred and sixty - four feet at [Niagara]124-niagara . It is a very simple and noble fall , and leaves nothing to be desired ; but the most that [I]0-i could say of it would only have the force of one other testimony to assure [the reader]747-the reader that it is there . [We]1374-we looked directly down on it from the point of a projecting rock , and saw far below [us]1374-we , on a low promontory , the grass kept fresh and green by the perpetual drizzle , looking like moss . [The rock]1375-the rock is a kind of slate , in the crevices of which grew ferns and golden - rods . The prevailing trees on [the shores]1067-the shores were spruce and arbor - vitæ,—the latter very large and now full of fruit,—also aspens , alders , and [the mountain - ash]1377-the mountain - ash with its berries . [Every emigrant who arrives in [this country]5239-this country by way of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1378-every emigrant who arrives in this country by way of the st. lawrence , as [he]1378-every emigrant who arrives in this country by way of the st. lawrence opens [a point of [the Isle of Orleans]93-the isle of orleans]1380-a point of the isle of orleans , sees [the Montmorenci]106-montmorenci tumbling into [the Great River]126-the great river thus magnificently in a vast white sheet , making its contribution with emphasis . [Roberval]447-roberval ’s pilot , [Jean Alphonse]448-jean alphonse , saw this fall thus , and described it , in 1542 . It is a splendid introduction to the scenery of [Quebec]16-quebec . Instead of [an artificial fountain in [[its]1381-an artificial fountain in its square square]1382-its square]1381-an artificial fountain in its square , [Quebec]16-quebec has [this magnificent natural waterfall]1383-this magnificent natural waterfall to adorn one side of [[its]1381-an artificial fountain in its square harbor]1384-its harbor . Within the mouth of the chasm below , which can be entered only at ebb tide , [we]1385-we had a grand view at once of [Quebec]16-quebec and of the fall . [Kalm]425-kalm says that the noise of the fall is sometimes heard at [Quebec]16-quebec , about eight miles distant , and is a sign of a northeast wind . The side of this chasm , of soft and crumbling slate too steep to climb , was among the memorable features of the scene . In the winter of 1829 the frozen spray of the fall , descending on the ice of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence , made [a hill one hundred and twenty - six feet high]1386-a hill one hundred and twenty - six feet high . It is an annual phenomenon which some think may help explain the formation of glaciers .

In the vicinity of the fall [we]1385-we began to notice what looked like [our]1385-we red - fruited thorn bushes , grown to the size of ordinary apple - trees , very common , and full of large red or yellow fruit , which [the inhabitants called _ pommettes _]1387-the inhabitants called _ pommettes _ , but [I]0-i did not learn that [they]1387-the inhabitants called _ pommettes _ were put to any use .

------------------------------------------------------------------------

CHAPTER III .

[ST . ANNE]449-st . anne .

By the middle of [the forenoon]127-the forenoon , though it was a rainy day , [we]1385-we were once more on [our]1385-we way down [the north bank of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1388-the north bank of the st. lawrence , in a northeasterly direction , toward [the Falls of [St. Anne]128-st. anne]1389-the falls of st. anne , which are about thirty miles from [Quebec]16-quebec . The settled , more level , and [fertile portion of [Canada East]148-canada east]1390-fertile portion of canada east may be described rudely as a triangle , with its apex slanting toward the northeast , about one hundred miles wide at [its]148-canada east base , and from two to three , or even four hundred miles long , if [you]1391-you reckon its narrow northeastern extremity ; it being [the immediate valley of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1392-the immediate valley of the st. lawrence and [its]148-canada east tributaries , rising by a single or by successive terraces toward [the mountains]1393-the mountains on either hand . Though the words [Canada East]148-canada east on [the map]1394-the map stretch over many rivers and [lakes and unexplored wildernesses]1395-lakes and unexplored wildernesses , the actual [Canada]1-canada , which might be the colored portion of the map , is but a little clearing on the banks of [the river]905-the river , which one of those syllables would more than cover . [The banks of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1397-the banks of the st. lawrence are rather low from [Montreal]15-montreal to [the Richelieu Rapids]78-the richelieu rapids , about forty miles above [Quebec]16-quebec . Thence [they]1397-the banks of the st. lawrence rise gradually to [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond , or [Quebec]16-quebec . Where [we]1398-we now were , [eight miles northeast of [Quebec]16-quebec]1399-eight miles northeast of quebec , [the mountains which form the northern side of [this triangle]1401-this triangle]1400-the mountains which form the northern side of this triangle were only five or six miles distant from [the river]905-the river , gradually departing farther and farther from [it]905-the river , on the west , till [they]1397-the banks of the st. lawrence reach [the Ottawa]260-ottawa , and making haste to meet it on the east , at [Cape Tourmente]132-cape tourmente , now in plain sight about twenty miles distant . So that [we]1398-we were travelling in a very narrow and sharp triangle between [the mountains]1393-the mountains and [the river]905-the river , tilted up toward [the mountains on the north]1405-the mountains on the north , never losing sight of [[our]1398-we great fellow - traveller on [our]1398-we right]1406-our great fellow - traveller on our right . According to [Bouchette]450-bouchette ’s Topographical Description of [the Canadas]133-the canadas , [we]1398-we were in [the Seigniory of [the Côte de Beaupré]1407-the côte de beaupré]134-the seigniory of the côte de beaupré , in [the county of Montmorenci]1408-the county of montmorenci , and [the district of Quebec]1409-the district of quebec ; in [that part of [Canada]1-canada]1410-that part of canada which was the first to be settled , and where the face of [the country]750-the country and [the population]1412-the population have undergone the least change from the beginning , where the influence of [the States]841-the states and of [Europe]135-europe is least felt , and [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants see little or nothing of the world over the walls of [Quebec]16-quebec . [This Seigniory]136-this seigniory was granted in 1636 , and is now [the property of [the Seminary of Quebec]137-the seminary of quebec]1415-the property of the seminary of quebec . It is [the most mountainous one in [the province]1417-the province]1416-the most mountainous one in the province . There are [some half [a dozen parishes in [it]1415-the property of the seminary of quebec]1419-a dozen parishes in it , each containing [a church , parsonage - house , [grist - mill]1421-grist - mill]1420-a church , parsonage - house , grist - mill]1418-some half a dozen parishes in it , each containing a church , parsonage - house , grist - mill , and [several saw - mills]1422-several saw - mills . [We]1423-we were now in [the most westerly parish called [Ange Gardien]138-ange gardien]1424-the most westerly parish called ange gardien , or the [Guardian Angel]139-guardian angel , which is bounded on the west by [the Montmorenci]106-montmorenci . [The north bank of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1388-the north bank of the st. lawrence here is formed on a grand scale . It slopes gently , either directly from [the shore]846-the shore , or from the edge of an interval , till , at the distance of about a mile , it attains the height of four or five hundred feet . [The single road]1427-the single road runs along the side of [the slope]1428-the slope two or three hundred feet above [the river]905-the river at first , and from a quarter of a mile to a mile distant from [it]905-the river , and affords fine views of [the north channel]1430-the north channel , which is about a mile wide , and of [the beautiful Isle of [Orleans]141-orleans]1431-the beautiful isle of orleans , about twenty miles long by five wide , where grow the best apples and plums in the [Quebec District]142-quebec district .

Though there was but [this single road]1432-this single road , [it]1432-this single road was [a continuous village]1433-a continuous village for as far as [we]1423-we walked this day and the next , or about thirty miles down [the river]905-the river , [the houses being as near together all the way as in the middle of one of [[our]1423-we smallest straggling country villages]1436-our smallest straggling country villages]1435-the houses being as near together all the way as in the middle of one of our smallest straggling country villages , and [we]1423-we could never tell by [their]1435-the houses being as near together all the way as in the middle of one of our smallest straggling country villages number when [we]1423-we were on the skirts of [a parish]1437-a parish , for [the road]1438-the road never ran through [the fields]1304-the fields or [woods]1440-woods . [We]1423-we were told that it was just six miles from [one parish church]1441-one parish church to another . [I]0-i thought that [we]1423-we saw [every house in [Ange Gardien]138-ange gardien]1442-every house in ange gardien . Therefore , as it was a muddy day , [we]1423-we never got out of the mud , nor out of [the village]891-the village , unless [we]1423-we got over the fence ; then indeed , if it was on [the north side]1444-the north side , [we]1423-we were out of [the civilized world]1445-the civilized world . There were sometimes [a few more houses near [the church]980-the church]1446-a few more houses near the church , it is true , but [we]1423-we had only to go a quarter of a mile from [the road]1438-the road to the top of [the bank]1449-the bank to find [ourselves]1423-we on the verge of [the uninhabited]1450-the uninhabited , and , for the most part , unexplored wilderness stretching toward [Hudson ’s Bay]143-hudson ’s bay . [The farms]1451-the farms accordingly were extremely long and narrow , each having a frontage on [the river]905-the river . [Bouchette]450-bouchette accounts for this peculiar manner of laying out [a village]5245-a village by referring to “ the social character of [the Canadian peasant , who is singularly fond of [neighborhood , ”]5256-neighborhood , ”[450-bouchette] also to the advantage arising from a concentration of strength in Indian times]5255-the canadian peasant , who is singularly fond of neighborhood , ” also to the advantage arising from a concentration of strength in indian times . [Each farm]1454-each farm , called _ terre _ , [he]450-bouchette says , is , in nine cases out of ten , three arpents wide by thirty deep , that is , very nearly thirty - five by three hundred and forty - nine of [our]1423-we rods ; sometimes one half arpent by thirty , or one to sixty ; sometimes , in fact , a few yards by half a mile . Of course it costs more for fences . A remarkable difference between [the Canadian]412-the indians and the [New England]20-new england character appears from the fact that in 1745 , [the French government]1455-the french government were obliged to pass a law forbidding [the farmers]1456-the farmers or _ censitaires _ building on land less than one and a half arpents front by thirty or forty deep , under a certain penalty , in order to compel emigration , and bring [the seigneur ’s estates]1457-the seigneur ’s estates all under cultivation ; and it is thought that [they]1457-the seigneur ’s estates have now less reluctance to leave the paternal roof than formerly , “ removing beyond the sight of [the parish spire]5257-the parish spire , or the sound of [the parish bell]5258-the parish bell . ”[1457-the seigneur ’s estates] But [I]0-i find that in the previous or seventeenth century , the complaint , often renewed , was of a totally opposite character , namely , that [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants dispersed and exposed [themselves]1006-the inhabitants to [the Iroquois]413-the iroquois . Accordingly , about 1664 , [the king]1459-the king was obliged to order that “ [they]1006-the inhabitants should make no more clearings except one next to another , and that [they]1006-the inhabitants should reduce [their]1006-the inhabitants parishes to the form of [the parishes in [France]116-france]5259-the parishes in france as much as possible . ”[1459-the king] [The Canadians of those days]1460-the canadians of those days , at least , possessed a roving spirit of adventure which carried [them]1460-the canadians of those days further , in exposure to hardship and danger , than ever [the New England colonist]1461-the new england colonist went , and led [them]1460-the canadians of those days , though not to clear and colonize [the wilderness]1462-the wilderness , yet to range over it as _ coureurs de bois _ , or runners of [the woods]1463-the woods , or as [Hontan]426-hontan prefers to call [them]1460-the canadians of those days _ coureurs de risques _ , [runners of risks]1464-runners of risks ; to say nothing of [their]1464-runners of risks enterprising priesthood ; and [Charlevoix]440-charlevoix thinks that if [the authorities]1465-the authorities had taken the right steps to prevent [the youth]1466-the youth from ranging [the woods]1463-the woods ( _ de courir les bois _ ) [they]1465-the authorities would have had [an excellent militia]1468-an excellent militia to fight [the Indians]412-the indians and English .

[The road]1438-the road , in [this clayey looking soil]1470-this clayey looking soil , was exceedingly muddy in consequence of the night ’s rain . [We]1471-we met [an old woman directing [her]1472-an old woman directing her dog dog]1472-an old woman directing her dog , which was harnessed to [a little cart]1473-a little cart , to [the least muddy part of [it]1473-a little cart]1474-the least muddy part of it . It was a beggarly sight . But harnessed to [the cart]1475-the cart as [he]1475-the cart was , [we]1471-we heard [him]1475-the cart barking after [we]1471-we had passed , though [we]1471-we looked anywhere but to [the cart]1475-the cart to see where the dog was that barked . [The houses commonly fronted [the south]1040-the south]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south , whatever angle [they]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south might make with [the road]1438-the road ; and frequently [they]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south had no door nor cheerful window on [the roadside]1480-the roadside . Half the time [they]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south stood fifteen to forty rods from [the road]1438-the road , and there was no very obvious passage to [them]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south , so that [you]1482-you would suppose that there must be [another road running by [them]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south]1483-another road running by them . [They]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south were of stone , rather coarsely mortared , but neatly whitewashed , almost invariably one story high and long in proportion to [their]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south height , with a shingled roof , the shingles being pointed , for ornament , at the eaves , like the pickets of a fence , and also one row half - way up the roof . The gables sometimes projected a foot or two at the ridge - pole only . Yet [they]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south were very humble and unpretending dwellings . [They]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south commonly had the date of [their]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south erection on [them]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south . The windows opened in the middle , like blinds , and were frequently provided with solid shutters . Sometimes , when [we]1471-we walked along the back side of [a house]1156-a house which stood near [the road]1438-the road , [we]1471-we observed stout stakes leaning against [it]1156-a house ; by which the shutters , now pushed half open , were fastened at night ; within , [the houses]1086-the houses were neatly ceiled with wood not painted . The oven was commonly out of doors , built of stone and mortar , frequently on a raised platform of planks . [The cellar]1487-the cellar was often on the opposite side of [the road]1438-the road , in front of or behind [the houses]1086-the houses , looking like [an ice - house with [us]1471-we]1490-an ice - house with us with a lattice door for summer . The very few mechanics whom [we]1471-we met had an old - Bettyish look , in [their]1477-the houses commonly fronted the south aprons and _ bonnets rouges _ , like [fools]1491-fools ’ caps . [The men]1305-the men wore commonly the same _ bonnet rouge _ , or red woollen or worsted cap , or sometimes blue or gray , looking to [us]1471-we as if [they]1305-the men had got up with [their]1305-the men night - caps on , and , in fact , [I]0-i afterwards found that [they]1305-the men had . [Their]1305-the men clothes were of the cloth of [the country]750-the country , _ étoffe du pays _ , gray or some other plain color . [The women]1330-the women looked stout , with gowns that stood out stiffly , also , for the most part , apparently of some home - made stuff . [We]1471-we also saw some specimens of the more characteristic winter dress of [the Canadian]412-the indians , and [I]0-i have since frequently detected [him]1495-his in [New England]20-new england by [his]1495-his coarse gray homespun capote and picturesque red sash , and [his]1495-his well - furred cap , made to protect [his]1495-his ears against the severity of [his]1495-his climate .

It drizzled all day , so that [the roads]5254-the roads did not improve . [We]1471-we began now to meet with wooden crosses frequently , by [the roadside]1480-the roadside , about a dozen feet high , often old and toppling down , sometimes standing in a square wooden platform , sometimes in a pile of stones , with a little niche containing a picture of [the Virgin]1498-the virgin and [Child]451-child , or of [Christ]452-christ alone , sometimes with a string of beads , and covered with a piece of glass to keep out the rain , with the words , _ pour la vierge _ , or _ Iniri _ , on [them]1499-them . Frequently , on the cross - bar , there would be quite a collection of symbolical knickknacks , looking like an Italian ’s board ; the representation in wood of a hand , a hammer , spikes , pincers , a flask of vinegar , a ladder , & c. , the whole , perchance , surmounted by a weathercock ; but [I]0-i could not look at [an honest weathercock]1500-an honest weathercock in this walk without mistrusting that there was some covert reference in it to [St. Peter]453-st. peter . From time to time [we]1471-we passed [a little one - story chapel - like building , with a tin - roofed spire , a shrine , perhaps it would be called , close to the pathside , with a lattice door , through which [we]1471-we could see an altar , and pictures about the walls]1501-a little one - story chapel - like building , with a tin - roofed spire , a shrine , perhaps it would be called , close to the pathside , with a lattice door , through which we could see an altar , and pictures about the walls ; equally open , through rain and shine , though there was no getting into [it]1501-a little one - story chapel - like building , with a tin - roofed spire , a shrine , perhaps it would be called , close to the pathside , with a lattice door , through which we could see an altar , and pictures about the walls . At these places [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants kneeled and perhaps breathed a short prayer . [We]1471-we saw [one school - house in [our]1471-we walk]1503-one school - house in our walk , and listened to the sounds which issued from it ; but it appeared like a place where the process , not of enlightening , but of obfuscating the mind was going on , and [the pupils]1504-the pupils received only so much light as could penetrate the shadow of [the Catholic Church]1505-the catholic church . [The churches]1506-the churches were very picturesque , and [their]1506-the churches interior much more showy than [the dwelling - houses]1507-the dwelling - houses promised . [They]1506-the churches were of stone , for it was ordered , in 1699 , that that should be [their]1506-the churches material . [They]1506-the churches had tinned spires , and quaint ornaments . That of l’Ange [Gardien]454-gardien had a dial on it , with the Middle Age Roman numerals on its face , and some images in niches on the outside . Probably its counterpart has existed in [Normandy]145-normandy for a thousand years . At [the church of [Chateau Richer]146-chateau richer]1508-the church of chateau richer , which is [the next parish to l’Ange Gardien]1509-the next parish to l’ange gardien , [we]1471-we read , looking over the wall , the inscriptions in [the adjacent churchyard]1510-the adjacent churchyard , which began with , “ _ Ici git _ ”[1471-we] or “ _ Repose _ ”[1511-a boy] and one over [a boy]1511-a boy contained , “ _ [Priez]455-priez pour lui _ . ”[1511-a boy] This answered as well as Père la Chaise . [We]1471-we knocked at the door of [the curé ’s house here]1512-the curé ’s house here , when a sleek friar - like personage , in [his]1511-a boy sacerdotal robe , appeared . To [our]1471-we _ [Parlez - vous Anglais]442-parlez - vous anglais ? _ even [he]1511-a boy answered , “ _ Non , [Monsieur _ ”]5260-monsieur _ ”[1511-a boy] ; but at last [we]1471-we made [him]1511-a boy understand what [we]1471-we wanted . It was to find the ruins of [the old _ chateau _]1513-the old _ chateau _ . “ _ Ah ! oui ! oui ! _ ”[1511-a boy] [he]1511-a boy exclaimed , and , donning [his]1511-a boy coat , hastened forth , and conducted [us]1471-we to a small heap of rubbish which [we]1471-we had already examined . [He]1511-a boy said that fifteen years before , it was _ plus considérable _ . Seeing at that moment three little red birds fly out of a crevice in [the ruins]1514-the ruins , up into an arbor - vitæ tree , which grew out of [them]1514-the ruins , [I]0-i asked [him]1511-a boy [their]1514-the ruins names , in such French as [I]0-i could muster , but [he]1511-a boy neither understood [me]0-i nor ornithology ; [he]1511-a boy only inquired where [we]1471-we had _ appris à parler Français _ ; [we]1471-we told [him]1511-a boy , _ dans les États - Unis _ ; and so [we]1471-we bowed [him]1511-a boy into [[his]1511-a boy house]1515-his house again . [I]0-i was surprised to find [a man wearing a black coat]1516-a man wearing a black coat , and with apparently no work to do , even in [that part of [the world]741-the world]1517-that part of the world .

The universal salutation from [the inhabitants whom [we]1471-we met]1519-the inhabitants whom we met was _ bon jour _ , at the same time touching the hat ; with _ bon jour _ , and touching [your]1520-your hat , [you]1520-your may go smoothly through all [Canada East]148-canada east . [A little boy]1521-a little boy , meeting [us]1471-we , would remark , “ _ Bon jour , [Monsieur]5261-monsieur ; le chemin est mauvais _ ”[1521-a little boy] Good morning , [sir]5242-sir ; it is bad walking . [Sir Francis Head]456-sir francis head says that [the immigrant]1523-the immigrant is forward to “ appreciate the happiness of living in a land in which the old country ’s servile custom of touching the hat does not exist , ”[1523-the immigrant] but [he]1511-a boy was thinking of [Canada West]149-canada west , of course . It would , indeed , be a serious bore to be obliged to touch [your]1520-your hat several times a day . [A Yankee]1524-a yankee has not leisure for it .

[We]1471-we saw peas , and even beans , collected into heaps in [the fields]1304-the fields . The former are an important crop here , and , [I]0-i suppose , are not so much infested by the weevil as with [us]1471-we . There were plenty of apples , very fair and sound , by [the roadside]1480-the roadside , but they were so small as to suggest the origin of the apple in the crab . There was also a small red fruit which [they]1527-they called _ snells _ , and another , also red and very acid , whose name [a little boy]1521-a little boy wrote for [me]0-i “ _ pinbéna _ . ”[1521-a little boy] It is probably the same with , or similar to , the _ pembina _ of the voyageurs , a species of viburnum , which , according to [Richardson]457-richardson , has given its name to many of [the rivers of [Rupert ’s Land]150-rupert ’s land]1529-the rivers of rupert ’s land . The forest trees were spruce , arbor - vitæ , firs , birches , beeches , two or three kinds of maple , bass - wood , wild - cherry , aspens , & c , but no pitch pines ( _ Pinus rigida _ ) . [I]0-i saw very few , if any , trees which had been set out for shade or ornament . The water was commonly running streams or springs in the bank by [the roadside]1480-the roadside , and was excellent . [The parishes]1531-the parishes are commonly separated by [a stream]1532-a stream , and frequently [the farms]1451-the farms . [I]0-i noticed that [the fields]1304-the fields were furrowed or thrown into [beds]1535-beds seven or eight feet wide to dry the soil .

At the _ Rivière du Sault à la Puce _ , which , [I]0-i suppose , means [the River of the Fall of the Flea]151-the river of the fall of the flea , was advertised in English , as [the sportsmen]1536-the sportsmen are English , “ [The best Snipe - shooting grounds , ”]5262-the best snipe - shooting grounds , ”[1536-the sportsmen] over the door of [a small public - house]1537-a small public - house . These words being English affected [me]0-i as if [I]0-i had been absent now ten years from [[my]0-i country]1538-my country , and for so long had not heard the sound of [my]0-i native language , and [every one of [them]1536-the sportsmen]1539-every one of them was as interesting to [me]0-i as if [I]0-i had been a snipe - shooter , and [they]1536-the sportsmen had been snipes . The prunella or self - heal , in the grass here , was [an old acquaintance]1540-an old acquaintance . [We]1541-we frequently saw [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants washing , or cooking for [their]1006-the inhabitants pigs , and in one place hackling flax by [the roadside]1480-the roadside . It was pleasant to see these usually domestic operations carried on out of doors , even in [that cold country]1544-that cold country .

At twilight [we]1541-we reached a bridge over [a little river]1545-a little river , the boundary between [Chateau Richer]146-chateau richer and [St. Anne]128-st. anne , [_ le premier pont de St. Anne _]1546-_ le premier pont de st. anne _ , and at dark [the church of _ La Bonne St. Anne _]1547-the church of _ la bonne st. anne _ . Formerly vessels from [France]116-france , when [they]1536-the sportsmen came in sight of [this church]935-this church , gave “ a general discharge of [their]1536-the sportsmen artillery , ”[1536-the sportsmen] as a sign of joy that [they]1536-the sportsmen had escaped all the dangers of [the river]905-the river . Though all the while [we]1541-we had grand views of [the adjacent country]1550-the adjacent country far up and down [the river]905-the river , and , for the most part , when [we]1541-we turned about , of [Quebec]16-quebec in the horizon behind [us]1541-we , and [we]1541-we never beheld it without new surprise and admiration ; yet , throughout [our]1541-we walk , [the Great River of Canada]152-the great river of canada on [our]1541-we right hand was the main feature in [the landscape]1552-the landscape , and this expands so rapidly below the [Isle of Orleans]93-the isle of orleans , and creates such a breadth of level horizon above [its]152-the great river of canada waters in that direction , that , looking down [the river]905-the river as [we]1541-we approached [the extremity of [that island]1555-that island]1554-the extremity of that island , the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence seemed to be opening into [the ocean]1556-the ocean , though [we]1541-we were still about three hundred and twenty - five miles from what can be called [its]905-the river mouth.[2 ]

Footnote 2 :

From [McCulloch]458-mcculloch ’s Geographical Dictionary [we]1541-we learn that “ immediately beyond [the Island of Orleans]153-the island of orleans [it]153-the island of orleans is a mile broad ; where [the Saguenay]154-the saguenay joins [it]153-the island of orleans , eighteen miles ; at [Point Peter]155-point peter , upwards of thirty ; at [the Bay of Seven Islands]156-the bay of seven islands , seventy miles ; and at [the Island of [Anticosti]157-anticosti]5263-the island of anticosti ( about three hundred and fifty miles from [Quebec]16-quebec ) it rolls a flood into [the ocean]1556-the ocean nearly one hundred miles across . ”[1541-we]

When [we]1541-we inquired here for [a _ maison publique _]1557-a _ maison publique _ [we]1541-we were directed apparently to [that private house]1558-that private house where [we]1541-we were most likely to find entertainment . There were no guideboards where [we]1541-we walked , because there was but [one road]1316-one road ; there were [no shops]1560-no shops nor signs , because there were [no artisans]1561-no artisans to speak of , and [the people]1562-the people raised [their]1562-the people own provisions ; and there were [no taverns]1563-no taverns , because there were [no travellers]1564-no travellers . [We]1541-we [here bespoke lodging]1565-here bespoke lodging and breakfast . [They]1541-we had , as usual , a large old - fashioned , two - storied box - stove in the middle of [the room]1352-the room , out of which , in due time , there was sure to be forthcoming a supper , breakfast , or dinner . The lower half held the fire , the upper the hot air , and as it was a cool Canadian evening , this was a comforting sight to [us]1541-we . Being four or five feet high it warmed [the whole person]1567-the whole person as [you]1568-you stood by [it]1567-the whole person . The stove was plainly a very important article of furniture in [Canada]1-canada , and was not set aside during the summer . Its size , and the respect which was paid to it , told of the severe winters which it had seen and prevailed over . [The master of [the house]1349-the house]1348-the master of the house , in [his]1348-the master of the house long - pointed , red woollen cap , had a thoroughly antique physiognomy of the old Norman stamp . [He]1348-the master of the house might have come over with [Jacques Cartier]410-cartier . [His]1348-the master of the house was the hardest French to understand of any [we]1571-we had heard yet , for there was a great difference between [one speaker]1572-one speaker and another , and [this man]1573-this man talked with a pipe in [his]1573-this man mouth beside , a kind of tobacco French . [I]0-i asked [him]1573-this man what [he]1573-this man called [his]1573-this man dog . [He]1573-this man shouted _ Brock ! _ ( the name of the breed ) . [We]1541-we like to hear the cat called _ min_,—min ! min ! min ! [I]0-i inquired if [we]1541-we could cross [the river]905-the river here to [the Isle of Orleans]93-the isle of orleans , thinking to return that way when [we]1541-we had been to [the Falls]158-the falls . [He]1573-this man answered , “ _ S’il ne fait pas un trop grand vent _ , ”[1573-this man] If there is not too much wind . [They]1575-they use [small boats]1576-small boats , or pirogues , and the waves are often too high for [them]1575-they . [He]1573-this man wore , as usual , something between a moccasin and a boot , which [he]1573-this man called _ bottes Indiennes _ , Indian boots , and had made [himself]1573-this man . The tops were of calf or sheep - skin , and the soles of cowhide turned up like a moccasin . [They]1575-they were yellow or reddish , the leather never having been tanned nor colored . [The women]1330-the women wore the same . [He]1573-this man told [us]1541-we that [he]1573-this man had travelled ten leagues due north into the bush . [He]1573-this man had been to [the Falls of [St. Anne]128-st. anne]1389-the falls of st. anne , and said that [they]1330-the women were more beautiful , but not greater , than [Montmorenci]106-montmorenci , _ plus beau , mais non plus grand que Montmorenci _ . As soon as [we]1541-we had retired , [the family]1579-the family commenced [their]1579-the family devotions . [A little boy]1521-a little boy officiated , and for a long time [we]1541-we heard [him]1521-a little boy muttering over [his]1521-a little boy prayers .

In the morning , after a breakfast of tea , maple - sugar , bread and butter , and what [I]0-i suppose is called _ potage _ ( potatoes and meat boiled with flour ) , the universal dish as [we]1541-we found , perhaps the national one , [I]0-i ran over to [the Church of [La Bonne St. Anne]159-la bonne st. anne , whose matin bell [we]1541-we had heard]1581-the church of la bonne st. anne , whose matin bell we had heard , it being Sunday morning . [Our]1541-we book said that [this church]935-this church had “ long been an object of interest , from the miraculous cures said to have been wrought on [visitors]5265-visitors to [the shrine]5266-the shrine . ”[1541-we] There was a profusion of gilding , and [I]0-i counted more than twenty - five crutches suspended on the walls , some for [grown persons]1583-grown persons , some for [children , which it was to be inferred so many sick]1584-children , which it was to be inferred so many sick had been able to dispense with ; but [they]1584-children , which it was to be inferred so many sick looked as if [they]1584-children , which it was to be inferred so many sick had been made to order by [the carpenter who made [the church]980-the church]1585-the carpenter who made the church . There were [one or two villagers]1587-one or two villagers at [their]1587-one or two villagers devotions at that early hour , who did not look up , but when [they]1587-one or two villagers had sat a long time with [their]1587-one or two villagers little book before the picture of [one saint]1588-one saint , went to another . [Our]1541-we whole walk was through [a thoroughly Catholic country]1589-a thoroughly catholic country , and there was no trace of any other religion . [I]0-i doubt if there are [any more simple and unsophisticated Catholics]1590-any more simple and unsophisticated catholics anywhere . [Emery de Caen]460-emery de caen , [[Champlain]411-champlain ’s contemporary]1591-champlain ’s contemporary , told [the Huguenot sailors]1592-the huguenot sailors that “ [Monseigneur]461-monseigneur , [the Duke de Ventadour]462-the duke de ventadour ( [Viceroy]5267-viceroy ) , did not wish that [they]1592-the huguenot sailors should sing psalms in [the Great River]126-the great river . ”[460-emery de caen]

On [our]1541-we way to [the Falls]1318-the falls , [we]1541-we met [the habitans]1594-the habitans coming to [the Church of [La Bonne St. Anne]159-la bonne st. anne]1595-the church of la bonne st. anne , walking or riding in charettes by [families]1596-families . [I]0-i remarked that [they]1594-the habitans were universally of small stature . [The toll - man at [the bridge over the [St. Anne]128-st. anne]1598-the bridge over the st. anne]1597-the toll - man at the bridge over the st. anne was [the first man [we]1541-we had chanced to meet]1599-the first man we had chanced to meet , since [we]1541-we left [Quebec]16-quebec , who could speak a word of English . How good French [the inhabitants of [this part of [Canada]1-canada]1601-this part of canada]1600-the inhabitants of this part of canada speak , [I]0-i am not competent to say ; [I]0-i only know that it is not made impure by being mixed with English . [I]0-i do not know why it should not be as good as is spoken in [Normandy]145-normandy . [Charlevoix]440-charlevoix , who was here a hundred years ago , observes , “ The French language is nowhere spoken with greater purity , there being no accent perceptible ”[440-charlevoix] ; and [Potherie]463-potherie said “ [they]1600-the inhabitants of this part of canada had no dialect , which , indeed , is generally lost in [a colony]5268-a colony . ”[463-potherie]

[The falls]1318-the falls , which [we]1541-we were in search of , are three miles up the [St. Anne]128-st. anne . [We]1541-we followed for a short distance a foot - path up [the east bank of [this river]1085-this river]1603-the east bank of this river , through [handsome sugar - maple and arbor - vitæ groves]1605-handsome sugar - maple and arbor - vitæ groves . Having lost the path which led to [a house where [we]1541-we were to get further directions]1606-a house where we were to get further directions , [we]1541-we dashed at once into [the woods]1463-the woods , steering by guess and by compass , climbing directly through [woods]1440-woods , [a steep hill , or mountain , five or six hundred feet high , which was]1609-a steep hill , or mountain , five or six hundred feet high , which was , in fact , only [the bank of the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1610-the bank of the st. lawrence . Beyond this [we]1541-we by good luck fell into [another path]1611-another path , and following this or a branch of it , at [our]1541-we discretion , through [a forest consisting of large white pines,—the first [we]1541-we had seen in [our]1541-we walk,—we]1612-a forest consisting of large white pines,—the first we had seen in our walk,—we at length heard the roar of falling water , and came out at the head of [the Falls of [St. Anne]128-st. anne]1389-the falls of st. anne . [We]1541-we had descended into [a ravine]1614-a ravine or cleft in [the mountain]1615-the mountain , whose walls rose still a hundred feet above [us]1541-we , though [we]1541-we were near its top , and [we]1541-we now stood on [a very rocky shore]1616-a very rocky shore , where the water had lately flowed a dozen feet higher , as appeared by the stones and drift - wood , and large birches twisted and splintered as [a farmer]1617-a farmer twists a withe . Here [the river]905-the river , one or two hundred feet wide , came flowing rapidly over a rocky bed out of [that interesting wilderness]1619-that interesting wilderness which stretches toward [Hudson ’s Bay]143-hudson ’s bay and [Davis ’s Straits]161-davis ’s straits . [Ha - ha Bay]162-ha - ha bay , on [the Saguenay]154-the saguenay , was about one hundred miles north of where [we]1541-we stood . Looking on the map , [I]0-i find that [the first country on the north which bears a name is that part of [Rupert ’s Land]150-rupert ’s land called [East Main]164-east main]1620-the first country on the north which bears a name is that part of rupert ’s land called east main . [This river]1085-this river , called after [the holy Anne]449-st . anne , flowing from such a direction , here tumbled over [a precipice , at present by three channels]1622-a precipice , at present by three channels , how far down [I]0-i do not know , but far enough for all [our]1541-we purposes , and to as good a distance as if twice as far . It matters little whether [you]1623-you call it one , or two , or three hundred feet ; at any rate , it was a sufficient Water - privilege for [us]1541-we . [I]0-i crossed the principal channel directly over the verge of the fall , where it was contracted to about fifteen feet in width by a dead tree , which had been dropped across and secured in a cleft of the opposite rock , and a smaller one a few feet higher , which served for a hand - rail . [This bridge]1624-this bridge was rotten as well as small and slippery , being stripped of bark , and [I]0-i was obliged to seize a moment to pass when the falling water did not surge over it , and mid - way , though at the expense of wet feet , [I]0-i looked down probably more than a hundred feet , into the mist and foam below . This gave [me]0-i the freedom of [an island of precipitous rock]1625-an island of precipitous rock , by which [I]0-i descended as by giant steps , the rock being composed of large cubical masses , clothed with delicate close - hugging lichens of various colors , kept fresh and bright by the moisture , till [I]0-i viewed the first fall from the front , and looked down still deeper to where [the second and third channels]1626-the second and third channels fell into a remarkably large circular basin worn in the stone . The falling water seemed to jar the very rocks , and the noise to be ever increasing . [The vista down stream]1627-the vista down stream was through a narrow and deep cleft in [the mountain]1615-the mountain , [all white suds at the bottom]1629-all white suds at the bottom ; but a sudden angle in [this gorge]1630-this gorge prevented [my]0-i seeing through to the bottom of the fall . Returning to [the shore]846-the shore , [I]0-i made [my]0-i way down [stream]1632-stream through [the forest]752-the forest to see how far the fall extended , and how [the river]905-the river came out of that adventure . It was to clamber along the side of [a precipitous mountain of loose mossy rocks]1635-a precipitous mountain of loose mossy rocks , covered with [a damp primitive forest]1636-a damp primitive forest , and terminating at the bottom in an abrupt precipice over [the stream]1637-the stream . This was the east side of the fall . At length , after a quarter of a mile , [I]0-i got down to still water , and , on looking up through [the winding gorge]1638-the winding gorge , [I]0-i could just see to the foot of the fall which [I]0-i had before examined ; while from the opposite side of [the stream]1637-the stream , here much contracted , rose a perpendicular wall , [I]0-i will not venture to say how many hundred feet , but only that it was the highest perpendicular wall of bare rock that [I]0-i ever saw . In front of [me]0-i tumbled in from the summit of [the cliff a tributary stream]1640-the cliff a tributary stream , making a beautiful cascade , which was a remarkable fall in itself , and there was a cleft in this precipice , apparently four or five feet wide , perfectly straight up and down from top to bottom , which , from its cavernous depth and darkness , appeared merely as _ a black streak _ . This precipice is not sloped , nor is the material soft and crumbling slate as at [Montmorenci]106-montmorenci , but it rises perfectly perpendicular , like the side of [a mountain fortress]1641-a mountain fortress , and is cracked into vast cubical masses of gray and black rock shining with moisture , as if it were the ruin of an ancient wall built by [Titans]464-titans . Birches , spruces , mountain - ashes with their bright red berries , arbor - vitæs , white pines , alders , & c. , overhung this chasm on the very verge of [the cliff]1642-the cliff and in the crevices , and here and there were buttresses of rock supporting trees part way down , yet so as to enhance , not injure , the effect of the bare rock . Take it altogether , it was a most wild and rugged and stupendous chasm , so deep and narrow where [a river]1643-a river had worn [itself]1643-a river a passage through [a mountain of rock , and all around was the comparatively untrodden wilderness]1644-a mountain of rock , and all around was the comparatively untrodden wilderness .

This was the limit of [our]1645-we walk down [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence . Early in the afternoon [we]1645-we began to retrace [our]1645-we steps , not being able to cross [the north channel]1430-the north channel and return by [the Isle of Orleans]1647-the isle of orleans , on account of [the _ trop grand vent _]1648-the _ trop grand vent _ , or too great wind . Though the waves did run pretty high , it was evident that [the inhabitants of [Montmorenci County]165-montmorenci county]1649-the inhabitants of montmorenci county were [no sailors]1650-no sailors , and made but little use of [the river]905-the river . When [we]1645-we reached [the bridge]1652-the bridge , between [St. Anne]128-st. anne and [Chateau Richer]146-chateau richer , [I]0-i ran back a little way to ask a man in the field the name of [the river]905-the river which [we]1645-we were crossing , but for a long time [I]0-i could not make out what [he]1654-he said , for [he]1654-he was one of the more unintelligible [Jacques Cartier men]410-cartier . At last it flashed upon [me]0-i that it was _ La Rivière au Chien _ , or [the Dog River]166-the dog river , which [my]0-i eyes beheld , which brought to [my]0-i mind the life of the Canadian voyageur and _ coureur de bois _ , [a more western and wilder Arcadia]1655-a more western and wilder arcadia , [methinks]1656-methinks , than [the world]741-the world has ever seen ; for [the Greeks]1658-the greeks , with all [their]1658-the greeks wood and river gods , were not so qualified to name the natural features of [a country]1235-a country , as [the ancestors of [these French Canadians]1661-these french canadians]1660-the ancestors of these french canadians ; and if [any people]1662-any people had a right to substitute [their]1662-any people own for the Indian names , it was [they]1662-any people . [They]1662-any people have preceded [the pioneer]1663-the pioneer on [[our]1664-our own frontiers]1665-our own frontiers , and named the _ prairie _ for [us]1664-our . _ La Rivière au Chien _ can not , by any license of language , be translated into [Dog River]166-the dog river , for that is not such a giving it to the dogs , and recognizing [their]1662-any people place in creation as the French implies . [One of [the tributaries of [the St. Anne]128-st. anne]1667-the tributaries of the st. anne]1666-one of the tributaries of the st. anne is named [_ La Rivière de la Rose _]169-_ la rivière de la rose _ ; and farther east are , [_ La Rivière de la Blondelle _ , and _ La Rivière de la Friponne _]1668-_ la rivière de la blondelle _ , and _ la rivière de la friponne _ . [Their]1666-one of the tributaries of the st. anne very _ rivière _ meanders more than [our]1664-our _ river _ .

Yet the impression which [this country]5239-this country made on [me]0-i was commonly different from this . To [a traveller from [the Old World]1671-the old world]1670-a traveller from the old world , [Canada East]148-canada east may appear like [a new country]1672-a new country , and [[its]1672-a new country inhabitants like [colonists]1674-colonists]1673-its inhabitants like colonists , but to [me]0-i , coming from [New England]20-new england , and being [a very green traveller]1675-a very green traveller withal,—notwithstanding what [I]0-i have said about [Hudson ’s Bay,—it]170-hudson ’s bay,—it appeared as old as [Normandy]145-normandy itself , and realized much that [I]0-i had heard of [Europe]135-europe and [the Middle Ages]1676-the middle ages . Even the names of [humble Canadian villages]1677-humble canadian villages affected [me]0-i as if [they]1677-humble canadian villages had been those of [the renowned cities of antiquity]1678-the renowned cities of antiquity . To be told by a habitan , when [I]0-i asked the name of [a village]5245-a village in sight , that it is _ [St. Fereole _ or _ St. Anne _]171-st. fereole _ or _ st. anne _ , the _ Guardian Angel _ or the _ [Holy Joseph]465-holy joseph ’s _ ; or of [a mountain]1680-a mountain , that it was _ Bélange _ or _ St. Hyacinthe _ ! As soon as [you]1681-you leave [the States]841-the states , these saintly names begin . _ [St. John]466-st. john _ is [the first town [you]1681-you stop at]1683-the first town you stop at ( fortunately [we]1684-we did not see [it]466-st. john ) , and thenceforward , the names of [the mountains]1393-the mountains , and [streams]1686-streams , and [villages]1687-villages reel , if [I]0-i may so speak , with the intoxication of poetry;—_Chambly _ , _ Longueil _ , _ [Pointe aux Trembles _]77-_ pointe aux trembles _ , _ Bartholomy _ , & c. , & c. ; as if it needed only a little foreign accent , a few more liquids and vowels perchance in the language , to make [us]1688-we locate [our]1688-we ideals at once . [I]0-i began to dream of [Provence]173-provence and [the Troubadours]174-the troubadours , and of places and things which have no existence on [the earth]1074-the earth . [They]1690-they veiled [the Indian]175-the indian and [the primitive forest]1691-the primitive forest , and [the woods]1463-the woods toward [Hudson ’s Bay]143-hudson ’s bay , were only as [the forests of [France]116-france and [Germany]176-germany]1693-the forests of france and germany . [I]0-i could not at once bring [myself]0-i to believe that [the inhabitants who pronounced daily those beautiful and , to [me]0-i , significant names , lead as prosaic lives as [we]1688-we of [New England]20-new england]1694-the inhabitants who pronounced daily those beautiful and , to me , significant names , lead as prosaic lives as we of new england . In short , the [Canada]1-canada which [I]0-i saw was not merely a place for [railroads]1695-railroads to terminate in and for [criminals]1696-criminals to run to .

When [I]0-i asked [the man]1697-the man to whom [I]0-i have referred , if there were any falls on the Rivière au Chien,—for [I]0-i saw that it came over the same high bank with [the Montmorenci]106-montmorenci and [St. Anne,—he]467-st. anne,—he answered that there were . How far ? [I]0-i inquired . _ Trois quatres lieue . _ How high ? _ Je pense , quatre - vingt - dix pieds _ ; that is , ninety feet . [We]1688-we turned aside to look at [the falls of [the _ Rivière du Sault à la Puce _]177-the _ rivière du sault à la puce _]1698-the falls of the _ rivière du sault à la puce _ , half a mile from [the road]1438-the road , which before [we]1688-we had passed in [our]1688-we haste and ignorance , and [we]1688-we pronounced [them]1698-the falls of the _ rivière du sault à la puce _ as beautiful as any that [we]1688-we saw ; yet [they]1698-the falls of the _ rivière du sault à la puce _ seemed to make no account of [them]1698-the falls of the _ rivière du sault à la puce _ there , and , when first [we]1688-we inquired the way to [the Falls]1318-the falls , directed [us]1688-we to [Montmorenci]106-montmorenci , seven miles distant . It was evident that this was [the country for waterfalls]1701-the country for waterfalls ; that [every stream that empties into [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1702-every stream that empties into the st. lawrence , for some hundreds of miles , must have a great fall or cascade on it , and in its passage through [the mountains]1393-the mountains was , for a short distance , a small Saguenay , with [its]1702-every stream that empties into the st. lawrence upright walls . This fall of [La Puce]178-la puce , the least remarkable of [the four which [we]1688-we visited in [this vicinity]1705-this vicinity]1704-the four which we visited in this vicinity , [we]1688-we had never heard of till [we]1688-we came to [Canada]1-canada , and yet , so far as [I]0-i know , there is nothing of the kind in [New England]20-new england to be compared with it . [Most travellers in [Canada]1-canada]1706-most travellers in canada would not hear of it , though [they]1706-most travellers in canada might go so near as to hear it . Since [my]0-i return [I]0-i find that in the topographical description of [the country]750-the country mention is made of “ two or [three romantic falls ”]5269-three romantic falls ”[0-i] on [this stream]1708-this stream , though [we]1688-we saw and heard of but [this one]1709-this one . Ask [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants respecting [any stream]1711-any stream , if there is a fall on it , and [they]1006-the inhabitants will perchance tell [you]1712-you of something as interesting as [Bashpish]468-bashpish or [the Catskill]469-the catskill , which [no traveller]1713-no traveller has ever seen , or if [they]1006-the inhabitants have not found it , [you]1714-you may possibly trace up [the stream]1637-the stream and discover it [yourself]1712-you . [Falls]158-the falls there are a drug ; and [we]1688-we became quite dissipated in respect to [them]1006-the inhabitants . [We]1688-we had drank too much of [them]1006-the inhabitants . Beside these which [I]0-i have referred to , there are a thousand other falls on [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence and [its]1637-the stream tributaries which [I]0-i have not seen nor heard of ; and above all there is one which [I]0-i have heard of , called [Niagara]124-niagara , so that [I]0-i think that [this river]1085-this river must be the most remarkable for [its]1085-this river falls of any in [the world]741-the world .

At [a house near [the western boundary of [Chateau Richer]146-chateau richer , whose [master]1720-master was said to speak a very little English , having recently lived at [Quebec]16-quebec]1719-the western boundary of chateau richer , whose master was said to speak a very little english , having recently lived at quebec]1718-a house near the western boundary of chateau richer , whose master was said to speak a very little english , having recently lived at quebec , [we]1688-we got lodging for the night . As usual , [we]1688-we had to go down [a lane]1721-a lane to get round to the south side of [the house]1349-the house where the door was , away from [the road]1438-the road . For [these Canadian houses]1724-these canadian houses have no front door , properly speaking . Every part is for the use of the occupant exclusively , and no part has reference to [the traveller]755-the traveller or to travel . [Every New England house]1726-every new england house , on the contrary , has a front and principal door opening to [the great world]1727-the great world , though it may be on the cold side , for [it]1726-every new england house stands on [the highway of nations]1728-the highway of nations , and [the road which runs by [it]1726-every new england house comes from [the Old World]1671-the old world]1729-the road which runs by it comes from the old world and goes to [the far West]1731-the far west ; but [the Canadian]412-the indians ’s door opens into [[his]146-chateau richer back - yard]1732-his back - yard and farm alone , and [the road which runs behind [[his]146-chateau richer house]1515-his house leads only from [the church of one saint to that of another]1735-the church of one saint to that of another]1733-the road which runs behind his house leads only from the church of one saint to that of another . [We]1736-we found [a large family]1737-a large family , hired [men]1028-men , [wife]1739-wife and [children]1123-children , just eating [their]1737-a large family supper . [They]1737-a large family prepared some for [us]1736-we afterwards . [The hired men]1741-the hired men were [a merry crew of short , black - eyed fellows]1742-a merry crew of short , black - eyed fellows , and [the wife a thin - faced , sharp - featured French Canadian woman]1743-the wife a thin - faced , sharp - featured french canadian woman . [[Our]1736-we host]1340-our host ’s English staggered [us]1736-we rather more than any French [we]1736-we had heard yet ; indeed , [we]1736-we found that even [we]1736-we spoke better French than [he]146-chateau richer did English , and [we]1736-we concluded that a less crime would be committed on the whole if [we]1736-we spoke French with [him]146-chateau richer , and in no respect aided or abetted [his]146-chateau richer attempts to speak English . [We]1736-we had a long and merry chat with [the family]1579-the family this Sunday evening in [[their]1579-the family spacious kitchen]1746-their spacious kitchen . While [[my]0-i companion]1747-my companion smoked a pipe and parlez - vous’d with one party , [I]0-i parleyed and gesticulated to another . [The whole family]1344-the whole family was enlisted , and [I]0-i kept [a little girl]1749-a little girl writing what was otherwise unintelligible . The geography getting obscure , [we]1736-we called for chalk , and the greasy oiled table - cloth having been wiped,—for it needed no French , but only a sentence from the universal language of looks on [my]0-i part , to indicate that it needed it,—we drew [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence , with [its]48-the st. lawrence parishes , thereon , and thenceforward went on swimmingly , by turns handling the chalk and committing to the table - cloth what would otherwise have been left in a limbo of unintelligibility . This was greatly to the entertainment of all parties . [I]0-i was amused to hear how much use [they]1344-the whole family made of the word _ oui _ in conversation with [one another]1750-one another . After repeated single insertions of it , one would suddenly throw back [his]146-chateau richer head at the same time with [his]146-chateau richer chair , and exclaim rapidly , “ _ oui ! oui ! oui ! oui ! _ ”[146-chateau richer] like [a Yankee driving pigs]1751-a yankee driving pigs . [[Our]1736-we host]1340-our host told [us]1736-we that the farms thereabouts were generally [two acres]1753-two acres , or three hundred and sixty French feet wide , by one and a half leagues , ( ? ) or a little more than four and a half of [our]1736-we miles deep . This use of the word _ acre _ as long measure arises from the fact that the French acre or arpent , [the arpent of [Paris]180-paris]1754-the arpent of paris , makes a square of ten perches , of eighteen feet each on a side , a [Paris]180-paris foot being equal to 1.06575 English feet . [He]146-chateau richer said that the wood was cut off about one mile from [the river]905-the river . The rest was “ bush , ”[146-chateau richer] and beyond that the “ [Queen]446-queen victoria ’s bush . ”[146-chateau richer] Old as [the country]750-the country is , [each landholder bounds on [the primitive forest]1691-the primitive forest]1757-each landholder bounds on the primitive forest , and fuel bears no price . As [I]0-i had forgotten [the French]416-the french for _ sickle _ , [they]416-the french went out in the evening to [the barn]1759-the barn and got one , and so clenched the certainty of [our]1736-we understanding one another . Then , wishing to learn if [they]416-the french used the cradle , and not knowing any French word for this instrument , [I]0-i set up the knives and forks on the blade of the sickle to represent one ; at which [they]416-the french all exclaimed that [they]416-the french knew and had used it . When _ snells _ were mentioned [they]416-the french went out in the dark and plucked some . [They]416-the french were pretty good . [They]416-the french said [they]416-the french had three kinds of plums growing wild,—blue , white , and red , [the two former much alike]1760-the two former much alike and the best . Also [they]416-the french asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i would have _ des pommes _ , some apples , and got [me]0-i some . [They]416-the french were exceedingly fair and glossy , and it was evident that there was no worm in [them]416-the french ; but [they]416-the french were as hard almost as a stone , as if the season was too short to mellow them . [We]1736-we had seen no soft and yellow apples by [the roadside]1480-the roadside . [I]0-i declined eating one , much as [I]0-i admired it , observing that it would be good _ dans le printemps _ , in the spring . In the morning when [the mistress]1762-the mistress had set the eggs a - frying [she]1762-the mistress nodded to a thick - set , jolly - looking fellow , who rolled up [his]1762-the mistress sleeves , seized the long - handled griddle , and commenced a series of revolutions and evolutions with it , ever and anon tossing its contents into the air , where [they]416-the french turned completely topsy - turvy and came down t ’ other side up ; and this [he]1762-the mistress repeated till [they]416-the french were done . That appeared to be [his]1762-the mistress duty when eggs were concerned . [I]0-i did not chance to witness this performance , but [[my]0-i companion]1747-my companion did , and [he]1747-my companion pronounced it a master - piece in its way . [[This man]1573-this man ’s farm]1765-this man ’s farm , with [the buildings]1766-the buildings , cost seven hundred pounds ; some smaller ones , two hundred .

In 1827 , [Montmorenci County]165-montmorenci county , to which the [Isle of Orleans]93-the isle of orleans has since been added , was nearly as large as [Massachusetts]12-massachusetts , being [the eighth county]1767-the eighth county out of forty ( in [Lower Canada]181-lower canada ) in extent ; but by far the greater part still must continue to be [waste land]1768-waste land , lying , as [it]1768-waste land were , under the walls of [Quebec]16-quebec .

[I]0-i quote these old statistics , not merely because of the difficulty of obtaining more recent ones , but also because [I]0-i saw there so little evidence of any recent growth . There were in [this county]1769-this county , at the same date , [five Roman Catholic churches]1770-five roman catholic churches , and [no others]1771-no others , five curés and five presbyteries , [two schools]1772-two schools , two corn - mills , [four saw - mills]1773-four saw - mills , [one carding - mill,—no medical man]1774-one carding - mill,—no medical man , or notary or [lawyer,—five shopkeepers]1775-lawyer,—five shopkeepers , [four taverns]1776-four taverns ( [we]1777-we saw no sign of any , though , after a little hesitation , [we]1777-we were sometimes directed to [some undistinguished hut]1778-some undistinguished hut as such ) , [thirty artisans]1779-thirty artisans , and five river crafts , whose tonnage amounted to sixty - nine tons ! This , notwithstanding that it has a frontage of more than thirty miles on [the river]905-the river , and [the population]1412-the population is almost wholly confined to [its]1412-the population banks . This describes nearly enough what [we]1777-we saw . But double some of these figures , which , however , its growth will not warrant , and [you]1782-you have described a poverty which not even its severity of climate and ruggedness of soil will suffice to account for . The principal productions were wheat , potatoes , oats , hay , peas , flax , maple - sugar , & c , & c. ; linen , cloth , or _ étoffe du pays _ , flannel , and homespun , or _ petite étoffe _ .

In [Lower Canada]181-lower canada , according to [Bouchette]450-bouchette , there are two tenures,—the feudal and the socage . [Tenanciers]1783-tenanciers , [censitaires]1784-censitaires , or holders of land _ en roture _ , pay a small annual rent to the seigneurs , to which “ is added some article of provision , such as a couple of fowls , or a goose , or a bushel of wheat . ”[450-bouchette] “ [They]1784-censitaires are also bound to grind [their]1784-censitaires corn at [the _ moulin banal _]5270-the _ moulin banal _ , or [[the lord]5271-the lord ’s mill]5272-the lord ’s mill , where one fourteenth part of it is taken for [his]1785-the seigneur use ”[450-bouchette] as toll . [He]450-bouchette says that the toll is one twelfth in [the United States]2-the united states , where competition exists . It is not permitted to exceed one sixteenth in [Massachusetts]12-massachusetts . But worse than this monopolizing of mill rents is what are called _ lods et ventes _ , or mutation fines . According to which [the seigneur]1785-the seigneur has “ a right to a twelfth part of the purchase - money of every estate within [his]1785-the seigneur seigniory that changes [its owner]5273-its owner by sale . ”[1785-the seigneur] This is over and above the sum paid to [the seller]1786-the seller . In such cases , moreover , “ [the lord]5271-the lord possesses the _ droit de retrait _ , which is the privilege of pre - emption at the highest bidden price within forty days after the sale has taken place,”—a[1785-the seigneur] right which , however , is said to be seldom exercised . “ Lands held by [Roman Catholics]471-roman catholics are further subject to the payment to [their]471-roman catholics curates of one twenty - sixth part of all the grain produced upon [them]471-roman catholics , and to occasional assessments for [building]5275-building and repairing churches , ”[1785-the seigneur] & c,—a tax to which [they]1787-they are not subject if [the proprietors]761-the proprietors change [their]1787-they faith ; but [they]1787-they are not the less attached to [[their]1787-they church]1789-their church in consequence . There are , however , various modifications of the feudal tenure . Under the socage tenure , which is that of [the townships or more recent settlements]1790-the townships or more recent settlements , English , Irish , Scotch , and others , and generally of [Canada West]149-canada west , [the landholder]1791-the landholder is wholly unshackled by such conditions as [I]0-i have quoted , and “ is bound to no other obligations than those of allegiance to [the king]1459-the king and obedience to the laws . ”[0-i] Throughout [Canada]1-canada “ a freehold of forty shillings yearly value , or the payment of ten pounds rent annually , is the qualification for [voters]5277-voters . ”[0-i] In 1846 more than [one sixth of [the whole population of [Canada East]148-canada east]1793-the whole population of canada east]1792-one sixth of the whole population of canada east were qualified to vote for members of [Parliament,—a]182-parliament,—a greater proportion than enjoy a similar privilege in [the United States]1794-the united states .

The population which [we]1795-we had seen the last two days,—I mean [the habitans of [Montmorenci]106-montmorenci]1796-the habitans of montmorenci County,—appeared very inferior , intellectually and even physically , to that of [New England]20-new england . In some respects [they]1796-the habitans of montmorenci were incredibly filthy . It was evident that [they]1796-the habitans of montmorenci had not advanced since [the settlement of [the country]750-the country]1797-the settlement of the country , that [they]1796-the habitans of montmorenci were quite behind the age , and fairly represented [[their]1796-the habitans of montmorenci ancestors]1799-their ancestors in [Normandy]145-normandy a thousand years ago . Even in respect to the common arts of life , [they]1796-the habitans of montmorenci are not so far advanced as [a frontier town in [the West]1801-the west three years old]1800-a frontier town in the west three years old . [They]1796-the habitans of montmorenci have no money invested in railroad stock , and probably never will have . If [they]1796-the habitans of montmorenci have got a French phrase for a railroad , it is as much as [you]1802-you can expect of [them]1796-the habitans of montmorenci . [They]1796-the habitans of montmorenci are very far from a revolution ; have no quarrel with [Church or State]1803-church or state , but [[their]1796-the habitans of montmorenci vice]1804-their vice and [their]1796-the habitans of montmorenci virtue is content . As for annexation , [they]1796-the habitans of montmorenci have never dreamed of it ; indeed , [they]1796-the habitans of montmorenci have not a clear idea what or where [the States]841-the states are . [The English government]1806-the english government has been remarkably liberal to its Catholic subjects in [Canada]1-canada , permitting [them]1796-the habitans of montmorenci to wear [their]1796-the habitans of montmorenci own fetters , both political and religious , as far as was possible for subjects . [Their]1796-the habitans of montmorenci government is even too good for [them]1796-the habitans of montmorenci . Parliament passed “ an act [ in 1825 ] to provide for the extinction of feudal and seigniorial rights and burdens on lands in [Lower Canada]181-lower canada , and for the gradual conversion of those tenures into the tenure of free and common socage , ”[1796-the habitans of montmorenci] & c. But as late as 1831 , at least , the design of the act was likely to be frustrated , owing to the reluctance of [the seigniors]1807-the seigniors and [peasants]1808-peasants . It has been observed by another that [the French Canadians]416-the french do not extend nor perpetuate [their]416-the french influence . [The British]472-the british , Irish , and [other immigrants]1809-other immigrants , who have settled [the townships]1810-the townships , are found to have imitated [the American settlers]1811-the american settlers , and not [the French]416-the french . [They]416-the french reminded [me]0-i in this of [the Indians]412-the indians , whom [they]416-the french were slow to displace and to whose habits of life [they]416-the french themselves more readily , conformed than [the Indians]412-the indians to [theirs]412-the indians .
