[The Governor General Denouville]473-the governor general denouville remarked , in 1685 , that [some]1812-some had long thought that it was necessary to bring [the Indians]412-the indians near [them]412-the indians in order to [Frenchify]183-frenchify ( _ franciser _ ) [them]412-the indians , but that [they]412-the indians had every reason to think [themselves]412-the indians in an error ; for [those who had come near [them]412-the indians and were even collected in [villages]1687-villages in the midst of [the colony]1815-the colony]1813-those who had come near them and were even collected in villages in the midst of the colony had not become French , but [the French , who had haunted [them]1816-the french , who had haunted them]1816-the french , who had haunted them , had become savages . [Kalm]425-kalm said : “ Though [many nations]5278-many nations imitate the French customs , yet [I]425-kalm observed , on the contrary , that [the French in [Canada]1-canada]5279-the french in canada , in many respects , follow the customs of [the Indians]5280-the indians , with whom [they]5280-the indians converse every day . [They]5280-the indians make use of the tobacco - pipes , shoes , garters , and girdles of [the Indians]412-the indians . [They]5280-the indians follow the Indian way of making war with exactness ; [they]5280-the indians mix the same things with tobacco ( [he]425-kalm might have said that [both French and English]5281-both french and english learned the use itself of this weed of the Indian ) ; [they]5280-the indians make use of [the Indian bark - boats]5282-the indian bark - boats , and row [them]5281-both french and english in the Indian way ; [they]5280-the indians wrap square pieces of cloth round [their]5280-the indians feet instead of stockings ; and have adopted many other Indian fashions . ”[425-kalm] Thus , while [the descendants of [the Pilgrims]1818-the pilgrims]1817-the descendants of the pilgrims are teaching [the English]1819-the english to make pegged boots , [the descendants of the French in [Canada]1-canada]1820-the descendants of the french in canada are wearing the Indian moccasin still . [The French]1821-the french , to [their]1820-the descendants of the french in canada credit be it said , to a certain extent respected [the Indians]412-the indians as [a separate and independent people]1822-a separate and independent people , and spoke of [them]412-the indians and contrasted [themselves]412-the indians with [them]412-the indians as [the English]1819-the english have never done . [They]412-the indians not only went to war with [them]412-the indians as [allies]1824-allies , but [they]412-the indians lived at [home]867-home with [them]412-the indians as [neighbors]1826-neighbors . In 1627 [the French king]1827-the french king declared “ that [the descendants of [the French]416-the french]5283-the descendants of the french , settled in ”[1827-the french king] [New France]86-new france , “ and [the savages who should be brought to the knowledge of the faith , and should make profession of it]5284-the savages who should be brought to the knowledge of the faith , and should make profession of it , should be counted and reputed French born ( _ Naturels François _ ) ; and as such could emigrate to [France]116-france , when it seemed good to [them]412-the indians , and there acquire , will , inherit , & c , & c , without obtaining letters of naturalization . ”[1827-the french king] When [the English]1819-the english had possession of [Quebec]16-quebec , in 1630 , [the Indians]412-the indians , attempting to practise the same familiarity with [them]412-the indians that [they]412-the indians had with [the French]416-the french , were driven out of [[their]412-the indians houses]1829-their houses with blows ; which accident taught [them]412-the indians a difference between the two races , and attached [them]412-the indians yet more to [the French]416-the french . The impression made on [me]0-i was , that [the French Canadians]1358-the french canadians were even sharing the fate of [the Indians]412-the indians , or at least gradually disappearing in what is called the Saxon current .

[The English]1819-the english did not come to [America]23-america from a mere love of adventure , nor to truck with or convert the savages , nor to hold offices under the crown , as [the French]1821-the french to a great extent did , but to live in earnest and with freedom . The latter overran [a great extent of [country]1834-country]1833-a great extent of country , selling strong water , and collecting its furs , and converting [its]1819-the english inhabitants,—or at least baptizing [its dying infants]1835-its dying infants ( _ enfans moribonds_),—without _ improving _ it . First , went the _ coureur de bois _ with the _ eau de vie _ ; then followed , if [he]1836-he did not precede , [the heroic missionary with the _ eau d’immortalité _]1837-the heroic missionary with the _ eau d’immortalité _ . It was freedom to hunt , and fish , and convert , not to work , that [they]1358-the french canadians sought . [Hontan]426-hontan says that the _ coureurs de bois _ lived like [sailors]5248-sailors ashore . In no part of the seventeenth century could [the French]416-the french be said to have had a foothold in [Canada]1-canada ; [they]1358-the french canadians held only by the fur of the wild animals which [they]1358-the french canadians were exterminating . To enable [the poor seigneurs]1839-the poor seigneurs to get [their]1839-the poor seigneurs living , it was permitted by a decree passed in the reign of [Louis the Fourteenth]474-louis the fourteenth , in 1685 , “ to all nobles and [gentlemen]5285-gentlemen settled in [Canada]1-canada , to engage in commerce , without being called to account or reputed to have done anything derogatory . ”[474-louis the fourteenth] [The reader]747-the reader can infer to what extent [they]1358-the french canadians had engaged in agriculture , and how [[their]1358-the french canadians farms]1841-their farms must have shone by this time . The [New England]20-new england youth , on the other hand , were never _ coureurs de bois _ nor _ voyageurs _ , but [backwoodsmen]1842-backwoodsmen and [sailors]5248-sailors rather . Of all nations the English undoubtedly have proved hitherto that [they]1358-the french canadians had the most business here .

Yet [I]0-i am not sure but [I]0-i have most sympathy with that spirit of adventure which distinguished [the French and Spaniards of those days]1844-the french and spaniards of those days , and made [them]1844-the french and spaniards of those days especially [the explorers of [the American Continent,—which]184-the american continent,—which]1845-the explorers of the american continent,—which so early carried the former to [the Great Lakes]185-the great lakes and [the Mississippi]186-the mississippi on the north , and the latter to [the same river on the south]1846-the same river on the south . It was long before [our]1847-our frontiers reached [[their]1845-the explorers of the american continent,—which settlements in [the West]187-the west]1848-their settlements in the west . So far as [inland discovery]1849-inland discovery was concerned , the adventurous spirit of the English was that of [sailors who land]1850-sailors who land but for a day , and [their]1850-sailors who land enterprise the enterprise of [traders]1851-traders .

There was apparently a greater equality of condition among [the habitans of [Montmorenci County]165-montmorenci county]1852-the habitans of montmorenci county than in [New England]20-new england . [They]1852-the habitans of montmorenci county are [an almost exclusively agricultural , and so far independent , population]1853-an almost exclusively agricultural , and so far independent , population , [each family]1854-each family producing nearly all the necessaries of life for itself . If [the Canadian]1855-the canadian wants energy , perchance [he]1855-the canadian possesses those virtues , social and others , which [the Yankee]882-the yankee lacks , in which case [he]1855-the canadian can not be regarded as [a poor man]1857-a poor man .

------------------------------------------------------------------------

CHAPTER IV .

[THE WALLS OF [QUEBEC]16-quebec]1858-the walls of quebec .

After spending the night at [a farm - house in [Chateau Richer]146-chateau richer]1859-a farm - house in chateau richer , about [a dozen miles northeast of [Quebec]16-quebec]1860-a dozen miles northeast of quebec , [we]1861-we set out on [our]1861-we return to [the city]903-the city . [We]1861-we stopped at [the next house]1863-the next house , [a picturesque old stone mill]1864-a picturesque old stone mill , over [the _ Chipré_,—for]1865-the _ chipré_,—for so the name sounded,—such as [you]1866-you will nowhere see in [the States]841-the states , and asked [the millers]1868-the millers the age of [the mill]1334-the mill . [They]1868-the millers went up stairs to call [the master]1870-the master ; but [the crabbed old miser]1871-the crabbed old miser asked why [we]1861-we wanted to know , and would tell [us]1861-we only for some compensation . [I]0-i wanted [French]416-the french to give [him]1871-the crabbed old miser a piece of [my]0-i mind . [I]0-i had got enough to talk on a pinch , but not to quarrel ; so [I]0-i had to come away , looking all [I]0-i would have said . This was the utmost incivility [we]1861-we met with in [Canada]1-canada . In [Beauport]115-beauport , within [a few miles of [Quebec]16-quebec]1872-a few miles of quebec , [we]1861-we turned aside to look at [a church which was just being completed,—a very large and handsome edifice of stone , with a green bough stuck in [its]1873-a church which was just being completed,—a very large and handsome edifice of stone , with a green bough stuck in its gable gable]1873-a church which was just being completed,—a very large and handsome edifice of stone , with a green bough stuck in its gable , of some significance to [Catholics]1874-catholics . The comparative wealth of [the Church in [this country]5239-this country]1875-the church in this country was apparent ; for in [this village]1877-this village [we]1861-we did not see [one good house]1878-one good house besides . [They]1879-they were [all humble cottages]1880-all humble cottages ; and yet this appeared to [me]0-i a more imposing structure than [any church in [Boston]8-boston]1881-any church in boston . But [I]0-i am [no judge of these things]1882-no judge of these things .

Re - entering [Quebec]16-quebec through [St. John ’s Gate]96-st. john ’s gate , [we]1861-we took a caleche in [Market Square]188-market square for [the Falls of [the Chaudière]189-the chaudière]1883-the falls of the chaudière , about nine miles southwest of [the city]903-the city , for which [we]1861-we were to pay so much , beside forty sous for tolls . [The driver]1055-the driver , as usual , spoke French only . The number of [these vehicles]1886-these vehicles is very great for so small [a town]783-a town . [They]1886-these vehicles are like one of [our]1861-we chaises that has lost its top , only stouter and longer in the body , with a seat for [the driver]1055-the driver where the dasher is with [us]1861-we , and broad leather ears on each side to protect [the riders]1889-the riders from the wheel and keep [children]1123-children from falling out . [They]1889-the riders had an easy jaunting look , which , as [our]1861-we hours were numbered , persuaded [us]1861-we to be [riders]1891-riders . [We]1861-we met with [them]1889-the riders on [every road near [Quebec]16-quebec]1892-every road near quebec these days , each with its complement of [two inquisitive - looking foreigners]1893-two inquisitive - looking foreigners and [a Canadian driver]1894-a canadian driver , the former evidently enjoying [their]1886-these vehicles novel experience , for commonly it is only the horse whose language [you]1895-you do not understand ; but [they]1896-they were one remove further from [him]1894-a canadian driver by the intervention of [an equally unintelligible driver]1897-an equally unintelligible driver . [We]1861-we crossed [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence to [Point Levi]190-point levi in [a French - Canadian ferry - boat]1898-a french - canadian ferry - boat , which was inconvenient and dirty , and managed with great noise and bustle . The current was very strong and tumultuous , and [the boat]942-the boat tossed enough to make some sick , though it was only a mile across ; yet the wind was not to be compared with that of the day before , and [we]1861-we saw that [the Canadians]1300-the canadians had a good excuse for not taking [us]1861-we over to [the Isle of Orleans]93-the isle of orleans in a pirogue , however shiftless [they]1300-the canadians may be for not having provided any other conveyance . The route which [we]1861-we took to the Chaudière did not afford [us]1861-we those views of [Quebec]16-quebec which [we]1861-we had expected , and [the country]750-the country and [inhabitants]1902-inhabitants appeared less interesting to [a traveller]1260-a traveller than those [we]1861-we had seen . [The Falls of [the Chaudière]189-the chaudière]1883-the falls of the chaudière are three miles from [its]1883-the falls of the chaudière mouth on [the south side of the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]1905-the south side of the st. lawrence . Though [they]1883-the falls of the chaudière were the largest which [I]0-i saw in [Canada]1-canada , [I]0-i was not proportionately interested by [them]1883-the falls of the chaudière , probably from satiety . [I]0-i did not see any _ peculiar _ propriety in the name _ Chaudière _ , or cauldron . [I]0-i saw here the most brilliant rainbow that [I]0-i ever imagined . It was just across [the stream below the precipice]1906-the stream below the precipice , formed on the mist which this tremendous fall produced ; and [I]0-i stood on a level with the key - stone of [its]1906-the stream below the precipice arch . It was not a few faint prismatic colors merely , but a full semicircle , only four or five rods in diameter , though as wide as usual , so intently bright as to pain the eye , and apparently as substantial as an arch of stone . It changed its position and colors as [we]1861-we moved , and was the brighter because the sun shone so clearly and the mist was so thick . Evidently a picture painted on mist for the men and animals that came to [the falls]1318-the falls to look at ; but for what special purpose beyond this , [I]0-i know not . At the farthest point in this ride , and when most inland , unexpectedly at a turn in [the road]1438-the road [we]1861-we descried [the frowning citadel of [Quebec]16-quebec]1909-the frowning citadel of quebec in the horizon , like the beak of a bird of prey . [We]1861-we returned by [the river - road under [the bank , which is very high , abrupt , and rocky]1911-the bank , which is very high , abrupt , and rocky]1910-the river - road under the bank , which is very high , abrupt , and rocky . When [we]1861-we were opposite to [Quebec]16-quebec , [I]0-i was surprised to see that in [the Lower Town]1129-the lower town , under the shadow of the rock , the lamps were lit , twinkling not unlike crystals in [a cavern]1913-a cavern , while the citadel high above , and [we]1861-we , too , on [the south shore]1914-the south shore , were in broad daylight . As [we]1861-we were too late for [the ferry - boat]1915-the ferry - boat that night , [we]1861-we put up at [a _ maison de pension _]1916-a _ maison de pension _ at [Point Levi]191-point levi . The usual two - story stove was here placed against an opening in the partition shaped like a fireplace , and so warmed [several rooms]1917-several rooms . [We]1861-we could not understand [their]1861-we French here very well , but the _ potage _ was just like what [we]1861-we had had before . There were [many small chambers with doorways]1918-many small chambers with doorways but no doors . The walls of [[our]1861-we chamber]1919-our chamber , all around and overhead , were neatly ceiled , and the timbers cased with wood unpainted . The pillows were checkered and tasselled , and the usual long - pointed red woollen or worsted night - cap was placed on each . [I]0-i pulled [mine]0-i out to see how it was made . It was in the form of a double cone , one end tucked into the other ; just such , it appeared , as [I]0-i saw [men]1028-men wearing all day in [the streets]995-the streets . Probably [I]0-i should have put it on if the cold had been then , as it is sometimes there , thirty or forty degrees below zero .

When [we]1861-we landed at [Quebec]16-quebec the next morning , [a man]1027-a man lay on [his]1027-a man back on [the wharf]919-the wharf , apparently dying , in the midst of a crowd and directly in the path of the horses , groaning , “ _ O ma conscience ! _ ”[1027-a man] [I]0-i thought that [he]1027-a man pronounced [his]1027-a man French more distinctly than any [I]0-i heard , as if [the dying]1924-the dying had already acquired the accents of a universal language . Having secured the only unengaged berths in [the Lord Sydenham steamer]1925-the lord sydenham steamer , which was to leave [Quebec]16-quebec before sundown , and being resolved , now that [I]0-i had seen somewhat of [the country]750-the country , to get an idea of [the city]903-the city , [I]0-i proceeded to walk round [the Upper Town]1116-the upper town , or fortified portion , which is two miles and three quarters in circuit , alone , as near as [I]0-i could get to [the cliff]1642-the cliff and the walls , like a rat looking for a hole ; going round by the southwest , where there is but [a single street between the cliff and [the water]797-the water , and up [the long , wooden stairs]1932-the long , wooden stairs , through [the suburbs]1933-the suburbs northward to [the King ’s Woodyard]1934-the king ’s woodyard , which [I]0-i thought must have been a long way from [his]1934-the king ’s woodyard fireplace , and under [the cliffs of [the St. Charles]110-st. charles]1935-the cliffs of the st. charles]1930-a single street between the cliff and the water , and up the long , wooden stairs , through the suburbs northward to the king ’s woodyard , which i thought must have been a long way from his fireplace , and under the cliffs of the st. charles , where the drains issue under the walls , and the walls are loop - holed for musketry ; so returning by [Mountain Street]193-mountain street and [Prescott Gate]89-prescott gate to [the Upper Town]1116-the upper town . Having found [my]0-i way by an obscure passage near [the St. Louis Gate]97-the st. louis gate to the glacis on the north of [the citadel]1128-the citadel proper,—I believe that [I]0-i was [the only visitor then in [the city]903-the city who got in there,—I enjoyed a prospect nearly as good as from within [the citadel itself , which [I]0-i had explored some days before]1940-the citadel itself , which i had explored some days before]1938-the only visitor then in the city who got in there,—i enjoyed a prospect nearly as good as from within the citadel itself , which i had explored some days before . As [I]0-i walked on the glacis [I]0-i heard the sound of a bagpipe from [[the soldiers]874-the soldiers ’ dwellings]1942-the soldiers ’ dwellings in the rock , and was further soothed and affected by the sight of [a soldier]1943-a soldier ’s cat walking up a cleeted plank into a high loop - hole , designed for _ mus - catry _ , as serene as Wisdom [herself]1944-her , and with a gracefully waving motion of [her]1944-her tail , as if [her]1944-her ways were ways of pleasantness and all [her]1944-her paths were peace . Scaling a slat fence , where a small force might have checked [me]0-i , [I]0-i got out of the esplanade into [the Governor ’s Garden]1945-the governor ’s garden , and read the well - known inscription on [Wolfe]475-wolfe and [Montcalm]476-montcalm ’s monument , which for saying much in little , and that to the purpose , undoubtedly deserved the prize medal which it received :

[MORTEM]477-mortem . [VIRTUS]478-virtus . COMMUNEM . FAMAM . HISTORIA . MONUMENTUM . POSTERITAS . DEDIT .

[Valor]479-valor gave [them]479-valor one death , history one fame , posterity one monument . [The Government Garden]1946-the government garden has for nose - gays , amid kitchen vegetables , beside the common garden flowers , the usual complement of cannon directed toward some future and [possible enemy]1947-possible enemy . [I]0-i then returned up [St. Louis Street]95-st. louis street to [the esplanade]1948-the esplanade and ramparts there , and went round [the Upper Town]1116-the upper town once more , though [I]0-i was very tired , this time on the _ inside _ of the wall ; for [I]0-i knew that the wall was the main thing in [Quebec]16-quebec , and had cost a great deal of money , and therefore [I]0-i must make the most of it . In fact , these are the only remarkable walls [we]1950-we have in [North America]63-north america , though [we]1950-we have a good deal of [Virginia]195-virginia fence , it is true . Moreover , [I]0-i can not say but [I]0-i yielded in some measure to [the soldier]1002-the soldier instinct , and , having but a short time to spare , thought it best to examine the wall thoroughly , that [I]0-i might be the better prepared if [I]0-i should ever be called that way again in the service of [[my]0-i country]1538-my country . [I]0-i committed all the gates to memory in [their]1953-their order , which did not cost [me]0-i so much trouble as it would have done at [the hundred - gated city]1954-the hundred - gated city , there being only five ; nor were [they]1953-their so hard to remember as [those seven of [Bœotian Thebes]196-bœotian thebes]1955-those seven of bœotian thebes ; and , moreover , [I]0-i thought that , if [seven champions]1956-seven champions were enough against the latter , [one]936-one would be enough against [Quebec]16-quebec , though [he]936-one bore for all armor and device only an umbrella and a bundle . [I]0-i took [the nunneries]1958-the nunneries as [I]0-i went , for [I]0-i had learned to distinguish [them]1958-the nunneries by the blinds ; and [I]0-i observed also [the foundling hospitals]1959-the foundling hospitals and [the convents]1960-the convents , and whatever was attached to , or in the vicinity of the walls . All the rest [I]0-i omitted , as naturally as one would the inside of an inedible shell - fish . These were the only pearls , and the wall the only mother - of - pearl for [me]0-i . [Quebec]16-quebec is chiefly famous for the thickness of its parietal bones . The technical terms of its conchology may stagger [a beginner]1961-a beginner a little at first , such as _ banlieue _ , _ esplanade _ , _ glacis _ , _ ravelin _ , _ cavalier _ , & c. , & c. , but with the aid of a comprehensive dictionary [you]1962-you soon learn the nature of [your]1962-you ground . [I]0-i was surprised at the extent of [the artillery barracks]1963-the artillery barracks , built so long ago,—_Casernes Nouvelles _ , [they]1963-the artillery barracks used to be called,—nearly six hundred feet in length by forty in depth , where the sentries , like [peripatetic philosophers]1964-peripatetic philosophers , were so absorbed in thought , as not to notice [me]0-i when [I]0-i passed in and out at the gates . Within , are “ small arms of every description , sufficient for the equipment of [twenty thousand men]5286-twenty thousand men , ”[1964-peripatetic philosophers] so arranged as to give a startling _ coup d’œil _ to [strangers]1965-strangers . [I]0-i did not enter , not wishing to get a black eye ; for [they]1963-the artillery barracks are said to be “ in a state of complete repair and readiness for immediate use . ”[1963-the artillery barracks] Here , for a short time , [I]0-i lost sight of the wall , but [I]0-i recovered it again on emerging from [the barrack yard]1966-the barrack yard . There [I]0-i met with [a Scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like [myself]0-i]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself ; and , being thus mutually drawn together by a similarity of tastes , [we]1968-we had a little conversation _ sub mœnibus _ , that is , by an angle of the wall which sheltered [us]1968-we . [He]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself lived about [thirty miles northwest of [Quebec]16-quebec]1969-thirty miles northwest of quebec ; had been nineteen years in [the country]750-the country ; said [he]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself was disappointed that [he]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself was not brought to [America]23-america after all , but found [himself]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself still under British rule and where [his]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself own language was not spoken ; that many Scotch , Irish , and English were disappointed in like manner , and either went to [the States]197-the states , or pushed up [the river]905-the river to [Canada West]149-canada west , nearer to [the States]841-the states , and where [their]841-the states language was spoken . [He]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself talked of visiting [the States]841-the states some time ; and , as [he]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself seemed ignorant of geography , [I]0-i warned [him]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself that it was one thing to visit [the State of Massachusetts]198-the state of massachusetts , and another to visit [the State of California]199-the state of california . [He]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself said it was colder there than usual at that season , and [he]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself was lucky to have brought [his]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself thick togue , or frock - coat , with [him]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself ; thought it would snow , and then be pleasant and warm . That is the way [we]1974-we are always thinking . However , [his]1967-a scotchman who appeared to have business with the wall , like myself words were music to [me]0-i in [my]0-i thin hat and sack .

At the ramparts on [the cliff]1642-the cliff near [the old Parliament House]1976-the old parliament house [I]0-i counted twenty - four thirty - two - pounders in a row , pointed over [the harbor]1131-the harbor , with [their]1978-their balls piled pyramid - wise between them,—there are said to be in all about one hundred and eighty guns mounted at [Quebec,—all]200-quebec,—all which were faithfully kept dusted by [officials]1979-officials , in accordance with the motto , “ In time of peace prepare for war ”[1980-she] ; but [I]0-i saw no preparations for peace : [she]1980-she was plainly [an uninvited guest]1981-an uninvited guest .

Having thus completed the circuit of [this fortress]1982-this fortress , both within and without , [I]0-i went no farther by the wall for fear that [I]0-i should become wall - eyed . However , [I]0-i think that [I]0-i deserve to be made [a member of [the Royal Sappers and Miners]1984-the royal sappers and miners]1983-a member of the royal sappers and miners .

In short , [I]0-i observed everywhere the most perfect arrangements for keeping a wall in order , not even permitting the lichens to grow on it , which some think an ornament ; but then [I]0-i saw no cultivation nor pasturing within it to pay for the outlay , and cattle were strictly forbidden to feed on the glacis under the severest penalties . Where the dogs get [their]1985-their milk [I]0-i do n’t know , and [I]0-i fear it is bloody at best .

[The citadel of [Quebec]16-quebec]1986-the citadel of quebec says , “ [I]0-i _ will _ live here , and [you]1987-you sha’n’t prevent [me]0-i . ”[0-i] To which [you]1987-you return , that [you]1987-you have not the slightest objection ; live and let live . [The Martello towers]1988-the martello towers looked , for all [the world]741-the world , exactly like abandoned wind - mills which had not had a grist to grind these hundred years . Indeed , [the whole castle]1990-the whole castle here was a “ folly,”—England[1992-the government] ’s folly,—and , in more senses than one , a castle in the air . [The inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants and [the government]1992-the government are gradually waking up to a sense of this truth ; for [I]0-i heard something said about [their]1006-the inhabitants abandoning the wall around [the Upper Town]1116-the upper town , and confining [the fortifications]1994-the fortifications to [the citadel of [forty acres]1996-forty acres]1995-the citadel of forty acres . Of course [they]1994-the fortifications will finally reduce [their]1994-the fortifications intrenchments to the circumference of [their]1994-the fortifications own brave hearts .

The most modern fortifications have an air of antiquity about [them]1994-the fortifications ; [they]1994-the fortifications have the aspect of ruins in better or worse repair from the day [they]1994-the fortifications are built , because [they]1994-the fortifications are not really the work of this age . The very place where [the soldier]1002-the soldier resides has a peculiar tendency to become old and dilapidated , as the word _ barrack _ implies . [I]0-i couple all fortifications in [my]0-i mind with [the dismantled Spanish forts]1998-the dismantled spanish forts to be found in so [many parts of [the world]741-the world]1999-many parts of the world ; and if in any place [they]1999-many parts of the world are not actually dismantled , it is because that there the intellect of [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants is dismantled . [The commanding officer of [an old fort near [Valdivia]201-valdivia in [South America]202-south america]2003-an old fort near valdivia in south america]2002-the commanding officer of an old fort near valdivia in south america , when [a traveller]1260-a traveller remarked to [him]2002-the commanding officer of an old fort near valdivia in south america that , with one discharge , [his]2002-the commanding officer of an old fort near valdivia in south america gun - carriages would certainly fall to pieces , gravely replied , “ No , [I]2002-the commanding officer of an old fort near valdivia in south america am sure , [sir]5242-sir , [they]5288-they would stand two . ”[2002-the commanding officer of an old fort near valdivia in south america] Perhaps the guns of [Quebec]16-quebec would stand three . [Such structures]2005-such structures carry [us]2006-us back to [the Middle Ages]1676-the middle ages , the siege of [Jerusalem]203-jerusalem , and [St. Jean]204-st. jean d’Acre , and the days of [the Buccaneers]2008-the buccaneers . In [the armory of [the citadel]1128-the citadel]2009-the armory of the citadel [they]2005-such structures showed [me]0-i a clumsy implement , long since useless , which [they]2005-such structures called a Lombard gun . [I]0-i thought that [[their]2005-such structures whole citadel]2011-their whole citadel was such a Lombard gun , fit object for the museums of the curious . Such works do not consist with the development of the intellect . Huge stone structures of all kinds , both in [their]2005-such structures erection and by [their]2005-such structures influence when erected , rather oppress than liberate the mind . [They]2005-such structures are tombs for the souls of [men]1028-men , as frequently for [their]2005-such structures bodies also . [The sentinel]2013-the sentinel with [his]2013-the sentinel musket beside [a man with [his]2013-the sentinel umbrella]2014-a man with his umbrella is spectral . There is not sufficient reason for [his]2013-the sentinel existence . Does [[my]0-i friend]2015-my friend there , with a bullet resting on half an ounce of powder , think that [he]2013-the sentinel needs that argument in conversing with [me]0-i ? [The fort]2016-the fort was [the first institution that was founded here]2017-the first institution that was founded here , and it is amusing to read in [Champlain]411-champlain how assiduously [they]2005-such structures worked at it almost from the first day of [the settlement]2018-the settlement . [The founders of [the colony]1815-the colony]2019-the founders of the colony thought this an excellent site for a wall,—and no doubt [it]2016-the fort was a better site , in some respects , for a wall than for a city,—but it chanced that [a city]916-a city got behind [it]2016-the fort . It chanced , too , that [a Lower Town]2022-a lower town got before it , and clung like an oyster to the outside of the crags , as [you]2023-you may see at low tide . It is as if [you]2023-you were to come to [a country village surrounded by palisades in [the old Indian]2025-the old indian]2024-a country village surrounded by palisades in the old indian fashion,—interesting only as a relic of antiquity and barbarism . [A fortified town]2026-a fortified town is like a man cased in the heavy armor of antiquity , with a horse - load of broadswords and small arms slung to [him]2026-a fortified town , endeavoring to go about [his]2026-a fortified town business . Or is this an indispensable machinery for [the good government of [the country]750-the country]2027-the good government of the country ? [The inhabitants of [California]205-california]2029-the inhabitants of california succeed pretty well , and are doing better and better every day , without any such institution . What use has [this fortress]1982-this fortress served , to look at it even from [the soldiers]874-the soldiers ’ point of view ? At first [the French]416-the french took care of it ; yet [Wolfe]475-wolfe sailed by it with impunity , and took [the town of Quebec]2032-the town of quebec without experiencing any hindrance at last from [its]2032-the town of quebec fortifications . [They]2029-the inhabitants of california were only the bone for which [the parties]2033-the parties fought . Then [the English]1819-the english began to take care of [it]1819-the english . So of [any fort in [the world,—that in [Boston]8-boston harbor]2036-the world,—that in boston harbor]2035-any fort in the world,—that in boston harbor , for instance . [We]2037-we shall at length hear that [an enemy]2038-an enemy sailed by it in the night , for it can not sail itself , and both it and [[its]2038-an enemy inhabitants]2039-its inhabitants are always benighted . How often [we]2037-we read that [the enemy]2040-the enemy occupied a position which commanded the old , and so [the fort]2016-the fort was evacuated . Have not [the school - house]2042-the school - house and the printing - press occupied a position which commands such [a fort]2043-a fort as this ?

However , this is a ruin kept in remarkably good repair . There are [some eight hundred or thousand men there to exhibit it]2044-some eight hundred or thousand men there to exhibit it . [One regiment]2045-one regiment goes bare - legged to increase the attraction . If [you]2046-you wish to study the muscles of the leg about the knee , repair to [Quebec]16-quebec . This universal exhibition in [Canada]1-canada of the tools and sinews of war reminded [me]0-i of the keeper of [a menagerie]2047-a menagerie showing [his]2047-a menagerie animals ’ claws . It was the English leopard showing [his]2047-a menagerie claws . Always the _ royal _ something or other ; as , at [the menagerie]2048-the menagerie , [the Royal Bengal Tiger]481-the royal bengal tiger . [Silliman]482-silliman states that “ the cold is so intense in the winter nights , particularly on [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond , that the sentinels can not stand it more than one hour , and are relieved at the expiration of that time ”[482-silliman] ; “ and even , as it is said , at much shorter intervals , in case of the most extreme cold . ”[482-silliman] What [a natural or unnatural fool]2049-a natural or unnatural fool must [that soldier]2050-that soldier be,—to say nothing of [his]2050-that soldier government,—who , when quicksilver is freezing and blood is ceasing to be quick , will stand to have [his]2050-that soldier face frozen , watching the walls of [Quebec]16-quebec , though , so far as [they]2051-they are concerned , both honest and [dishonest men]2052-dishonest men all [the world]741-the world over have been in [[their]2052-dishonest men beds]2054-their beds nearly half a century,—or at least for that space [travellers]1353-travellers have visited [Quebec]16-quebec only as [they]1353-travellers would read history . [I]0-i shall never again wake up in a colder night than usual , but [I]0-i shall think how rapidly [the sentinels]2056-the sentinels are relieving one another on [the walls of [Quebec]16-quebec]1858-the walls of quebec , [their]2056-the sentinels quicksilver being all frozen , as if apprehensive that [some hostile Wolfe]2058-some hostile wolfe may even then be scaling [the Heights of [Abraham]84-abraham]2059-the heights of abraham , or some persevering [Arnold]483-arnold about to issue from [the wilderness]1462-the wilderness ; [some Malay or Japanese]2061-some malay or japanese , perchance , coming round by [the northwest coast]2062-the northwest coast , have chosen that moment to assault [the citadel]1128-the citadel ! Why [I]0-i should as soon expect to find [the sentinels]2056-the sentinels still relieving one another on the walls of [Nineveh]206-nineveh , which have so long been buried to [the world]741-the world ! What a troublesome thing a wall is ! [I]0-i thought it was to defend [me]0-i , and not [I]0-i it . Of course , if [they]2056-the sentinels had no wall [they]2056-the sentinels would not need to have any sentinels .

[You]2066-you might venture to advertise [this farm]2067-this farm as well fenced with substantial stone walls ( saying nothing about [the eight hundred Highlanders and Royal Irish who are required to keep them from toppling down]2068-the eight hundred highlanders and royal irish who are required to keep them from toppling down ) ; stock and tools to go with [the land]834-the land if desired . But it would not be wise for [the seller]1786-the seller to exhibit [his]1786-the seller farm - book .

Why should [Canada]1-canada , wild and unsettled as it is , impress [us]2071-us as [an older country]2072-an older country than [the States]841-the states , unless because [[her]2074-her institutions]2075-her institutions are old ? All things appeared to contend there , as [I]0-i have implied , with a certain rust of antiquity,—such as forms on old armor and iron guns,—the rust of conventions and formalities . It is said that the metallic roofs of [Montreal]15-montreal and [Quebec]16-quebec keep sound and bright for forty years in some cases . But if the rust was not on the tinned roofs and spires , it was on [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants and [[their]1006-the inhabitants institutions]2077-their institutions . Yet the work of burnishing goes briskly forward . [I]0-i imagined that [the government vessels at the wharves]2078-the government vessels at the wharves were laden with rotten - stone and oxalic acid,—that is what [the first ship from [England]31-england in the spring]2079-the first ship from england in the spring comes freighted with,—and the hands of [the colonial legislature]2080-the colonial legislature are cased in wash - leather . The principal exports must be _ gun_ny bags , verdigrease , and iron rust . [Those who first built [this fort]2082-this fort , coming from [Old France]207-old france with the memory and tradition of feudal days and customs weighing on [them]2081-those who first built this fort , coming from old france with the memory and tradition of feudal days and customs weighing on them]2081-those who first built this fort , coming from old france with the memory and tradition of feudal days and customs weighing on them , were unquestionably behind [their]2081-those who first built this fort , coming from old france with the memory and tradition of feudal days and customs weighing on them age ; and [those who now inhabit and repair it]2083-those who now inhabit and repair it are behind [[their]2083-those who now inhabit and repair it ancestors or [predecessors]2085-predecessors]2084-their ancestors or predecessors . [Those old chevaliers]2086-those old chevaliers thought that [they]2086-those old chevaliers could transplant the feudal system to [America]23-america . It has been set out , but it has not thriven . Notwithstanding that [Canada]1-canada was settled first , and , unlike [New England]20-new england , for a long series of years enjoyed the fostering care of the mother country,—notwithstanding that , as [Charlevoix]440-charlevoix tells [us]2087-us , it had more of the ancient _ noblesse _ among [its early settlers]2088-its early settlers than [any other of [the French colonies]2090-the french colonies]2089-any other of the french colonies , and perhaps than all the others together,—there are in both [the Canadas]133-the canadas but 600,000 of French descent to - day,—about half so many as [the population of [Massachusetts]12-massachusetts]2091-the population of massachusetts . [The whole population of [both Canadas]2093-both canadas]2092-the whole population of both canadas is but about 1,700,000 Canadians , English , Irish , Scotch , [Indians]2094-indians , and all , put together ! [Samuel Laing]484-samuel laing , in [his]484-samuel laing essay on [the Northmen]2095-the northmen , to whom especially , rather than [the Saxons]485-the saxons , [he]484-samuel laing refers the energy and indeed the excellence of the English character , observes that , when [they]2096-they occupied [Scandinavia]208-scandinavia , “ [each man]1022-each man possessed [his]484-samuel laing lot of land without reference to , or acknowledgment of , [any other man,—without [any local chief to whom [his]5290-any other man,—without any local chief to whom his military service or other quit - rent for his land military service]5291-any local chief to whom his military service or other quit - rent for [[his]5290-any other man,—without any local chief to whom his military service or other quit - rent for his land land]5292-his land]5290-any other man,—without any local chief to whom his military service or other quit - rent for his land was due,—without tenure from , or duty or obligation to , any superior , real or fictitious , except [the general sovereign]5293-the general sovereign . [The individual settler]5294-the individual settler held [[his]5294-the individual settler land]5292-his land , as [[his]5294-the individual settler descendants in [Norway]209-norway]5296-his descendants in norway still express it , by the same right as [the king]1459-the king held [his]1459-the king crown,—by udal right , or adel,—that is , noble right . ”[484-samuel laing] [The French]1821-the french have occupied [Canada]1-canada , not _ udally _ , or by noble right , but _ feudally _ , or by ignoble right . [They]1821-the french are [a nation of [peasants]1808-peasants]2098-a nation of peasants .

It was evident that , both on account of the feudal system and [the aristocratic government]2100-the aristocratic government , [a private man]2101-a private man was not worth so much in [Canada]1-canada as in [the United States]1794-the united states ; and , if [your]2103-your wealth in any measure consists in manliness , in originality , and independence , [you]2103-your had better stay [here]820-here . How could [a peaceable , freethinking man]2105-a peaceable , freethinking man live [neighbor]2106-neighbor to [the Forty - ninth Regiment]2107-the forty - ninth regiment ? [A New - Englander]486-a new - englander would naturally be [a bad citizen]2108-a bad citizen , probably [a rebel]2109-a rebel , there,—certainly if [he]2109-a rebel were already [a rebel]2109-a rebel at [home]867-home . [I]0-i suspect that [a poor man who is not servile is a much rarer phenomenon there]2112-a poor man who is not servile is a much rarer phenomenon there and in [England]31-england than in [the Northern United States]210-the northern united states . [An Englishman]2113-an englishman , [methinks,—not]2114-methinks,—not to speak of other European nations,—habitually regards [himself]2113-an englishman merely as [a constituent part of [the English nation]2116-the english nation]2115-a constituent part of the english nation ; [he]2113-an englishman is [a member of [the royal regiment of Englishmen]2118-the royal regiment of englishmen]2117-a member of the royal regiment of englishmen , and is proud of [his]2113-an englishman company , as [he]2113-an englishman has reason to be proud of it . But an American,—one who has made a tolerable use of [his]2113-an englishman opportunities,—cares , comparatively , little about such things , and is advantageously nearer to the primitive and the ultimate condition of [man]2119-man in these respects . It is a government , that English one,—like [most other European ones,—that]2120-most other european ones,—that can not afford to be forgotten , as [you]2121-you would naturally forget it ; under which one can not be wholesomely neglected , and grow up [a man]1027-a man and not [an Englishman]2113-an englishman merely,—cannot be [a poet]2124-a poet even without danger of being made [poet - laureate]2125-poet - laureate ! Give [me]0-i [a country where it is the most natural thing in [the world]741-the world for a government that does not understand [you]2128-you to let [you]2128-you alone]2126-a country where it is the most natural thing in the world for a government that does not understand you to let you alone . [One]936-one would say that [a true Englishman]2130-a true englishman could speculate only within bounds . ( It is true [the Americans]2131-the americans have proved that [they]2131-the americans , in more than one sense , can _ speculate _ without bounds . ) [He]2113-an englishman has to pay [his]2113-an englishman respects to so many things , that , before [he]2113-an englishman knows it , [he]2113-an englishman _ may _ have paid away all [he]2113-an englishman is worth . What makes [the United States government]2132-the united states government , on the whole , more tolerable,—I mean for [us]2133-us lucky white men,—is the fact that there is so much less of government with [us]2133-us . Here it is only once in a month or a year that [a man]1027-a man _ needs _ remember [that institution]2135-that institution ; and those who go to [Congress]526-congress can play the game of the [Kilkenny]212-kilkenny cats there without fatal consequences to [those who stay at home,—their term]2136-those who stay at home,—their term is so short : but in [Canada]1-canada [you]2137-you are reminded of [the government]1992-the government every day . It parades itself before [you]2137-you . It is not content to be [the servant]2139-the servant , but will be [the master]1870-the master ; and every day it goes out to [the Plains of Abraham]1161-the plains of abraham or to the [Champ de Mars]66-champ de mars and exhibits itself and [its]66-champ de mars tools . Everywhere there appeared an attempt to make and to preserve trivial and otherwise transient distinctions . In [the streets of [Montreal]15-montreal and [Quebec]16-quebec]2142-the streets of montreal and quebec [you]2137-you met not only with [soldiers]1016-soldiers in red , and shuffling priests in unmistakable black and white , with [Sisters of Charity]2144-sisters of charity gone into mourning for [[their]2144-sisters of charity deceased relative,—not]2145-their deceased relative,—not to mention [the nuns of various orders depending on the fashion of a tear , of whom [you]2137-you heard,—but youths belonging to [some seminary]2147-some seminary or other , wearing coats edged with white , who looked as if [their]2144-sisters of charity expanding hearts were already repressed with a piece of tape]2146-the nuns of various orders depending on the fashion of a tear , of whom you heard,—but youths belonging to some seminary or other , wearing coats edged with white , who looked as if their expanding hearts were already repressed with a piece of tape . In short , [the inhabitants of [Canada]1-canada]2148-the inhabitants of canada appeared to be suffering between two fires,—the soldiery and [the priesthood]2149-the priesthood .

------------------------------------------------------------------------

CHAPTER V.

[THE SCENERY OF [QUEBEC]16-quebec]213-the scenery of quebec ; AND [THE RIVER ST . LAWRENCE]214-the river st . lawrence .

About twelve o’clock this day , being in [the Lower Town]1129-the lower town , [I]0-i looked up at the signal - gun by [the flag - staff on [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond]2151-the flag - staff on cape diamond , and saw [a soldier]1943-a soldier up in the heavens there making preparations to fire it,—both [he]1943-a soldier and the gun in bold relief against the sky . Soon after , being warned by the boom of the gun to look up again , there was only the cannon in the sky , the smoke just blowing away from it , as if [the soldier]1002-the soldier , having touched it off , had concealed [himself]1002-the soldier for effect , leaving the sound to echo grandly from [shore]2154-shore to [shore]2154-shore , and far up and down [the river]905-the river . This answered the purpose of a dinner - horn .

There are no such restaurateurs in [Quebec]16-quebec or [Montreal]15-montreal as there are in [Boston]8-boston . [I]0-i hunted an hour or two in vain in [this town]758-this town to find one , till [I]0-i lost [my]0-i appetite . In [one house]1339-one house , called a restaurateur , where lunches were advertised , [I]0-i found only tables covered with bottles and glasses innumerable , containing apparently a sample of every liquid that has been known since [the earth]1074-the earth dried up after the flood , but no scent of solid food did [I]0-i perceive gross enough to excite a hungry mouse . In short , [I]0-i saw nothing to tempt [me]0-i there , but a large map of [Canada]1-canada against the wall . In another place [I]0-i once more got as far as the bottles , and then asked for a bill of fare ; was told to walk [up stairs]2160-up stairs ; had no bill of fare , nothing but fare . “ Have [you]5298-you any pies or puddings ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i inquired , for [I]0-i am obliged to keep [my]0-i savageness in check by a low diet . “ No , [sir]5242-sir ; [we]5300-we ’ve nice mutton - chop , roast beef , beef - steak , cutlets , ”[0-i] and so on . [A burly Englishman , who was in the midst of the siege of a piece of roast beef , and of whom [I]0-i have never had a front view to this day]2161-a burly englishman , who was in the midst of the siege of a piece of roast beef , and of whom i have never had a front view to this day , turned half round , with [his]2161-a burly englishman , who was in the midst of the siege of a piece of roast beef , and of whom i have never had a front view to this day mouth half full , and remarked , “ [You]2161-a burly englishman , who was in the midst of the siege of a piece of roast beef , and of whom i have never had a front view to this day ’ll find no pies nor puddings in [Quebec]16-quebec , [sir]5242-sir ; [they]2162-the old women do n’t make any here . ”[2161-a burly englishman , who was in the midst of the siege of a piece of roast beef , and of whom i have never had a front view to this day] [I]0-i found that it was even so , and therefore bought some musty cake and some fruit in the open market - place . This market - place by the water - side , where [the old women]2162-the old women sat by [their]2162-the old women tables in the open air , amid a dense crowd jabbering all languages , was the best place in [Quebec]16-quebec to observe [the people]1562-the people ; and [the ferry - boats]2164-the ferry - boats , continually coming and going with [[their]2164-the ferry - boats motley crews and cargoes]2165-their motley crews and cargoes , added much to the entertainment . [I]0-i also saw [them]2164-the ferry - boats getting water from [the river]905-the river , for [Quebec]16-quebec is supplied with water by cart and barrel . [This city]913-this city impressed [me]0-i as wholly foreign and French , for [I]0-i scarcely heard the sound of the English language in [the streets]995-the streets . [More than three fifths of [the inhabitants]1006-the inhabitants]2169-more than three fifths of the inhabitants are of French origin ; and if [the traveller]755-the traveller did not visit [the fortifications]1994-the fortifications particularly , [he]755-the traveller might not be reminded that [the English]1819-the english have any foothold here ; and , in any case , if [he]755-the traveller looked no farther than [Quebec]16-quebec , [they]2169-more than three fifths of the inhabitants would appear to have planted [themselves]2169-more than three fifths of the inhabitants in [Canada]1-canada only as [they]2169-more than three fifths of the inhabitants have in [Spain]215-spain at [Gibraltar]101-gibraltar ; and [he]755-the traveller who plants upon a rock can not expect much increase . The novel sights and sounds by the water - side made [me]0-i think of such ports as [Boulogne]216-boulogne , [Dieppe]488-dieppe , [Rouen]217-rouen , and [Havre de Grace]218-havre de grace , which [I]0-i have never seen ; but [I]0-i have no doubt that [they]2169-more than three fifths of the inhabitants present similar scenes . [I]0-i was much amused from first to last with the sounds made by [the charette and caleche drivers]2174-the charette and caleche drivers . It was that part of [their]2174-the charette and caleche drivers foreign language that [you]2175-you heard the most of,—the French [they]2174-the charette and caleche drivers talked to [their]2174-the charette and caleche drivers horses,—and which [they]2174-the charette and caleche drivers talked the loudest . It was a more novel sound to [me]0-i than the French of conversation . [The streets]995-the streets resounded with the cries , _ “ Qui donc ! _ ”[0-i] “ _ March tôt ! _ ”[0-i] [I]0-i suspect that many of [our]2177-our horses which came from [Canada]1-canada would prick up [their]2169-more than three fifths of the inhabitants ears at these sounds . Of [the shops]2178-the shops , [I]0-i was most attracted by those where furs and Indian works were sold , as containing articles of genuine Canadian manufacture . [I]0-i have been told that [two townsmen of mine]2179-two townsmen of mine , who were interested in horticulture , travelling once in [Canada]1-canada , and being in [Quebec]16-quebec , thought it would be a good opportunity to obtain seeds of the real [Canada]1-canada crook - neck squash . So [they]2174-the charette and caleche drivers went into [a shop]2180-a shop where such things were advertised , and inquired for the same . [The shopkeeper]2181-the shopkeeper had the very thing [they]2174-the charette and caleche drivers wanted . “ But are [you]2181-the shopkeeper sure , ”[2174-the charette and caleche drivers] [they]2174-the charette and caleche drivers asked , “ that these are [the genuine Canada crook - neck]5302-the genuine canada crook - neck ? ”[2174-the charette and caleche drivers] “ O yes , [gentlemen , ”]5303-gentlemen , ”[2181-the shopkeeper] answered [he]2181-the shopkeeper , “ [they]2174-the charette and caleche drivers are a lot which [I]2181-the shopkeeper have received directly from [Boston]8-boston . ”[2181-the shopkeeper] [I]0-i resolved that [my]0-i Canada crook - neck seeds should be such as had grown in [Canada]1-canada .

Too much has not been said about [the scenery of [Quebec]16-quebec]2182-the scenery of quebec . [The fortifications of [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond]2183-the fortifications of cape diamond are omnipresent . [They]2183-the fortifications of cape diamond preside , [they]2183-the fortifications of cape diamond frown over [the river and surrounding country]1132-the river and surrounding country . [You]2185-you travel ten , twenty , thirty miles up or down [the river]905-the river ’s banks , [you]2185-you ramble fifteen miles amid [the hills]2187-the hills on either side , and then , when [you]2185-you have long since forgotten [them]2183-the fortifications of cape diamond , perchance slept on [them]2183-the fortifications of cape diamond by the way , at a turn of [the road]1438-the road or of [your]2185-you body , there [they]2183-the fortifications of cape diamond are still , with [their]2183-the fortifications of cape diamond geometry against the sky . [The child that is born]2189-the child that is born and brought up thirty miles distant , and has never travelled to [the city]903-the city , reads [[his]2189-the child that is born country]2191-his country ’s history , sees the level lines of the citadel amid the cloud - built citadels in the western horizon , and is told that that is [Quebec]16-quebec . No wonder if [[Jacques Cartier]410-cartier ’s pilot]2192-jacques cartier ’s pilot exclaimed in [Norman French]219-norman french , _ Que bec!_—“What a beak!”—when[410-cartier] [he]410-cartier saw this cape , as [some suppose]2193-some suppose . [Every modern traveller]2194-every modern traveller involuntarily uses a similar expression . Particularly it is said that its sudden apparition on turning Point [Levi]190-point levi makes a memorable impression on [him]190-point levi who arrives by water . The view from [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond has been compared by [European travellers]2195-european travellers with the most remarkable views of a similar kind in [Europe]135-europe , such as from [Edinburgh Castle]102-edinburgh castle , [Gibraltar]101-gibraltar , [Cintra]490-cintra , and others , and preferred by many . A main peculiarity in this , compared with other views which [I]0-i have beheld , is that it is from [the ramparts of [a fortified city]2197-a fortified city]2196-the ramparts of a fortified city , and not from [a solitary and majestic river cape alone that this view is obtained]2198-a solitary and majestic river cape alone that this view is obtained . [I]0-i associate [the beauty of [Quebec]16-quebec with the steel - like and flashing air , which may be peculiar to that season of the year , in which the blue flowers of the succory and some late golden - rods and buttercups on [the summit of [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond]1210-the summit of cape diamond]2199-the beauty of quebec with the steel - like and flashing air , which may be peculiar to that season of the year , in which the blue flowers of the succory and some late golden - rods and buttercups on the summit of cape diamond were almost [my]0-i only companions,—the former bluer than the heavens [they]2201-they faced . Yet even [I]0-i yielded in some degree to the influence of historical associations , and found it hard to attend to the geology of [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond or the botany of [the Plains of [Abraham]84-abraham]1161-the plains of abraham . [I]0-i still remember [the harbor far beneath [me]0-i , sparkling like silver in the sun,—the answering highlands of [Point Levi]191-point levi on the southeast,—the frowning [Cap Tourmente]221-cap tourmente abruptly bounding the seaward view far in [the northeast,—the villages of [Lorette]222-lorette]2204-the northeast,—the villages of lorette and [Charlesbourg]223-charlesbourg]2203-the harbor far beneath me , sparkling like silver in the sun,—the answering highlands of point levi on the southeast,—the frowning cap tourmente abruptly bounding the seaward view far in the northeast,—the villages of lorette and charlesbourg on the north,—and further west [the distant Val Cartier , sparkling with white cottages , hardly removed by distance through the clear air,—not]2205-the distant val cartier , sparkling with white cottages , hardly removed by distance through the clear air,—not to mention a few blue mountains along the horizon in that direction . [You]2206-you look out from the ramparts of [the citadel beyond [the frontiers of civilization]2208-the frontiers of civilization]2207-the citadel beyond the frontiers of civilization . [Yonder]224-yonder small group of hills , according to the guide - book , forms “ the portal of the wilds which are trodden only by the feet of [the Indian hunters]5304-the indian hunters as far as [Hudson ’s Bay]143-hudson ’s bay . ”[450-bouchette] It is but a few years since [Bouchette]450-bouchette declared that [the country ten leagues north of [the British capital of North America]2210-the british capital of north america]2209-the country ten leagues north of the british capital of north america was as little known as [the middle of [Africa]225-africa]2211-the middle of africa . Thus the citadel under [my]0-i feet , and all historical associations , were swept away again by an influence from the wilds and from nature , as if [the beholder]2212-the beholder had read [her]2212-the beholder history,—an influence which , like the Great River itself , flowed from [the Arctic fastnesses and Western forests]2213-the arctic fastnesses and western forests with irresistible tide over all .

The most interesting object in [Canada]1-canada to [me]0-i was [the River St. Lawrence]226-the river st. lawrence , known far and wide , and for centuries , as [the Great River]2214-the great river . [Cartier]410-cartier , [[its]410-cartier discoverer]2215-its discoverer , sailed up it as far as [Montreal]15-montreal in 1535,—nearly a century before the coming of [the Pilgrims]1818-the pilgrims ; and [I]0-i have seen a pretty accurate map of it so far , containing [the city of “ [Hochelaga]227-hochelaga ”[0-i] and [the river “ Saguenay]5306-the river “ saguenay]5305-the city of “ hochelaga ” and the river “ saguenay , ”[0-i] in [Ortelius]228-ortelius ’s _ [Theatrum Orbis Terrarum _]229-theatrum orbis terrarum _ , printed at [Antwerp]230-antwerp in 1575,—the first edition having appeared in 1570,—in which the famous [cities of “ Norumbega ”]5307-cities of “ norumbega ”[0-i] and “ [Orsinora]491-orsinora ”[0-i] stand on [the rough - blocked continent]2217-the rough - blocked continent where [New England]20-new england is to - day , and the fabulous but unfortunate [Isle of Demons]231-isle of demons , and [Frislant]492-frislant , and [others]985-others , lie off and on in [the unfrequented sea]2219-the unfrequented sea , some of [them]2220-them prowling near what is now the course of [the Cunard]232-the cunard steamers . In this ponderous folio of the “ Ptolemy of [his]48-the st. lawrence age , ”[492-frislant] said to be the first general atlas published after the revival of the sciences in [Europe]135-europe , only one page of which is devoted to the topography of [the _ Novus Orbis]233-the _ novus orbis _ , the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence is [the only large river , whether drawn from fancy or from observation]2221-the only large river , whether drawn from fancy or from observation , on [the east side of [North America]63-north america]2222-the east side of north america . It was famous in [Europe]135-europe before [the other rivers of [North America]63-north america]2223-the other rivers of north america were heard of , notwithstanding that [the mouth of [the Mississippi]186-the mississippi]2224-the mouth of the mississippi is said to have been discovered first , and [its]2224-the mouth of the mississippi stream was reached by [Soto]493-soto not long after ; but [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence had attracted [settlers]2225-settlers to [[its]2224-the mouth of the mississippi cold shores]2226-its cold shores long before [the Mississippi]186-the mississippi , or even [the Hudson]234-the hudson , was known to [the world]741-the world . [Schoolcraft]494-schoolcraft was misled by [Gallatin]495-gallatin into saying that [Narvaez]496-narvaez discovered [the Mississippi]186-the mississippi . [De Vega]497-de vega does _ not _ say so . [The first explorers]2228-the first explorers declared that the summer in [that country]2229-that country was as warm as [France]116-france , and [they]2228-the first explorers named one of [the bays in [the Gulf of [St. Lawrence the Bay of Chaleur]236-st. lawrence the bay of chaleur]2231-the gulf of st. lawrence the bay of chaleur]2230-the bays in the gulf of st. lawrence the bay of chaleur , or of warmth ; but [they]2228-the first explorers said nothing about the winter being as cold as [Greenland]237-greenland . In the manuscript account of [Cartier]410-cartier ’s second voyage , attributed by some to [that navigator]2232-that navigator [himself]2232-that navigator , it is called “ [the greatest river]5308-the greatest river , without comparison , that is known to have ever been seen . ”[2233-the savages] [The savages]2233-the savages told [him]2232-that navigator that it was [the “ _ chemin du Canada_,”—the[2233-the savages] highway to [Canada,—“which]238-canada,—“which]5309-the “ _ chemin du canada_,”—the highway to canada,—“which goes so far that [no man]5310-no man had ever been to the end that [they]2233-the savages had heard . ”[2233-the savages] [The Saguenay]154-the saguenay , one of [[its]154-the saguenay tributaries , which [the panorama]2235-the panorama has made known to [New England]20-new england]2234-its tributaries , which the panorama has made known to new england within three years , is described by [Cartier]410-cartier , in 1535 , and still more particularly by [Jean Alphonse]448-jean alphonse , in 1542 , who adds , “ [I]448-jean alphonse think that [this river]1085-this river comes from [the sea of Cathay]5312-the sea of cathay , for in [this place]5313-this place there issues a strong current , and there runs there a terrible tide . ”[448-jean alphonse] [The early explorers]2236-the early explorers saw many whales and other sea - monsters far up [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence . [Champlain]411-champlain , in [his]2232-that navigator map , represents a whale spouting in [the harbor of [Quebec]16-quebec]1099-the harbor of quebec , three hundred and sixty miles from what is called [the mouth of [the river]905-the river]2238-the mouth of the river ; and [Charlevoix]440-charlevoix takes [his]2232-that navigator reader to [the summit of [Cape Diamond]85-cape diamond]1210-the summit of cape diamond to see the “ porpoises , white as snow , ”[498-boucher] sporting on the surface of [the harbor of [Quebec]16-quebec]1099-the harbor of quebec . And [Boucher]498-boucher says in 1664 , “ from there ( [Tadoussac]239-tadoussac ) to [Montreal]15-montreal is found a great quantity of _ Marsouins blancs _ . ”[498-boucher] Several whales have been taken pretty high up [the river]905-the river since [I]0-i was there . [P. A. Gosse]499-p. a. gosse , in [his]2232-that navigator “ Canadian Naturalist , ”[499-p. a. gosse] p. 171 ( [London]240-london , 1840 ) , speaks of “ the white dolphin of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence ( _ Delphinus Canadensis _ ) , ”[2232-that navigator] as considered different from those of [the sea]2243-the sea . “ [The Natural History Society of [Montreal]15-montreal]5314-the natural history society of montreal offered a prize , a few years ago , for an essay on the _ Cetacea _ of the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence , which was , [I]2232-that navigator believe , handed in . ”[2232-that navigator] In [Champlain]411-champlain ’s day it was commonly called “ [the Great River of Canada]152-the great river of canada . ”[411-champlain] More than [one nation]2244-one nation has claimed it . In [Ogilby]500-ogilby ’s “ America of 1670 , ”[500-ogilby] in the map _ [Novi Belgii]241-novi belgii _ , it is called “ [De Groote Rivier van Niew Nederlandt]501-de groote rivier van niew nederlandt . ”[500-ogilby] It bears different names in different parts of [its]241-novi belgii course , as it flows through what were formerly [the territories of [different nations]2246-different nations]2245-the territories of different nations . From [the Gulf]62-the gulf to [Lake Ontario]242-lake ontario [it]242-lake ontario is called at present the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence ; from [Montreal]15-montreal to [the same place]2247-the same place [it]242-lake ontario is frequently called [the Cateraqui]243-the cateraqui ; and higher up [it]242-lake ontario is known successively as [the Niagara]124-niagara , [Detroit]245-detroit , [St. Clair]246-st. clair , [St. Mary ’s]247-st. mary ’s , and [St. Louis]92-st. louis rivers . Humboldt , speaking of [the Orinoco]248-the orinoco , says that this name is unknown in [the interior of [the country]750-the country]2248-the interior of the country ; so likewise [the tribes that dwell about [the sources of [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence]2251-the sources of the st. lawrence have never heard the name which [it]242-lake ontario bears in [the lower part of [its]242-lake ontario course]2252-the lower part of its course]2250-the tribes that dwell about the sources of the st. lawrence have never heard the name which it bears in the lower part of its course . It rises near [another father of [waters,—the Mississippi,—issuing]249-waters,—the mississippi,—issuing]2253-another father of waters,—the mississippi,—issuing from a remarkable spring far up in [the woods]1463-the woods , called [Lake Superior]250-lake superior , fifteen hundred miles in circumference ; and several other springs there are thereabouts which feed [it]242-lake ontario . It makes such a noise in its tumbling down at one place as is heard all round [the world]741-the world . [Bouchette]450-bouchette , [the Surveyor - General of [the Canadas]133-the canadas]2256-the surveyor - general of the canadas , calls it “ [the most splendid river on [the globe ”]5316-the globe ”]5315-the most splendid river on the globe ”[2256-the surveyor - general of the canadas] ; says that it is two thousand statute miles long ( [more recent geographers]2257-more recent geographers make it four or five hundred miles longer ) ; that at the [Rivière du Sud]251-rivière du sud [it]242-lake ontario is eleven miles wide ; at [the Traverse]252-the traverse , thirteen ; at [the Paps of Matane]253-the paps of matane , twenty - five ; at [the Seven Islands]2258-the seven islands , seventy - three ; and at [its]242-lake ontario mouth , from [Cape Rosier]254-cape rosier to [the Mingan Settlements]255-the mingan settlements in [Labrador]256-labrador , near one hundred and five ( ? ) miles wide . According to [Captain Bayfield]502-captain bayfield ’s recent chart it is about _ ninety - six _ geographical miles wide at the latter place , measuring at right angles with [the stream]1637-the stream . [It]1637-the stream has much the largest estuary , regarding both length and breadth , of [any river on [the globe]2261-the globe]2260-any river on the globe . [Humboldt]503-humboldt says that [the river Plate]2262-the river plate , which has [the broadest estuary of [the South American rivers]2264-the south american rivers]2263-the broadest estuary of the south american rivers , is ninety - two geographical miles wide at its mouth ; also [he]503-humboldt found [the Orinoco]248-the orinoco to be more than three miles wide at five hundred and sixty miles from its mouth ; but [he]503-humboldt does not tell [us]2265-us that [ships of six hundred tons]917-ships of six hundred tons can sail up it so far , as [they]917-ships of six hundred tons can up the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence to [Montreal,—an]257-montreal,—an equal distance . If [he]503-humboldt had described [a fleet of such ships]2267-a fleet of such ships at anchor in [[a city]916-a city ’s port]2269-a city ’s port so far inland , [we]2265-us should have got a very different idea of [the Orinoco]248-the orinoco . Perhaps [Charlevoix]440-charlevoix describes [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence truly as [the most _ navigable _ river]2270-the most _ navigable _ river in [the world]741-the world . Between [Montreal]15-montreal and [Quebec]16-quebec it averages about two miles wide . The tide is felt as far up as [Three Rivers]258-three rivers , four hundred and thirty - two miles , which is as far as from [Boston]8-boston to [Washington]30-washington . As far up as [Cap aux Oyes]504-cap aux oyes , sixty or seventy miles below [Quebec]16-quebec , [Kalm]425-kalm found a great part of the plants near [the shore]846-the shore to be marine , as [glass - wort ( _ Salicornia _ ) , seaside pease ( _ Pisum maritimum _]2273-glass - wort ( _ salicornia _ ) , seaside pease ( _ pisum maritimum _ ) , [sea - milkwort]2274-sea - milkwort ( _ Glaux _ ) , beach - grass ( _ Psamma arenarium _ ) , seaside plantain ( _ Plantago maritima _ ) , the sea - rocket ( _ Bunias cakile _ ) , & c.

The geographer [Guyot]505-guyot observes that [the Maranon]259-the maranon is three thousand miles long , and gathers [its]259-the maranon waters from a surface of a million and a half square miles ; that [the Mississippi]186-the mississippi is also three thousand miles long , but [its]259-the maranon basin covers only from eight to nine hundred thousand square miles ; that [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence is eighteen hundred miles long , and [its]259-the maranon basin covers more than a million square miles ( [Darby]506-darby says five hundred thousand ) ; and speaking of [the lakes]2275-the lakes , [he]506-darby adds , “ [These vast fresh - water seas]5317-these vast fresh - water seas , together with [the St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence , cover [a surface of nearly one hundred thousand square miles]5318-a surface of nearly one hundred thousand square miles , and it has been calculated that [they]5317-these vast fresh - water seas contain about one half of all the fresh water on the surface of [[our]5319-our planet]5320-our planet . ”[506-darby] But all these calculations are necessarily very rude and inaccurate . Its tributaries , the [Ottawa]260-ottawa , [St. Maurice]261-st. maurice , and [Saguenay]154-the saguenay , are great rivers [themselves]2276-themselves . [The latter]2277-the latter is said to be more than one thousand ( ? ) feet deep at its mouth , while its cliffs rise perpendicularly an equal distance above its surface . [Pilots]2278-pilots say there are no soundings till one hundred and fifty miles up the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence . The greatest sounding in [the river]905-the river , given on [Bayfield]262-bayfield ’s chart of [the gulf]2280-the gulf and [river]2281-river , is two hundred and twenty - eight fathoms . [McTaggart]508-mctaggart , [an engineer]2282-an engineer , observes that “ [the Ottawa]5321-the ottawa is larger than [all the rivers in [Great Britain]263-great britain]5322-all the rivers in great britain , were [they]5322-all the rivers in great britain running in one . ”[2283-the traveller grey] [The traveller Grey]2283-the traveller grey writes : “ A dozen Danubes , [Rhines]264-rhines , [Taguses]265-taguses , and [Thameses]266-thameses would be nothing to twenty miles of fresh water in breadth ( as where [he]2283-the traveller grey happened to be ) , from ten to forty fathoms in depth . ”[2283-the traveller grey] And again : “ There is not perhaps in the whole extent of [this immense continent]5323-this immense continent so fine an approach to it as by [the river St. Lawrence]5324-the river st. lawrence . In [the Southern States]5325-the southern states [you]5326-you have , in general , [a level country]5327-a level country for many miles inland ; here [you]5326-you are introduced at once into a majestic scenery , where everything is on a grand scale,—mountains , [woods]1440-woods , [lakes]832-lakes , [rivers , precipices , waterfalls]5330-rivers , precipices , waterfalls . ”[2283-the traveller grey]

[We]2284-we have not yet the data for a minute comparison of the [St. Lawrence]48-the st. lawrence with [the South American rivers]2264-the south american rivers ; but it is obvious that , taking it in connection with [[its]2264-the south american rivers lakes]2286-its lakes , [[its]2264-the south american rivers estuary]2287-its estuary , and [its]2264-the south american rivers falls , it easily bears off the palm from all the rivers on [the globe]2261-the globe ; for though , as [Bouchette]450-bouchette observes , it may not carry to [the ocean]1556-the ocean a greater volume of water than [the Amazon]267-the amazon and [Mississippi]186-the mississippi , [its]2264-the south american rivers surface and cubic mass are far greater than theirs . But , unfortunately , [this noble river]2290-this noble river is closed by ice from the beginning of December to [the middle of April]2291-the middle of april . The arrival of [the first vessel from [England]31-england]2292-the first vessel from england when the ice breaks up is , therefore , a great event , as when the salmon , shad , and alewives come up [a river]1643-a river in the spring to relieve [the famishing inhabitants on [[its]2290-this noble river banks]2295-its banks]2294-the famishing inhabitants on its banks . Who can say what would have been the history of [this continent]2296-this continent if , as has been suggested , [this river]1085-this river had emptied into [the sea]2243-the sea where [New York]45-new york stands !

After visiting [the Museum]2299-the museum and taking one more look at the wall , [I]0-i made haste to [the Lord Sydenham steamer]1925-the lord sydenham steamer , which at five o’clock was to leave for [Montreal]15-montreal . [I]0-i had already taken a seat on [deck]2301-deck , but finding that [I]0-i had still an hour and a half to spare , and remembering that large map of [Canada]1-canada which [I]0-i had seen in the parlor of the restaurateur in [my]0-i search after pudding , and realizing that [I]0-i might never see the like out of [the country]750-the country , [I]0-i returned thither , asked liberty to look at the map , rolled up the mahogany table , put [my]0-i handkerchief on it , stood on it , and copied all [I]0-i wanted before [the maid]2303-the maid came in and said to [me]0-i standing on the table , “ [Some gentlemen]5331-some gentlemen want [the room]1352-the room , [sir]5242-sir ”[2303-the maid] ; and [I]0-i retreated without having broken the neck of a single bottle , or [my]0-i own , very thankful and willing to pay for all the solid food [I]0-i had got . [We]2304-we were soon abreast of [Cap Rouge]269-cap rouge , [eight miles above [Quebec]16-quebec]1087-eight miles above quebec , after [we]2304-we got underway . It was in [this place]5313-this place , then called “ _ [Fort du France]270-fort du france Roy _ , ”[447-roberval] that [the Sieur de Roberval]447-roberval with [[his]447-roberval company]2307-his company , having sent [home]867-home two of [[his]447-roberval three ships]2309-his three ships , spent the winter of 1542 - 43 . It appears that [they]2309-his three ships fared in the following manner ( [I]0-i translate from the original ): “ Each mess had only two loaves , weighing each a pound , and half a pound of beef . [They]2309-his three ships ate pork for dinner , with half a pound of butter , and beef for supper , with about two handfuls of beans , without butter . Wednesdays , Fridays , and Saturdays [they]2309-his three ships ate salted cod , and sometimes green , for dinner , with butter ; and porpoise and beans for supper . [Monsieur Roberval]509-monsieur roberval administered good justice , and punished each according to [his]509-monsieur roberval offence .
